RATING: 10
I've had the privilege and pleasure of being involved in the playtesting of the prototype since May 2010 and saw it evolve. The game I played back then was great.. the finished game is phenomenal! 

The game is truly an epic 4X civilization-building game, but it doesn't take all day to play. It is built upon very intuitive mechanics that allow you to play the [i]game[/i], not the system. It is in essence very much a eurogame with loads and loads of highly immersive theme seamlessly integrated into the package. 

The gameplay is so exciting it keeps you at the edge of your seat, but the balance between strategy and luck feels good (by playing smart, luck is [i]very[/i] manageable). 

First rating after first (early prototype) playtest games: [size=14][BGCOLOR=#66FF99][COLOR=#66FF99]_[/COLOR][size=8][b]8.5[/b][/size][COLOR=#66FF99]_[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR][/size] - May 2010

Improved rating after several (developed prototype) playtest games: [size=14][BGCOLOR=#00CC99][COLOR=#00CC00]_[/COLOR][size=6][COLOR=#00CC99]_[/COLOR][size=8][b]9[/b][/size][COLOR=#00CC99]_[/COLOR][/size][COLOR=#00CC99]_[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR][/size] - November 2010

Improved rating after more (late prototype) playtest games: [size=14][BGCOLOR=#00CC99][COLOR=#00CC00]_[/COLOR][size=8][b]9.5[/b][/size][COLOR=#00CC99]_[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR][/size] - March 2011

May 2011 Update: The finished game and components design is simply exceptional. If the production value is right, I fully expect to give this game full marks.

Rating after playing the the final (pre)production copy: [size=14][BGCOLOR=#00CC00][COLOR=#00CC00]_[/COLOR][size=2][COLOR=#00CC00]_[/COLOR][size=8][b]10[/b][/size][COLOR=#00CC00]_[/COLOR][/size][COLOR=#00CC00]_[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR][/size] - The quality of game components is as high as the ambitious design deserves. The game looks gorgeous and plays like a dream. I'm pretty sure this will become my favourite board game of all time.

UPDATE: I'm finding some people's complaints about "luck" more and more ridiculous. They're only indicative of their own inexperience and inability to play the game well. The rules are deceptively easy to grasp but true understanding of different strategies and how to play the game competitively might take a lot more effort. Apparently some people never get it. 

I just played a game (including the expansion in playtesting) where 6 out of my 7 explores where ancients, including my first four hex pulls and I was sitting next to Draco. I ended up discarding two hexes over the course of the game and even the only one without an ancient had a Warp gate. Sounds bad? I was "screwed by luck"? You know what happened? I won by a landslide, because I adapted to the situation and chose my strategy accordingly. 

The game has several random elements to ensure replayability and excitement, but calling it "luck-based" is a load of bull****.

RATING: 9
Beatiful game with space exploration and combat.
It's fast (for a 4X game,if the players know the game it is 30 minutes per player), with little downtime. The different races are quite interesting (especially those from the expansions), and I wouldn't recommend to play with humans. I like a lot the possibility to upgrade your ships  in a lot of different ways, allowing very different combat strategies.
It's quite a strict game (you never have all the resources you want), but I think all the people who define eclipse a eurogame in space (I think I've seen on the forums the definition "accountants go to space") are just plain wrong imho. You have 3 different resources (used for different things) to manage, but it always requires only a look at your player board and a single sum/subtraction.

RATING: 8
Not the epic flavor-fest that Twilight Imperium is, Eclipse holds its own ground with an innovative economic system that keeps everything moving and flowing smoothly. Taking up a ton of table-space, Eclipse does so many things right, that it creates a sort of hybrid experience, bringing some random elements of Ameritrash and crossing it with a highly polished Euro resource management system.

My favorite parts revolve around the technological improvements, building up a unique armada and testing it against your foes. You could also go the peaceful route if you'd like, exploring the system, hoping to find ancient alien technology, and establishing monoliths and orbitals along the way, gaining resources and VPs, without dealing in space battles. Or, depending on the number of players, feel free to form alliances and boost each other's resource income, defending each other against other aggressive enemies. Trading in your alliance for a quick grab of power will earn you a traitor card with negative VPs, but it just may be worth it if the opportunity presents itself. 

Eclipse is a Euro's Space Epic. It doesn't quite bring the story and expansiveness and unpredictability of other space games, but it is an effortlessly solid and glowing tribute to the sci-fi genre.

RATING: 10
2012-02-06
After numerous plays of the final product:
Excellent production value + A game that keeps you in its grip still after several plays = A TEN

2016-10-12
Eclipse satisfies the need for a civilization game in almost every possible way. It is epic enough without suffering from being too long or being guilty of too much micromanaging that ultimately has no or very little impact on the outcome of the game. Every action you take feels significant and almost always you are one or two actions short of accomplishing everything you want which creates interesting trade-offs to ponder. Eclipse also manages to overcome the hurdle of book-keeping with your ever growing empire. All information is easy to read and very little time is spent on calculating things allowing you to concentrate solely on playing. And perhaps the coolest thing about the whole game is that you get to create your own ship blueprints!!!

There are a few minor things that might start to annoy you after a while though. First off, the non-player enemies (Ancients) are all the same. On the couple of first plays this won't bother you but personally I would have liked some variety to them. Now you have a bunch of standard ship blueprints you use to defeat the Ancients thus making this part of the game a bit scripted. However, the number and the timing of Ancients you encounter varies from game to game and hence this does not script the whole experience.

Another thing about the Ancients is that especially for new players they may seem invincible. Many have been ready to throw the game after "bad luck" with exploring when they have found their homeworld being surrounded by Ancients. I must say that the situation may seem dire but you can usually make a comeback and fight for the win. However, facing this kind of a situation on your first play can be truly devastating for the experience causing these players never to look back once they leave the table.

Third thing is that after a few rounds there is very little incentive to add a odd number of hull to your ship blueprints. All more powerful weapons deal an even number of damage thus making odd hull useless. Hence there are times when the Improved Hull technology feels a bit over powered to me. This feeling is further magnified by the Plasma Missile technology.

Fourth and perhaps my biggest complaint is about the art. I really like the subtle and extremely functional graphic design which helps to create a right kind of atmosphere. But oh man, the generic art on the faction sheets and the box really is not to my taste. Almost all alien races are of humanoid type thus showing very little imagination. It almost feels like watching Star Trek. Moreover, all races are portrayed from the front with their torso and face visible. It makes me feel like I am at a gallery of mugshots.

Nevertheless, despite its minor shortcomings Eclipse is truly a great game that delivers you bags of fun. You are operating on both, the short term tactical level and on the longer term strategic level. You also get the satisfaction of actually accomplishing something when you watch your empire grow. Personally I also love the sci-fi setting.

RATING: 8
Finally got to play Eclipse with a group today! Overall I was very impressed. A few underwhelming aspects, and a few items seemed unbalanced, but on the whole a great streamlined empire-builder. The way a small set of components is used for multiple purposes is brilliant.

Neutron bombs are ridiculously cheap for what they do; ground combat in general is a hand wave. 

The plasma missiles are nuttily OP. 

Combat in general is very anticlimactic and, compared to the economic engine of the game, very inelegant. Like after each round of a beautiful are control game you suddenly revert to RISK to decide all confrontations. 

Lastly, it is possible for a player, through luck of the sector draw, luck of available technologies and turn order, the vagaries of 'wormhole' alignment, and presence of the Elders, to be sealed off from interaction with other players and/or economically stifled. Effective player isolation / suppression. 

This is based on 1 play of the base game. Look forward to more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The good news is, it is the game that Space Empires should have been. And the bad news is its more expensive and got published second [and Space Empires XXXX was 20 years in the making...damn!]. We played six-player and I'm not sure that worked as well as a smaller number might. Its simple, and therefore may be good for a few plays before you turn to other Essen releases. The main variations are travel possibilities between tiles and the selections of technology tiles that are available each turn, which are concerned with warship operation and production, but of course you buy whatever is available that you can afford. So the choice is limited, even if you go first.

The trouble with simplicity is that its no friend to radical novelty, and here there are a few old clichés:  you can't fight more than one war, onesuch will bankrupt you, and the enemy can build new ships in beleaguered systems. Yawn.

RATING: 5
The economic system in this game is fantastic.  I also love the tech tree.  The way hexes are explored is a bit luck dependent for this type of heavy Euro.  My major beef though is the issue of player interaction.  If you are next to an aggressive military race you are either going to be stomped or forced to spend a lot of resources protecting your home system from attack.  Conversely if someone ignores a peaceful race on the other side of the galaxy they will have an easy time, building up their economic engine.  The alliance system does nothing to address this as it averages the scores so once you have either fallen behind or have been stomped into last no one wants to ally with you. This coupled with the length of the game is Monopoly style misery.`

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Absolutely incredible experience. Think Euro economic mechanics (a la Power Grid) meets territory control and combat (a la Risk), but with tech trees and customizable ships (a la the Civ video game series), all set within something like the Mass Effect universe.

Eclipse blends Euro mechanics with a great theme and fun combat mechanics. While the rulebook looks daunting, it is very well laid out, with a good portion devoted to a play-by-play example game. Couple that with UndeadViking's great how-to video, and you should be up and running in no time.

While Eclipse looks quite complicated, a graceful and elegant game lies behind the imposing appearance. With only 6 actions to choose from, the gameplay is streamlined and sensible.

The components are well-built, the art is great, and the player mat is extremely well designed and straightforward.

I had an absolute blast playing, and I can't wait to get it to the table again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Changed my rating from 9 to 7 and now to 6.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.92
Abstract:
"Fast" 4X space game with economic elements.

Prs:
+ Quite fast
+ Upgrading ships is fun
+ Alliance system (light and easy, but no real trading)
+ Ability to still react after passing
+ The economy system is cool, but lots of cubes require a game board that holds all of them in place

Neutrals:
# NPC aliens are quite fun, however, they appear too randomly and may encircle you in the beginning of the game.
# Upkeep limits your actions
# You have to diversify your technologies
# Two-Step for technology research + upgrade may feel a bit slowly
# Traitor mechanic can lead to stalemates
# Minis are okay (lacking details)

Cons:
- Tight resources and economic emphasis forces you to play rather efficient, cautious, and avoid losses. 
- Tight resources likely restrict your ability to move or act, if you do not research the right technologies.
- Too much randomness: exploration / hex tiles, ancient tiles, victory tiles, technology tiles, missiles
- Strong focus on combat because of victory tiles.
- Combat gets clunky: compare all ship-types' abilities and match them with each dice roll
- Artwork is not good (hopefully be better in second edition)
- Fiddly due to lots of technology tiles: frequently search or sort them
- No catch-up mechanic: it quickly gets even worse as soon as you loose a lot of ships or a system (the upkeep system does not mitigate that well enough)

Thoughts:
Eclipse (first edition) is a quite fast, fun 4X space game. My biggest complaint is the luck-factor which occurs nearly everywhere in the game. I also do not like the focus on combat which is strongly awarded by the game. Regardless of all negative points, I still like to play Eclipse.
I like Twilight Imperium 4th Edition much better - it is not that much longer with 5-6 players, more elegant, deeper, and epic.

Similar to:
* Exodus: Proxima Centauri is very similar to Eclipse but seems to be better in most parts. It is a bit more aggressive. It also has an expansion to play coop!

Player: 2-6 (best: 4, 6) | Time: 60-240m

RATING: 7.5
Eclipse is a good game and a missed 10 for me, since this game has a lot of great ideas and mechanisms, but I've really a problem with some of its aspects. I love the technologies, the possibility to customize the spaceships and the different powers of the alien races. The components are great and the artwork is excellent! I like the different strategies, the action selection mechanism and the combat resolution.

What brings this game down to be "just" a good game is basically a combination of rules that I don't like. The bag is the first one, because I think it's a very stupid way to determine the points you receive from a battle. It doesn't makes sense at all and it just adds unnecessary and negative randomness to the game, that can cause significant point swings. I also have a problem with the exploration, because you can get some bad random tiles and find yourself simply behind the others for that only. I know that you are supposed to fight for the best tiles, but it still bothers me that someone can jump ahead just because he/she was lucky enough to find the good ones.

Eclipse could have been the game I was searching for as a 4X game, but - for these issues - it's "just" a medium-good game that failed to be awesome for me. I still enjoy it, but I'm a little annoyed by some simply strange rules.

RATING: 9.5
It was the first scy fi game I've played, and I have a very good care of this one, it is relatively simple and elegant, beautiful.

The best part in this game is the way you build the blueprints of your ships, researching tecnology to build new wepon, shield, computer, energy source, hull. The customization of your ship and build for combat is great.

The way you track the incomming of the resources is very elegant, too, despite of the long setup.

Tecnology track is good, but there is an unecessary randomness here, the way to mitigate this is trying to be the first player, to guarantee the best tecnology available first. The alternate order of play variant, or the order of pass play variant makes this even better and fair. The only problem here is that some key strategies may not work if you need an advanced economy, or advanced science, mining.

The exploration is very interesting and makes the game change every new play. Of course you can be stuck if you find just ancient ships in the first round and be surrounded by them and be not possible to colonize the new sectors discovered. But in the other hand when you fight them, if you fight them earlier, you have a good chance to collect better reputation.

The combat is simple and functional, and have lots of modifiers depending on the type of wepon, quantity of cannons, difference between the computer and the shield and of course the thick of the hulls.

The different races put an assimetry of play in this game, after some plays it seems balanced.

I love to play this game.

RATING: 8.5
[i]2016/12/27 3 plays 3-4p[/i]

(copy-pasted from Scythe comment)

To me Scythe feels like an evolution from Eclipse. Same hexagonal play area (but not modular), same central galactic core (factory), asymmetric powers, space ships (mechas).

Scythe lacks an exploration phase, and the opportunity for players to build their galaxy by choosing how to place system tiles.

Also, there is no mecha customization, whereas spaceship design is a strong suit of Eclipse.

In Scythe combat is much more streamlined, which is really a plus, but it's much less epic than with Eclipse.

Scythe offers more modularity in the asymmetric powers by randomly combining two player faction boards, whereas Eclipse has fixed boards (but more of them with the expansions).

Artwork in Scythe completely crushes Eclipse. Scythe art is beautiful and distinct, Eclipse artwork is generic and uninspired.

Eclipse plays nine turns, Scythe endgame is activated by achieving 6 "goals", which is a mechanic I disliked.

I had the feeling that Scythe played faster than Eclipse.

Scythe has a popularity mechanic, whereas Eclipse only has a puny "traitor" negative tile.

Scythe has a seemingly great solo module, but as I don't own neither Eclipse, nor Scythe, that is irrelevant to me.

Given the choice, I'll play Eclipse any time over Scythe. The tension, epic scale, diversity of strategies are much grander in Eclipse than Scythe.

Please, design Eclipse with better artwork, and fix the combat mechanic.

RATING: 8
There are lots of things I like about Eclipse (exploring, techs, the 4x style, customizing my ships, variable player powers). There are some things I particularly don't like (too much luck in combat, mainly). It's a good game, I just don't love it overmuch. Which is too bad, because there's too few games out there shooting for the '4x' or 'light civ' style. 

If the combat was less swingy, I'd like it more. If there were just a few more options to build up your civ other than the generic monuments for VP and techs that by and large enhance your ability for warfare--I'd like it a lot more. Another thing I wish is that there were more interesting races. Some of them are cool. Others are... eh. More of the same.

I think it's "very good" mainly because it's the only option available in its weight and category, so go Eclipse for being there! It's also "very good" mainly if and because you can play it in a reasonable amount of time. If players drag the game on... it can be a drag. But Eclipse does its best, I think, to try to keep the game clipping along. So thanks for that, Eclipse.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After three plays of Eclipse, I'm admiring the cleverness of its design more than enjoying it as a game.  The way in which it applies euro design principles to the bloated, fiddly 4x genre, making systems streamlined and intuitive is really, really impressive.

Most impressive to me is the resource system.  Just three resources, with each planet supplying one type.  Eclipse's system of  the space vacated by population cubes transferred from your player board to those planets keeping track of your income works like a charm.  

The action system is pretty clever too.  Influence discs are spent both on taking actions and on controlling sectors of space, so it's cheaper for a smaller, more efficient empire to get things done. What's more, even with six players, the single action per player turn means that there is little downtime.  

The tech system rewards the player who develops steadily along one branch of the tech tree with discounts.  However,there aren't the A to B to C constraints of some other games.

So, lots to admire, but...Are there real strategic alternatives?  An  arms race to gain an advantage in the ship technologies seems inevitable.  To compete technologically you need more resources, so you need more planets; staying small but efficient doesn't appear a realistic option.

A couple more caveats. The alien races are more interesting to play than the humans, but they don't seem well balanced.  Second, the game ends after nine turns and there are no victory points for surviving ships.  According to your tastes, this either brings the game to an exciting climax or leads to rather gamey end of the universe sorts of behaviour.

The graphic design of Eclipse is clear and functional, and shows how to do icons well.  The artwork is less inspired.  The second edition rulebook is a model of clarity.

RATING: 9.5
Finally got a chance to try Eclipse last week and it was worth the wait.  Other than the fact that it is not historical, in terms of both theme and mechanics, it has virtually everything that I find compelling in a strategic game.  Technology ladder, grand scope, economic engine, strategic and tactical play, risk taking, direct but muted conflict (and thus a nearly ideal amount of player interaction from my POV).  Of the games I've played in the last 2 years, the only one that exceeds it is Dominant Species and that might just because I know the game better.  There are a lot of moving parts, but the mechanics are very intuitive and other than keeping track of and remembering the technologies (which would not have been a problem if we had a cheat sheet available), the game is remarkably easy to pick up.

RATING: 10
Includes:
[thing=125898][/thing]
[thing=179255][/thing]

:arrowE: [u]Synopsis[/u]:
eXplore. eXpand. eXploit. eXterminate. A gorgeous 4X game which is secretly a concise Euro gilt with Ameritrash glory. Diplomacy, backstabbing, resource management, empire management, variable powers, custom ship design, tech-tree-which-is-not-on-rails, long term strategy, tactical agency, big tiles, big ships, lots of cubes and discs, amazing insta-upkeep display for each player, intuitive combat modifiers and economic planning, strong graphic design, theme-if-you-want-it, and tons of variability and combos. Eclipse is, without a doubt, a game that touches on essentially everything I want out of a board game. 

:arrowE: [u]What I like most[/u]:
It's a toss-up between the customized ship design via technology, and the overall emergent gameplay between aggression and turtling. To the first point, the majority of researched technology unlocks ship parts which can be slotted over the schematics for various ships and fixed structures. This means that one player can pursue heavy, tanky ships with lots of hull, others can focus very energy-intensive and expensive weapons, while others can focus on maneuverability and targeting--in fact, most games see a small meta develop based on what is being slapped on what ships, so everyone responds accordingly. To the second point, everyone gets victory points for combat, but that doesn't mean you need to be a warmonger. Spreading oneself too thin affords for eventual losses without defense, while doing very little combat at all can be stilling from a points perspective. Balancing the two extremes is very cool. Firing Anti-Matter Cannons into someone's face is also very cool.

:arrowE: [u]What I like least[/u]:
Like any game with negotiation and emergent alliances, there is the possibility for kingmaking here. It doesn't happen often, but it's happened to me, and that sucks. Period.

RATING: 7
For what this game aspires to be, a space-based war game with some euro mechanics thrown in, this game is excellent, and in its own way, well-designed.  

This game has a very steep learning curve in terms of all the ship capabilities, and on first play (we played with 5 players, two experienced, 3 first timers including myself) it took over 4 hours to play, which for my tastes, is too long...and I won the game.

This game is rightly considered a war game, and is undoubtedly creating a frenzy of excitement with the war gamers at BGG, which I think is great.  It is worthy.  

The interesting thing to consider for me, going forward, is whether the euro gamers at BGG (like me) will rate this war game as highly.  For us, there are some euro aspects to the game: resource management, exploration, monument building (though they are small, ugly chits), and I suppose, building a cool ship with pride of ownership, but fundamentally, and predominantly, this is a war game.  

If you don't like war games, you are not going to like this game.  If you don't like attacking and rolling dice, and being attacked and rolling dice, you won't like this.  Hate Risk? You won't like this game.

RATING: 5
Finally got this to the table and managed to play half a game.  The group was enthralled.  I completely expect this to be a 10, although still going to be quite difficult to bring it out consistently.

===
We played a full second game and it was still hugely enjoyable.  Favourite part was that, although I didn't win, I did cost the winning player (who was my direct adversary all game) to lose by forging an alliance and immediately attacking another player to break it (setting him back a VP token of actual value).  Everyone still wants to play more.
Perhaps not perfect, but easily warrants its position on the charts (still think the overall 'economy' mechanic is brilliant).

===
So some time has settled and we've played with the expansion, and I think there's only so much to like about Eclipse.  What probably made it so enjoyable the first few times when we didn't finish is that the game is most exciting in the first few turns and peaks at the mid-point.  It's often easy to tell who will win by that point, making the rest of the game a slow grind to the finish for everyone else.  Alliances don't have a 'nicely handled' version at this point, which compounds this problem.
The technology tree is still nice, especially with building your own ships.  The economy engine is also still really smart.  But it just falls flat past a point.
===

Sold off, November 2015.

RATING: 7
What is really annoying about this game is the fact that it is in the top 10 of BGG. It doesn't deserve it and it is something that I don't understand.

First of all there is terrible randomness in one of the more important elements of the game during the first round: the exploration. One player can draw an excellent tile with Planets full of production or even a technology without effort while other player can find an ancient enemy and therefore has to build ships and spend time conquering it and maybe not to get a great reward. To sum up, you can be out of the game since the very start. 

Absurd randomness is still present in the technology that players can research. The middle of the game consists in a race struggling for this technology and more ships, more than that struggling to buy a technology the wich your opponents can not resist because generally is not possible to get a copy of it or even the technology that matches it doesn't appear from the bag.  

So we get the last round where the man who were lucky, bought that technology and armed his ships with it, devastates the other players, wins the play and the others feel like idiots.
 
Its rating in BGG has not sense, and I am not eager to play this game ever again.

-------

Lo que fastidia de este juego es cómo puede estar en el top 10 de BGG. Simplemente no lo merece y es algo que no puedo entender. 

Lo primero de todo, hay un azar terrible en uno de los elementos más importantes durante los primeros compases de partida: La exploración. 
Un jugador puede robar una loseta llena de planetas con producción, o incluso obtener una tecnología gratis sin esfuerzo alguno, mientras que otro se encuentra a enemigos ancestrales, por lo que tiene que gastar más tiempo y fabricar naves inmediatamente para conquistar esa loseta y obtener una recompensa que puede ser incluso poca cosa. En resumidas cuentas, te puedes ver fuera de la partida desde el turno uno. 

El azar absurdo sigue presente en la tecnología que los jugadores pueden investigar. La parte media de la partida consiste en una carrera para obtener tecnología y naves, o más bien, para obtener una tecnología que el resto de jugadores no puedan contrarrestar porque es habitual que no se pueda obtener una copia de ella o la tecnología que la contrarresta no sale de la bolsa, o no todos pueden tenerla. 

Así llegamos a la ronda final, donde el hombre que tuvo suerte, que consiguió dar con esa tecnología irresistible y que con ella arma sus naves, pasa por encima de sus enemigos en un combate final que importa poco, gana la partida y el resto se sienten como idiotas. 

No se entiende su puntuación y desde luego no tengo ganas de repetir experiencia tras una primera partida.

RATING: 8
Rating based on one play.

After reading the instructions and setting up, I was a little skeptical of how much I would like this.  I've been underwhelmed in the past by some designs that tried to mimic the complexity of computer games.  I felt I spent so much time doing the accounting -- the part the computer should be doing -- that it was hard to get into the game.

But I found this to not be the case with Eclipse.  The accounting was very easy and came naturally.  And that left me free to focus on a game with a wide variety of comprehensible choices and strategies.  I'm looking forward to playing it again.

RATING: 9

One thing that everybody would agree is that it take WAY too long to setup, and it needs a BIG table to play due to the exploration tiles being so big. One game could possibly take 3-4 hours, but I will guarantee that it will be a lot of tension and its extremely hard to get the "Runaway leader" effect.  Highly recommended for regular board gamers.  If you are a casual gamer, I would give it a chance but I warn you that it takes a long time to play and a long time to setup, so be PATIENT (the game is worth it).  The price it a little bit to high for casual gamers, but for veteran gamers its perfect, due to the amount of pieces this game had.  The races in the game are nice, and even if you just play humans all the time it seems that every race has its own theme.  Before you completely say NO to this game I highly suggest you play it with 3 players.

RATING: 10
10/6/16: Bumped up to a 10.  This game is a great experience and the best of its class.

8/13/2015: Bumped up from an 8 to a 9 because this still gets fairly regular play 3 years on in my gaming group.

3/28/12: The latest must have 'it' game.  A very nice space exploration game, and it does several things right.  Good production values, well playtested, and not rushed into production unlike so many other games these days.

In my opinion better than Twilight Imperium, which I consider overwrought.  Certainly faster paced that Twilight Imperium, but not a thematic game.  Like most civ building games, there is development of an economic engine under the hood, and I appreciate that more than the combat.  I do like the part of being able to customize your ships, and I'm starting to see that there is some skill in how you upgrade. I disagree with others that say this game ends too soon.

However I've got this nagging feeling that after the initial glow wears off, this will be a very good game, but not the end all game.  For me it's perhaps biased a little too much towards combat, though I won by avoiding combat.  This is a nit, but the colors for the 3 resources are a little too close together.  Rating more likely to go up than down.  

One thing that has me nervous is that more than one battle has been decided by who could be the first to roll a 6 on their dice.  There is a moderate amount of luck in this game and you need to be comfortable with that.

Just starting to learn the differences in the races.  My perspective is that the Eridani are harder to play than the others.  Will have to spend more time with this.

Plays well with 4-6 players.  Played 5 players with 3 newbies in 4 hours.  A little concerned that in 5 players, the ones on the edge have the advantage.  With more players it can become a much more aggressive game due to limited resources.

RATING: 5
Overall, I was left feeling disappointed with this game. It has plenty of interesting and clever mechanics, though in fairness it owes quite a bit to Through the Ages. It also felt like it could flow quite smoothly, implying a short playtime, neither a given in these kind of civilization games. In terms of the game design, however, I had a big issue with the high degree of randomness: not so much the combat, where it can to a very large extent be minimized through smart ship design, but in the exploration and research steps - you can consistently get poor tiles and be locked out of important technologies you didn't know were coming through turn order quirks. I also didn't much care for the fact you can keep building ships in systems with enemy presence.

In the end, though, my biggest problem with the game is personal: I find I simply don't much enjoy these kind of development and confrontation games (though Through the Ages is a big exception, probably due to the more abstract military interaction). I generally tend to be too pacifist, and I think that sucks some of the fun out of them, particularly if other people behave similarly.

I might try this again, but it won't be for some time, and then I'd want to play with some house rules to mitigate the randomness.

RATING: 3
Where to start?

The technology system is bullshit.  You can scoop a tech via turn order, and then your opponent cannot research it, ever.  That's exactly the opposite way the technology works in real life, which is: You develop a technology, and your adversaries copy or steal it.

The exploration system is bullshit.  While all planets are more-or-less balanced overall, some people find awesome planets for their current situation, while others find flaming plasma death.  Since this is an economic game, finding unguarded planets early is a huge booster.

The scoring system is bullshit.  There are a set number of game turns, so feel free to do unthematic things like dismantling your empire, throwing your remaining fleet into a meat grinder, and researching worthless techs just to maximize your score.  Also, the grab bag of random battle chits is silly.  If you want to reward early aggression, just make those early chits worth more points.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
16-IX-2012. Por dónde empezar... Este juego está hecho para mí. En todo. Temática, aspecto, posibilidades, estrategias, mecánicas... Una maravilla. 

4 fases:
-A. El jugador inicial escoge entre seis acciones, muy intuitivas todas, la ejecuta (que durará unos 30 segundos) y pasa el turno al siguiente jugador que puede elegir una acción o pasar. Así hasta que todos pasan.
-B. Después, si hay contacto en un mismo hexágono de dos o más jugadores se resuelve a base de toñas con un sistéma de combate muy bien implementado y nada engorroso.
-C. Una fase de pago y cobro (unkeep), (que me evoca mucho al aroma del Through the Ages).
-D. Y para terminar una fase de limpieza muy sencilla y fácil de seguir.

El juego en realidad gira sobre tres de detalles: 
- Tres tipos de recursos (materiales, dinero y tecnología).
- Todos los planetas proporcionan uno de estos tres tipos de materiales. Por medio de un sistéma ingenioso y sencillo, mandas tus trabajadores especializados a trabajar esos mundos y recolectar este tipo de recursos... Cuantos más trabajadores tengas recolectando, más recurso recibirás en la fase de mantenimiento. De tal manera que todo está muy relacionado y de nada sirve expandirte y enfatizar en un tipo de recurso si dejas de lado los otros dos.  
- los discos que sirven para dos cosas: realizar tus acciones (a modo de trabajadores del Caylus) y reclamar los exágonos de la galaxia como tuyos (colocando uno de esos discos). Cuantos más discos uses, más dinero te costará pagar en la fase de unkeep.

Y ya está. Algún detalle más pero sencillo, intuitivo y con miles de posibilidades. Destacar sobre todo el manual y los iconos de todo el juego. Una currada del diseñador que habría que premiar. 

Para mí un diez. Always want to play y blablabla.

20-IV-2014.Edito: pedazo de juego. Ayer jugamos con las razas alienígenas por primera vez y el juego es delicioso. No le veo ninguna pega, me amoldo al juego perfectamente y todo lo veo tan perfectamente integrado y cohesionado que me hace disfrutar la partida como en pocos juegos. 
24-I-2015: Después de jugar cuatro partidas más con las razas le voy a poner una pega: si tienes mala suerte, la partida puede hacerse difícil. No siempre se tienen las mismas posibilidades de disfrutar, la suerte importa a la hora de descubrir mundos, naves, avances gratuitos... No me refiero al dado en el combate, esa suerte está asumida y agradecida, es... es otro rollo. Le voy a bajar la nota un pelín, porque eso no me pasa con los juegos a los que tengo puesto un 10. ¿9,8?. Vaya!, que me sigue chiflando!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pont ma került be a játék a top10-be (és előzte meg a Caylust), kíváncsian vártam hát, hogy kiderüljön, mitől ennyire nagy durranás. A szabály nagyon biztató volt...

És most, hogy kipróbáltam, azt kell mondjam, hogy nagyon jó játék, de azért nem egy műfajteremtő, korszakos darab. Sok jó ötlet van benne, sok régi dolog is visszaköszön persze, de a fő erénye, hogy jól össze van gyúrva. Emellett szép is. De nincs benne az általam eddig próbáltak közt a legjobb 10-ben.

Pozitívumok: Azt írtam az előbb, nem műfajteremtő a játék, de a worker placement műfajban mégis egy új evolúciós szintet képvisel, mert az akcióválasztó bábuk itt többfunkciósak, így minél több a területünk, annál kevesebb akciót tudunk választani. Az egyes akcióknak nem önálló költségei vannak, hanem az egész civilizációnknak van egy összköltsége. Számomra nagy újdonság a passz mechanizmusa: bizonyos akciók még passz után is használhatók korlátozott mértékben (=reakció). Jó ötlet a különféle (diplomácia ill. csatából származó) győzelmi pontok korlátja is (max 5 pontlapka). Bár diplomáciát nem használtunk (3 főnél nincs), jó ötlet az is (meg az áruló lapka is). Talán érhetne többet is, mint 1-1 pont. Mi csak az alap (földi) fajokkal játszottuk, a táposabb fajokkal szerintem nagyban nőhet az újrajátszhatóság. A csaták jók, az űrlapkák felépítése (életterek 2 szintje) is tetszik. Profi az ikonrendszer, igényes az egész (engem nem zavar a műanyag).

Negatívumok: sokan játszva durva hosszú lehet, nekünk 3 fővel volt 3 óra, szerintem 6 fővel legalább 6 óra (maga a szabály még 1 óra). Az űrhajók rendszere tetszik ugyan, de kicsit Galaxis roncsderbi koppintás érzete volt mindannyiunknak. A technológia lapkák közül csak kevés ötletes van, a legtöbb csak az egyes űrhajó elemek kifejlesztése. A kevesebb néha több... (A többiek nagyon kritikusak voltak a játékkal szemben, szerintük a túl sok alkatrész lapka volt túlzás, és feleslegesen túlbonyolítottnak tartották az űrhajó 2 fázisban történő építését: először kifejleszteni, utána megépíteni.) A szerencsefaktor viszonylag nagy, jópár helyen megjelenik, nem csak a csata kockák miatt, szinte minden lapkát húzunk. Elég sok idő ki- ill. belpakolni. Nem nyelvfüggő, de nagyon tematikus. Főleg sci-fi fanoknak ajánlott.

Kiegyenlítettségről egyelőre nem sokat tudok mondani: a spéci fajoknál kérdéses lehet... A játék végén ötleteltünk, és többféle nyerő stratégia is felmerült bennünk, de a fegyverkezés valószínűleg elengedhetetlen.

Összességében szinte bármikor játszanám, a hossza ellenére is, de egy játék alapján nem került be a kedvenceim közé.

---

Aludtam rá egyet:
+1 pozitívum: a sok féle technika nem egymásra épül, ez szerintem nagyon változatossá teszi a játékot. Akár csúcstechnológiát is kifejleszthet valaki néhány körön belül (bár kicsit ráfizetéses).
+1 negatívum: nagyon nagy helyet foglal a játék! A játékostáblák nem A4-esek, hanem majdnem A3 méretűek + ugyanekkora a fő tábla is, az űrpálya pedig kiszámíthatatlan méretű. Mi 3 játékossal teljesen belaktuk a 120 x 150-es asztalt, 6 fővel szerintem gondban lennénk, pedig még a Railroad Tycoon és a WOTR is elfér az asztalon.

Elhangzott olyan vélemény az asztalnál, hogy a játék Galaxis Roncsderbi mellett Shipyardból és Starcraftból van összegyúrva, ez kb. annyira igaz szerintem, mint ahogy az Agricola a Bohnanzából és a Caylusból lett gyúrva: van benne zöldség, meg vannak akciók.
---
Helyesbítek: ez nem worker placement, mert nem közös akciók vannak, és egyik akció sem korlátos.
---
A táblák készülhettek volna valamivel keményebbre.
---
3 parti után: elég nagy hiba a csata résznél szerintem, hogy aki kamikaze módon beáldoz egy kis űrhajót, az is húzhat egy hírnévlapkát, pusztán azért, mert részt vett egy csatában. Így aki végig nem csatázott semmit, a végén (már úgyis mindegy alapon) gyorsan csatába küldi minden minden űrhajóját egyesével, és így egy csomó hírnév lapkát húzhat. Közel annyi pontot szerezhet így a legprimitívebb űrhajóival is akár, mint az aki végig űrhajókra gyúrt, és csatázott. A játék továbbra se kedvenc, de a műfajban még nem próbáltam jobbat, szerintem a Starcraftnál és a Twilight Imperiumnál is jobb!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Eclipse is an excellently themed 4X structured game that uses moderate economy building and light combat to amazing effect. With so many unique races, variable galaxy topology,  random tech availability, and user driven ship design the game really is a crown pleaser as it gracefully scale from 3-6 players (9 with expansion). Eclipse is the best board game I have ever played. To give you an idea of the games we really enjoy, over the three years we have gotten great amount of play from 7 Wonders and 7 Wonders Duel, Coup, Avalon, Codenames, Star Realms, X-Wing TMG, Star Wars Imperial Assault, C&C Ancients, Race for the Galaxy, Lost Cities, Catan, Ticket to Ride, Small World, Sheriff of Nottingham, Patchwork, Jaipur, Blokus, Carcassone, Battleline, Forbidden Island and Desert, to name our most played games that we really enjoy. Eclipse, hands down, has passed them all as our family's favorite game. The strategy is deep and while most will argue if it is a wargame (only lightly) or a eurogame (moderately) the game is really a tactical diplomacy game which to many will appear odd on face value due to the limited overt diplomatic mechanisms. But the game is rich in concepts such as virtual fleets and the threat of weaker players to bomb planets of players with larger threatening fleets which requires a high degree of subtle negotiation to maximize your empire and direct attention elsewhere. The game is expertly designed and exceptionally balanced. Easily a "10" without the Rise of the Ancients expansion which, while in no way necessary, adds to an already exceptional game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Played three or four times, and enjoyed it every time. Develop your space outposts, gather resources, and build spaceships to defeat and colonise your opponents.

The game takes some set-up, and maybe half a game to really get used to the rules and object of the game, but once it clicks you can easily get hooked. There are two levels of play, standard human races that are all the same to get used to the game, then a number of alien races that change your starting set-up and the things that you can do in small but significant ways. The quality of game pieces is very good, and you get a lot, which is good given the high price tag.

There are a few quibbles, but they're quite minor. It can be a bit easy, especially with four or fewer players, to intentionally avoid conflict with other players and stay in your own bit of space, developing your defences in case anyone comes to pick on you. The set up time is fairly long, as is the game, and whoever manages to get the high level cannons for their ships first seems to get quite an advantage, as you get a lot of victory points simply from destroying other ships. Still a very enjoyable game, but will take a whole evening or afternoon to get a game in.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game was okay -- it felt a lot like Through the Ages, but with an exploration component and a bit more interesting economic engine.  Like TtA, the combat system seemed too separated from the rest of the game, and didn't offer a path to victory on its own.  I find that I'm not as interested in games that end after a certain number of turns, either.  It just always feels like it ends before you can do what you want.  As such, I would definitely play it again, as it is so popular a game, but I probably won't go looking for a game of it on my own.

RATING: 7.5
Eclipse is a piece of design genius.
The way resources are generated, actions are drafted and everything is managed through the (most awesome ever designed) player mat is so brilliant one wonders why noone thought about it before!
There is also a very clever mechanic (Reputation) to handle turtling.
The box is full of components, and the quality of the production is (almost) top-notch, so nothing is lacking in this department.
The game has definitely a story arc, it is engaging and fun to play, and it is shorter than most civilization games.
So... why Eclipse is not in my top10?
Apart from the very minor nitpicks about luck, I guess I am not in love with the way the large part of the techs is dedicated to ships upgrading, leading to a game where military upgrade and fighting is a necessity.
Of course these may be the trademarks of the 4x genre... And so I wonder if I have a problem with the genre itself...

The game is fun and has just the right amount of randomness to prevent it from becoming a stale Euro. The different races allow for different playstyles with only minor tweaks to the base rules. My only gripes at this point are a lack of negotiation abilities and lack of rich theme. It seems as if the designer purposefully left the game generic.

10 Plays: This game still feels very fresh and more plays have really highlighed the great care that the designer put into balancing the different victory conditions. Many of our plays have been won by a small margin of just a few VPs, despite everyone choosing different goals. I've now added the Rise of the Ancients expansion into the mix, which brings with it some background and theme, along with more races.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
Very well designed 4X game. It's short which means it hits the table often. There is great variety with the different races, board set-up and available techs. And it really has so many strategies to explore. Each race has quite a few ways to victory. Choosing the right one comes down to recognizing the opportunities presented by the game and your fellow players. Furthermore it is a clean and easy to learn system. Explanation can be done for the biggest part by just starting to play. As for once the great majority of rules just make sense. Also it scales pretty well. I've played with between 2 and 5 players and enjoyed every one game. It's amazing to see that gameplay in a 2 player game differs not that much from that in a 5 player game. Lastly the only (small) negative remark are the components. While being OK the tiles do get worn pretty quickly. The rest of the components are just standard and functional.

There has been some discussion about the influence of luck. I don't think luck plays a big part in this game as for me it's all about risk management. Players who take too many risks tend to lose and then blame it on bad luck. I blame it on bad play.

Gameplay: :star::star::star::star::star:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::star:
Fun/Social: :star::star::star::star::star:
Components: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar:
Rules: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:

Bought on february 16th 2013.

A superb game that matches a very clever resource management system with a 4x gameplay. One of my favourite games. I've played this with 11 different people and everybody loves it so far. My main problem is that I have yet to play it without someone new, which means always playing with Terrans and playtime being very long (typically one hour per player rather than the suggested 30 minutes per player). I am looking forward to playing this without having anyone new to the game involved.

Some pros:
- An overall great game that everybody who likes somewhat complex games enjoys.
- A great and intuitive resource management system
- While there is definitely luck involved with this game (which exlopartion hexes do you draw, which reputation tiles do you draw, do you have good dice rolls), I've found that in 4 out of the 5 games I've played, the player who made the best decisions also won the game.

Some cons:
- Somewhat complex.
- Rather long.
- Plasma missiles, while not game breaking or particularly overpowered, tend to make the game revolve around them when they show up. I feel that a power requirement of 1 would be a good house rule.

RATING: 9
An excellent space-faring game with compelling variability between races. It has everything you'd want out of a space 4X, and upgrading your ships is a really fun mechanic. My only complaint is that the diplomacy is handled in a very weak way and the benefits to diplomacy (and drawback to betrayal) are barely there. This is because the diplomatic connections themselves are more or less just symbolic.

I still love the game though, and I REALLY enjoy that when the game ends you'll have an overarching story about the growth of your galactic civilization.

RATING: 6
Pro's:

1) The empire management aspect is incredibly intuitive.
2) Aesthetics and art style suits the genre with the iconography being very well designed.
3) The cold war style arms race of technology and ship upgrading while trying to counter what your opponent is doing. Many people complain that plasma missiles or whatever are overpowered, I have found that NOT to be the case in my games as long as I kept up the arms race.

Con's:

1) Randomness of tile drawing can make it feel like your empire stagnates at turn one. It's like you instantly lost the game.
2) Battles can feel like a long drawn out messy slog.
3) Game will generally end just as things are about to ramp up. Kind of like listening to a song remixed by an idiot who cuts out the bit that everyone likes.
4) Setup time is a pain.
5) The bookkeeping/empire management part of this game is definitely well done from an intuitive point of view, but it slows the game down a lot and ends up being kind of disconnected from the 4X elements.

RATING: 6
When I heard other players praise Eclipse as a well-done crossover - actually they said «hybrid», as it’s used to call them today - between a thematic and euro game, I was doubtful: since they’re mainly eurogamers, I expected Eclipse to be your typical and boring resource-gathering cube-pusher with just a pinch more of theme than usual, still enough to have them scream how thematic the game feels.

Yet, as I was lured into playing it at last, I had to change my mind quickly: Eclipse is an excellent game in which some thematic and euro elements coexist, hence appealing to both kinds of gamers. If only, it feels like the euro side is a bit prevalent since the game’s primary focus is on the resource-gathering and managing: still, this isn’t brought too far since rarely the game prevents a player from doing what he’s got in his mind.

Looks like that with Eclipse we have found a common ground to play on. (August 2012)

[b]Update I[/b] - Looks like I was wrong: although Eclipse has some theme - surely more than its likes usually have - it’s still heavily euro in its core. As a matter of fact, the more I’ve played it over the good last year the less I’ve liked it: some of its rules simply don’t make sense and seem to only be there to grind you down as in the end all your attention is aimed at optimizing your resource management with little left for doing anything else.

I still play it (although not gladly: it’s way too long and cumbersome for the fun it gives me) but I can’t consider it worthy of a high rating anymore: thus, in January 2014 I lowered it from 8 to 6. 

[b]Update II[/b] - It’s getting worse and worse: at the moment (May 2014) what’s preventing Eclipse from getting an even lower rating than 6 is, it has starships. And I love big starships.

RATING: 9.5
One of the best board games out there.  Excellent game and really fulfills a number of desires for us. It's space opera/empire building, exploration and domination, worker placement/resource management, a little diplomacy, and (one of the most important for me) a tile laying game board. You can easily go offensive or defensive fairly well and there are a number of paths to victory.

VERY re-playable and relatively quick given everything going on.  If you like the idea of Twilight Imperium but don't like the idea of spending 12 hours playing it, I think this is a good option.

This game works fairly well with any number of players.  Two player games play out just as fun as six player games, you merely have to change your strategies up a bit in some peoples cases.

The one drawback... setup and game pieces during game play. This game is messy used strictly out of the box with everything out and ready to go. In my opinion you will almost surely want some kind of after-market storage organization option and, ideally, during game play organizational aids to help keep things easily at hand but without getting moved or knocked over during game play.

This tray is an absolute must in my opinion: http://www.boardgameinnovation.com/eclipse-tray-expanded/

If you find you like this game and want an even more extreme variation of it, check out Twilight Imperium.

RATING: 7
This game really sings. It poetically integrates civ building, tactical fighting and an economic engine. So much has been said that there is nothing really to do except engage its criticisms. Luck of the tile draw plays a role; there is no way around that. Plasma missiles are very, very strong. One has to accept that Eclipse is also a game of diplomacy, though, and that the players have to react to luck which swings a player to an early lead or to the decision of a player to pick up plasma missiles. If players don't embrace the social game, then Eclipse is a game of math -- very clever, balanced, elegant math, but with that limitation nonetheless. My group loves table-talk which is why Eclipse is a firm "ten;" it is a perfect platform for a social game while still having a sophisticated engine humming along underneath. If I had one wish it would have been for the theme and backstory to have been a little more developed and immersive, but I can't quibble with a masterpiece like this.

Update: I dropped it to a 9 just because the theme isn't quite as rich as I'd like. We talk less now about the "narrative" of the game afterward than the "sequence" of the game. It's engrossing to be sure without being captivating. That said, I'm quibbling. It has a terrific engine and produces a terrific amount of fun interaction; I doubt it will slip below this rank for me.

Update: Yeah, I was wrong I have it as a 7 now. With a game this long and with this many decision points, I just need a more immersive theme to hold it all together. I really admire the combination of mechanics, but I have to acknowledge that I will reach for other games that tell me more of a story before I will reach for Eclipse again. I'm not trading it away but it's not at the front of the library anymore.

First glance looks good and the read-through encouraging so my place holder rating is a little higher than usual for this stage. Stay tuned...
++++++
Alright, two plays in (3&4 player) and wow! The game is every bit what I had hoped and more. Firstly, I had misgivings about the playing time even with only three or four players as I have seen optimistic statements about this sort of thing proved wrong more often than not. Even with a game limit of nine turns each comprised of several rounds of player actions, this game moved briskly even after just a short introduction and all of us total novices to the game (other than what we'd gleaned on-line). As a variation on the Civ model, all of the actions were quite intuitive once the details were outlined and each action was resolved quickly. Our first game lasted just about 2 1/2 hours.

The game gets obvious comparisons to TI-III and that's fair but a closer comparison might be between this and Galactic Emperor (the two games even share the same figs). The two games play out in about the same time and both have been declared forms of TI - Lite; but, in Eclipse, there are no roles and a different mechanic determines turn order. The tech system is much more detailed, as is the combat system, and the way the universe unfolds with the worm-hole system of movement is very clever. The book-keeping system (reminiscent of Through the Ages or Age of Renaissance) is absolutely brilliant. As much as I liked Galactic Emperor, Eclipse out-points it pretty well across the board.

The only observation we had after the two games was that the supply of "outer" hexes seemed unnecessarily limited, but I suspect this was deliberate to encourage player "interaction." Our first game was with all Terran factions (as recommended), the second was with the "alien" counterparts and both were fascinating. All of us were keen to play again with mixtures of both or some kind of player draft for starting races. When extended postmortems dominate the conversation after a game ("coulda/woulda/shoulda") you know you're on to something.

Much has been written about the level of "chaos" (read luck) present in the game and I can attest to the sense of frustration at turning over hex after hex of crap. But, like Conquest of Paradise (another fair comparison), it is what it is and can be part of the charm of the game for those not offended by it. Technology development can also seem like a crap shoot, but you cheerfully hope for the best and try to make the best of what is made available to you. Combat involving dice always invites discussion but the tech system at least gives players a chance at mitigation, and the whole combat phase is tightly designed, intuitive and exciting without being either too simple or too complex. None of this puts us off and the good news is that with the relatively short playing time for a space opera epic, you won't suffer long as the victim of bad luck and there's always next time!

Bottom line is that we all agreed that this is one of the better games we have come across in some time - perhaps the best. We are not always easy to please but this game just had us begging for more!

A piece of icing on the cake came with the info that the Interactivity (FLGS here in Victoria) crowd had a hand in the design/play-testing during Touko's stay here at some point during the development. This game has no rough edges to speak of and is lovingly crafted and presented. It fully deserves to be where it is on the Geek chart and it could well end up as number one. Unfortunately (and my only criticism), the game is neither uniformly distributed nor widely available here in North America. Aside from that - well done! My first ever Ten!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Wasn't quite as wow'd as I was expecting given all the great things everyone had been saying about this.

I need to play it again, preferably with players who know the game (and don't suffer AP).

So, comments to be taken with a liberal pinch of salt, my one play could be very unrepresentative of a typical game.

Good stuff: Map, variable, simple (ish), various routes to victory, aliens to mash.

Not so good stuff: tile map without a map, so not at all obvious where tiles go if the map gets spread out and messy. Tiles you find early seem pretty crucial, get naff ones and you fall behind.

Downtime, should be minimised as it's 1 do one thing, you do 1 thing, but even with 4 I felt there was quite a bit of waiting around (5 or 6 would be worse).

Problems of 2 people piling on a 3rd, or 2 go to war and rest mop up ... but that's a problem with any muliplayer conflict game.

Combat system, didn't enjoy chucking dice much

Tech system - just felt frustrating, you can't research what isn't there, and passing early just to get the jump in first has no guarantee what you want will appear. But it works.

Need to play it with the aliens to see what difference they make.

** Update, played again, Missiles seem rather good (perhaps too good?), and with anyone suffering AP this drags in the mid/late game.

RATING: 8
This game will initially remind people of TI- they are both space empire themed games with hexes, but they play completely differently.  TI is much more epic and flavorful and themey.  Very AT.  Eclipse is basically a euro with some space battles and dice thrown in.  It combines many things: economic euro, light war, a sprinkling of AT, a sci-fi theme, dice, etc. seamlessly into tight well-oiled machine of a game.  Very cool.  Rules are pretty simple (although it will initially appear fairly complex), still, first few plays were a little long.  Combat can be a little monotonous with no decisions (except to retreat or not) and many die rolls trying to get 6's.  Initial turns and luck exploring in the first few turns can also have a pretty big impact on the game.  These are minor complaints though.  Great game overall.

RATING: 9
Es un juego de civilizaciones y desarrollo espacial. Los jugadores están a cargo de una raza. Se juegan en 9 rondas. En cada ronda hay cuatro fases. Las fases de acciones permiten explorar nuevos sistemas, mover influencia de unos a otros, investigar en nuevas tecnologías, mejorar las naves, construir o mover. Después hay una fase de mantenimiento, y otra de limpieza. La mayor parte de interacción la realizas con los vecinos. Cada acción que realices te supondrá mayores costes en la fase de mantenimiento. Cuando colonizas un planeta, vas obteniendo recursos que te permitirán hacer otras cosas. Hay tres parámetros esenciales: dinero, materiales y ciencia.

Es un juego muy bueno y muy entretenido, pero más orientado para jugones. Los no jugones se pueden saturar un poco. Es muy de calcular que puedes hacer. Tiene un puntito de azar (cuando exploras, las losetas te vienen al azar.. en los combates, hay dados), pero no es, ni con mucho, determinante.

Totalmente recomendable. Estoy deseando jugarlo de nuevo. Lo he probado a 6. Lo recomiendan al menos a 4. Es algo largo, eso sí.

RATING: 9
A wonderful game: great components, great art, strong theme and clever mechanics. For me the best 4x game. You can really play your own style...try to play aggressive and attack everyone or stay in an isolated part of the galaxy, fight the non player species and build up your empire. 
For me the best part is the fact that the bigger you get, the harder it becomes to control your empire and the less actions you can do. This is different to most 4x games where you have this runaway effect: growth makes you stronger, allows you to expand faster, which makes you even more stronger and so on. If you had a bad start, you´re often screwed. Here it´s completely different: If you´re small, you might not have that much power, but you can do many actions to grow. The bigger you get though, the more limited your actions are so you really have to find a good balance here. 
With the expansions you have amazing replayability: lots of different races, tons of tiles for your galaxy, lots of technologies, your own ship construction...just amazing!

RATING: 6
A game of economy and optimization and confrontation. There are so many little aspects to explore, which provides a lot of replay value. 

Luck plays a big role in this game: Tile drawing, dice in combat, drawing reputation tiles after combat and, maybe most importantly, grabbing the powerful technologies when they come up (plasma missiles dominate battles, monoliths open up a whole new strategy for players with a lot of materials.) There is so much luck  that it will often even out, but if you're unlucky early and fall behind you can be stuck in a long game with no chance to recover.

In the games we played so far, everybody was concentrating on themselves, and there were barely any negotiations. If the victory points would be open information or it would be by other means more clear who was leading, diplomacy could play a bigger role, with weak players ganging up on the stronger players.

After a few more games, I have found that too often a player gets punished by bad luck, especially during exploration, or getting the righ tech. The game is much more about optimization than about combat, and when you're behind there really isn't much that you can do.

One play so far, will update this rating going forward...

This game has the distinction of being my 1000th BGG game rating (dec 2011).  Before I accept my award, I'd like to thank my fans, my publicist, and most of all, God.  But enough about me.  We have a game here to rate.  So, let's get started.   

Cue music.  Black background.  Somber voice.

Peace thrived.  The galaxy was still.  Then, it turned into a flaming ball of PLASMA HELL. WAVE AFTER WAVE OF PURE MISSILE ANNIHILATION.

Then Steve realized that his ship had missiles but no gun, and it was promptly blown into a trillion pieces of space dust -- the atoms of his body ionizing and ripping through space time....

So, there you have it.  A boy's sad tale of galactic destruction.

As for the game, ask me again in the morning.  Right now I'm trying to remove the daggers from my back and the missile stains from my pants...

Note to add:  Unfortunately, plasma missiles sort of ruin the game.  Hoping that some sort of house rule can fix that.

RATING: 8
Now a number of plays in, this is a fun game. I can't complain too much about any 3-4 hour game I've played 5 times. Still, I don't know how much there really is here. It's still about getting a big economy and bashing your neighbors with it, and people who get luck with good exploration draws are in good shape, while players who draw poorly are screwed. What can you do, I guess. There is enough nuance to the game, and building the ships is fun enough, and the alien races are different enough, that I think it'll have decent (but not great) staying power. But it'll need good expansions, I expect, to stay alive - more alien races, more space hexagons, more tech and artifacts.
---
3 plays, I think I basically get the game now. It's fun. It has enough chrome and chaos to mask what it basically is (a king-of-the-hill, whack-your-neighbor game), but the chromey stuff still plays cleanly and gives the game nice texture and flavor and in the end, does successfully smooth over and mask the big underlying problems of the genre. I think there is enough here that fans of euros and fans of this genre (Titan, Dune, Britannia, etc.) who haven't had anything really good in a very long time will find something to like here. It's not anything like as good as Titan or Dune, but it is a heck of a lot shorter and maybe more playable. On the other hand, I suspect the replay value will be pretty limited barring a good expansion - I suspect a lot of the fun here is in exploring the game space.

Two balance issues: in my experience, the game is substantially better with 4 than with 6 (3 is probably fine too, while 5 might be awkward due to the asymmetry). The pacing is better with 4, and the onset of conflict is closer to the end, which is better given the lack of any real incremental scoring. With 6, space will run out and conflict will have to start by turn 4 or 5 and losers in those first battles can be screwed and stuck idling for an hour or two. Also, with 4 you are less likely to be hosed by poor tile draws.

I'm also starting to come around to the idea that missiles may need to be tamped back a bit, or a better defense added. A dreadnaught loaded with missiles and +3 computer is not very hard to build and can be pretty devastating. 
---
Been enjoying this. I expect it will play out before too long - it doesn't have a ton of range - but the experience is generally positive, which is saying a lot for this particular genre which I don't generally like (I wouldn't touch TI3 with a barge pole). Do try to keep the player count down though.
---
First impressions are really positive. Lots of good stuff, but clean-playing, with systems that interact well, and decent balance between offense and defense. Plays in a sensible amount of time (although I probably wouldn't want to play with the full compliment of 6 - 4 is probably the sweet spot for a bunch of reasons). I hold out hope that this will finally be a game to deliver on this theme.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Tentative rating based on 1 play with 5 players, without alien powers:

Our first play took much, MUCH longer than I would have liked (around 6 hours). I'm sure subsequent plays would be faster, but I can't see this trimming down to the 2 hours I'd like it to be.

As far as the gameplay goes, what you've got here is a pretty straightforward 4X game fueled by a tight, though not particularly original, Euro-style resource game. The two blend together seamlessly. Is it mechanically superior to other 4X-meets-Euro blends (e.g., Twilight Imperium, Galactic Emperor)? I'm not sure I've played any enough for my opinion to be worth anything, but from my limited perspective: not really. No worse, though, certainly. After all, the economic game IS full of near-constant tense decisions, though for my money they are sometimes mired by too many layers of complexity and bookkeeping.

Once again, my main beefs with these kinds of games are present in full force: it's too long, there's too much downtime, and it's all too easy for 1-2 players to get locked out from even being competitive early on and having to sit there through the rest of it. Sure, they COULD get eliminated, but when everyone is pretty busy ganging up on the leader until the final turn when they start jumping on those in last to score some easy points, it seems fairly unlikely.

Let's work our way backwards, shall we?

Third: Players getting locked out of the win. There's a few reasons for this, but one thing that stood out to me is the VAST difference in exploration tiles. Some rewards are much, MUCH more powerful than others and if one player happens to luck into a bunch of them (and another "lucks" into none), it gives them a pretty hefty advantage over everyone else. Perhaps not insurmountably so, but if you luck into getting powerful ships early, then clean the floor with people in combat before anyone else is ready, thus scoring all the choicest VPs for yourself...

Second: Downtime! Granted much of this for us was unfamiliarity with the game, but part of this is due to the weird blend of mechanics, presentation, and components that is the tech tiles. Because new ones pop up each turn, you pretty much always want to have them in view. But the galaxy is what really needs to be in the center of the table, so you get this weird thing where people are constantly getting up from their seats, going over to the tech board, and staring at it. Mostly we were pretty good about doing this NOT on our turns, but I still think it contributes not inconsiderably to the overall downtime. The other big downtime factor (apart from the plain-ol' AP the game so easily lends itself to) is in combat. It can be fun to watch battles that you're not participating in if they're for the greater good of the table, but more often than not it just leads to sitting around twiddling your thumbs.

First: Length. I'm not one for long games in the first place, but due to the two issues above the length feels pretty painful. The beginning and endgame are pretty exciting, but unless you're primed for the lead the entire middle can be a excruciatingly slow.

The stuff I like about the game that actually feels unique to the game - the way alliances are part of the game mechanics (even if it feels odd that you can't move through enemy territory without declaring war), the hidden vs. known victory points, and the choice between those VPs and alliances, all feel kind of moot when compared with the above.

I'm certainly not against playing again now that we've got a full game under our belts, and have the alien powers left to try, but I can't say I'm exactly chomping at the bit to do so.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is one of the better games out there! Normally I don't like ameritrash, but this mix of ameritrash and eurogame is quite successful I think.

I'm not really sure what it is that makes me feel this way, but in general I seem to enjoy civilization games, and I'm a sucker for tech trees! It's also refreshing (for me as a eurogamer at least) to have some combat, and the negotiation, though not a huge part of the game, is nice.

However, there are a few downsides which has to do with the amount of luck involved in this game... People who know my tastes in board games know I despise luck if it directly causes a winner, especially if it's in longer games like this one.

There is luck involved in the exploring - sure, you can discard your tile, but I don't really think that is a good idea, and it will still cost you a turn and is therefore inefficient. Luck is involved in the dice combats - you can win if you keep rolling high numbers and your enemies low (though it's mitigated by computers/shields, but still). Also, to a lesser extent, there is randomness in which tech tiles become available each round - you can have a strategy and hexes that "need" specific techs, but they might never show up. Finally, there is luck involved in the reputation tiles you draw - they can cause huge point swings.

There are a few other aspects as well such as the ancient technologies, but those 3 can actually cause you to win a game even though you, objectively, haven't been the best player and vice versa... Especially the reputation tiles! I won a game with 2 points once, only because I got lucky in the last round and pulled some much higher reputation tiles than the person who finished 2nd!

Nevertheless, this is a great game because it, to me, comes close to what I would describe as an "epic space game". Sure, TI3 might be more epic, but Eclipse "only" takes ~3 hours with 4 players, which I think is reasonable.

The components and graphics are great. The rules aren't that difficult to understand as you can only do 6 quite basic actions - but the decisions about which action to take and when is what makes this game so great. Lots of tough and interesting decisions, and I feel they offset the shortcomings.

However... Having played this game more than 10 times now, I feel that the game is perhaps a little too little focused on the combat; it often happens that there are only serious combats during the last two rounds, although earlier battles of course do happen too. This saddens me a little as, though I'm a hardcore eurogamer, would like just a little more focus on the combat system and actual fighting than the economic system. Also, the randomness of especially the hexes, the tech tiles and the VP tiles is starting to get a little more annoying.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Eclipse is definitely among my favourite board games.  It describes itself as an "epic board game of interstellar conflict" -- and that's not far off!

Each player assumes the role of a galactic superpower.  Each race has its own distinct advantages and disadvantages*.  Each player starts on a single hex tile.  Exploration involves flipping over a tile from the stack and placing it on the table, literally building the galaxy as you go.  As players explore they can come into contact with their neighbours, where conflict or diplomacy can result.

The game uses cubes on numbered squares to track population and resource production; each player's reference card has a track for the three resources: money, science, and materials.  As you populate systems you take cubes off of your production tracks (revealing higher numbers) and place them on the board.  This delightfully simple mechanic works beautifully at indicating who owns what while simultaneously making it impossible to forget to update a resource production counter.

Throughout the game players can make scientific discoveries to give them lasting special abilities or allow them to buy upgraded parts for their ships.  Ships' weapons, armour/shields, power generators, and engines can all be upgraded.  Players can choose to make their ships nimble glass cannons, or can load them down with armour and shields to defeat their opponents through sheer attrition.

The game can take a long time, especially with novice players.  They estimate 30 minutes per player, which seems slightly short to me.  But we tend to have a very relaxed, social gaming atmosphere.

______________
* The game also supports all players being human, making the first few games easier since everyone will have the same special abilities.

RATING: 8.5

So you need to react by having the ability to travel to their region and take over tiles.  Watch where you place those wormholes, or get the wormhole technology early so you have flexibility. Update: Not good for 2 except as a learning game because imbalances from luck in tile draws and die rolls result in runaway leader problems without the help of other players for checks and balances.
