RATING: 6.5
Walking by and looking at this game, it looks extremely daunting and complicated, and the setup is an effort in itself.  Suprisingly, the rules are quite straightforward and the game plays remarkably well.  You need to manage your three resources (money, science, and materials) and explore the universe in search of more resources, points, and battles with others.  Two things that stood out to me on the first play were 1) outfitting the ships is a good time and 2) getting points for being in a battle (even if you lose) is a neat twist.  **Want to play again.

--Update on second play:  I have some pretty major gripes now with the game.  1) There is no mechanism to force you into other people's space.  With no contention or possibility of fighting, the game is boring to the end.  There should be something pushing everyone to explore into the middle instead of just turtling the Sector IIIs.  2) I have the feeling the game is decided on the random factors - a) what sectors you get when exploring, b) what techs are pulled when your are start player, c) what discovery tiles you get and to a lesser extent d) the point tiles (mitigated by winning).  Too much random and not enough good play to determine the winner.  3) The best part of the game is the ship blueprints, but by the time you get a power source, some extra firepower, and the ability to move the game is in the last turns.  Ramp up time is a downer with little payoff.

RATING: 10


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[b]Also includes Eclipse: Ship Pack One[/b]

Eclipse is my go-to option for an epic-feeling conquest game that still fits in a reasonable playing time. It's certainly a hybrid design, with "Euro" efficiency and VP scoring but plenty of Ameritrashy direct conflict and space combat dice chucking. 

All the "civ building" elements are there, with exploring, exterminating, tech trees, and resource management. The ability to customize your ships by dropping any number of technology tiles onto a ship blueprint is super-cool. The different alien races nudge players in different directions toward victory without being too heavy-handed or constricting.

I can't say enough about how the game is packaged together. The rulebook is incredibly clear, the iconography is shockingly consistent and intuitive... a lot of care went into making the game as approachable as possible.

Why is it not a 10? I suppose because, at times, the back and forth dice chucking in combat feels a bit tedious and random, and the plastic ships could have been better. I suppose though, that if you buy and tech up to those red-dice cannons, you want to use them!

RATING: 3
Many love Eclipse and for good reason as I definitely see the game has a lot to offer for players. However, I have a couple main problems with it.

Tile Laying: I love the idea of tile laying, but getting pinned in by aliens early on or being forced to throw out a tile can really hurt your economy at the start and can basically lead to you being eliminated early especially if a player doesn't form an alliance with you to help you out.

Victory Point Chit-Pull: Winning a battle is great but only gaining 1-4 victory points and that was completely random. Yes it could be mitigated by getting more pulls, but I had one combat with 4 pulls and pulled 4 1s.

Dice Rolling for Combat: While there is too much combat for my liking, the dice to resolve everything felt like it was a mechanic thrown in just to be there and didn't add anything to the game. Often times we knew the results even before we started, and in my opinion that's not where dice should be used in games.

While I may consider playing it again, I'd likely opt to play something else or tackle a game solo, which is never a good sign for a game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
UPDATE 8/17. Y'know what? Eclipse gets a 7. Eclipse is, in my opinion, as good a civ-building game as Through The Ages is, and in many ways better.

There's problems, no doubt -- I'm still not sold on the idea that Plasma Missiles aren't problematic from a design perspective, though they're not irretrievably broken, and I still have a bug up my ass about the turn order thing -- but Eclipse is a worthy game, if ludicrously overproduced.

(My pet hypothesis: you could fix the plasma missile thing if you find them annoyingly destabilizing by fishing the plasma missile tech tiles out of the bag the turn after the first player buys them and make them all available in addition to the normal tech draws. First player to buy them gets one turn to go on a spree if they're so inclined, and other players can either reach for plasma missiles as a balance-of-terror countermeasure OR concentrate on effective counters if the first player goes heavy into building unbalanced "missile boat" designs.

---

So I bought the iOS version, figuring a game this beloved must be worth a second shot.

I am a bit moved, enough so to bump this from an indifferent 5 to a mildly enthused 6. I like the ship-building -- quite a lot, actually. Research is cool but hampered by forces beyond my control. I loathe the clockwise-from-the-first-to-pass turn order; when combined with the random draw of technologies this can be almost game-breaking through (almost) no fault of my own. (This would be less of an issue if there weren't technologies that seem to be decisively better than others.) Determining next turn's play order by the order of passing seems like an obviously better solution. Buckets of dice for combat is fine in theory but overlong in practice; there are sound mechanical reasons for wanting combat to be an all-or-nothing proposition but one wonders if something more like, say, Here I Stand's one-round combats might reduce the downtime.

My take: a solid game whose rep has been juiced up beyond belief by being just enough Euro mechanics for the Eurogamers, just enough direct conflict and randomness for the AT crowd, and being in a category of games so dominated by dreck that a halfway decent game playable in a reasonable duration seems like the Second Coming by comparison. For me, it's as much fun as I can reasonably expect playing a 4X game. I would absolutely play again, I would not dream of buying it at anywhere close to MSRP, and I feel like 7 bones for the first-rate iOS version was money well spent.

RATING: 5
pros

the coolest player mats i've ever seen. ship design has incredible variety and is great fun. the game components are very well done; the game has fantastic theme and will feel very different play to play.

cons

the game length is long. on the one hand you need this to feel like you have enough time to execute on your strategy on the other this is a big investment of time.

victory is heavily influence by table politics and who is sitting next to whom. if you want to win in this game and you strategically place yourself between two players who don't enjoy war mongering, you are at a huge advantage.

a bit too much randomness in terms of which technologies come out of the bag - a lot of strategies hinge on a handful of techs that may show up early, may show up often, may never show up, etc.

too much downtime - even taking one action at a time can lead to a lot of waiting around in 5+ person games.

RATING: 9
Definitely worth it !

Eclipse is one of those rare large game that have good complexity, complex strategies and that keeps all players involved from the beginning to the end of a game.Even if average game takes 2-3 hours depending on number of players, I've seen very few dead time during our games. The only thing that is taking some times is the set-up, try to have ready bags with starting package for all players and its gonna save you a lot of problems.

One very good aspect of this game is its replay value, with an interactive galaxy that can change from game to game, different ways to achieve victory points (exploration, military invasions, building monoliths, maxing out tech, diplomacy) and different alien races you can play many game without using the same pattern. Some players dont like the randomness of technology tiles but in my opinion it gives different flavors to different games. Some techs will be harder to find and when they come out players will tend to rush toward it or try to save for them, it also forces you to always rethink your strategy. 

The more I play this game the more I like it, and i'll surely grab the expansion soon enough.

conclusion:
+
Well designed
Lots of customisation and strategies available
Super replay value
Lots of fun
-
Takes some time to set-up
You need a large table for this game

RATING: 7
I was very sceptical since I saw the prototype few years ago at Essen fair. I'm happy to see that the game has been evolved since then.
I like some aspects of the game very much: customizable ships are great, the way how your actions depend of that how much money you have, etc.
But as much I'd like to love the game, I can't because of the uncontrollable randomness. I think it's not fair way to give out victory points based on random tile draws. Also it's disturbing that all the hexes aren't connected with each other, which means that it's too easy to avoid contact with your opponents.
I think that after some rules tweaking, Eclipse might be pretty good space exploration game, but it would never match with Twilight Imperium, which is and will be my favorite.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great, epic game with a real feeling of tension.  Eclipse is one of those games where you find that there are moments when everyone is standing around the table instead of sitting.

I'm not sure how fair it is to describe this as a "4X" game.  Though it certainly fits all the criteria of the genre, it also captures everything I love about Space Opera.  It's by no means a short game, but it feels like a romp -- like an adventure.  

The unique traits of the different alien races (present in the base game and made even better with the expansion) allow civilizations to develop unique personalities as the game progresses.  Everything, of course, is shaped and guided by player choices and experiences, so even two human factions can end up looking, thinking, and behaving very differently by the end of the game.

There are downsides, however.  It can eat up your night, and is particularly susceptible to analysis paralysis since it punishes carelessness pretty severely.  It also has a fairly high barrier to entry for new players.  

Finally, the use of standard d6 rolls to resolve combat gives combat outcomes a high degree of randomness -- a bit too much randomness for my taste.  I absolutely think deterministic combat would be a mistake here, but the combat would benefit from tightening the probabilities a little.

All-in-all, though, Eclipse is an amazing game for creating great, compelling stories that will stick in your memory long after the game is done.

RATING: 7
Played this the first time on Monday nights at Mindgames Canberra (thanks to Richard and Basil for taking the time to teach this game). My first impression was that it was quite long and I didn't enjoy the amount of dice rolling involved. I played again another Monday night and enjoyed my second play much more (even though we discovered at the end we weren't playing with all the tiles in play much to Richard's disappointment). This is a game I could really enjoy after a few more plays (I think I am more across the various shield/weapons/power configurations now which is an important element of the game).

Played a fourth time and this game is really growing on me. I have been trying to figure out what appeals to me so much about this game. I think it is because there are strong elements of micro strategy and macro strategy involved which interestingly is lacking in many other board games - I have to admit however I haven't tried many war games which I expect would have these traits. Time to upgrade its rating. 

8/11/2012 - Time to upgrade its rating again (after my fifth play). I really love this game.

Update: Ugh. Rating falling fast. On life support. This is way too much pulling the slot wheel for me. Lucky rolls on the dice in combat are not even close to the main aspects of luck. And annoyingly very little to do about it. The exploration draws are just really painful how swingy they are. You might get what you want, you might not. You might have to fight aliens there before colonizing, you might not, you might get a random discovery bonus, you might not. The discovery bonuses also vary wildly in usefulness, especially depending on what you may already have. I hate to just give up on the game, so I think we're going to start experimenting with various house rules. But we're talking major revisions, not minor tweaks. This needs a lot of work to be worth repeat plays.

3 games in. More comments later. Major concerns about luck of both combat and exploration.

RATING: 9
This is an amazing game - scratches the TI3 itch while dropping the cumbersome wall-of-text rules (with accompanying exceptions/special cases), distilling the essence of space empire-building into a simple, approachable, and extremely fun experience. Things I like:

* The game literally plays in ~40 minutes per player while not feeling short/rushed
* There are a variety of valid strategies ranging from econ-focused to military-focused, and we've seen many different approaches win
* The iconography is very clear and the rules are very simple, making rulebook checks infrequent
* The population and influence mechanisms are brilliant, seamlessly handling upkeep, resource production, and action limitations without being fiddly

In short, this is an outstanding game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A good game, filled with a great theme and cool mechanics! Sadly (even with an expansion) the developers have not fixed the endgame... 

With a fixed number of rounds (8) Eclipse suffers from a "build up phase" - usually the first 5~6 rounds and then a combat phase - usually rounds 6~8. Seeing as round 8 is the last one, people dont care at all about the economy ect...

As stated earlier the developers could easily have fixed this in the expansion, but sadly didnt...

A simple "first to 100 VP", a variable number of turns (say 6-9) would also stop the late game abuse...

RATING: 7
Nothing has yet come close to taking Eclipse's spot as our 4X, Empire building, negotiation, conflict game.  There's lots to manage, lots to develop, lots of strategies to adopt and lots of decision to make, and that's just counting the game mechanisms.  The real game is in negotiation and table talk.  Normally I don't like that sort of game, but I think I like it more in Eclipse because it also lets me build an empire.

Sometimes I'll go out and be aggressive (and, unfortunately, I'll be too eager and go out before I'm ready, getting stomped for the rest of the game), other times I'll turtle up and build a science empire.  I like that flexibility.  I like how peoples' personalities can come out in the races that they play.

It doesn't get played a lot, due to the time and player requirement, but it does what it does very well, so it stays in the collection.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This game nails it on so many levels. Exploring, especially with expansion content, is exciting. Discoveries are frequently very cool. Available techs and their staggered arrival make for very interesting tactical decisions. Combat is dice-chucking at its best. The various races are significantly different, engender very different strategies, and yet for the most part feel balanced. The game is visually beautiful with a symbology that, while daunting at first, really does become intuitive. And ship design, oh my god, ship design--it's a perfect challenge. There are very few 4X games (or games, period) where so many diverse systems are woven together so seamlessly and make for a gaming experience whose every decision feels interesting and meaningful.

There are some problems that can't be overlooked, however. The largest of which is that poor luck during one's first few explorations can severely limit your options and possibility for success down the line and the ways a player can mitigate that poor luck (discarding poor hexes or pushing inward) aren't effective enough. My other complaints are much more minor. The game runs a little too long for many situations; even with four experienced players, you're likely to hit three and a half hours, which can be prohibitive, though I'm not sure a game like this can (or should) be any shorter. And, finally, it is a monster of a game to teach. Again, this really just comes with the territory; but it is worth considering.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Really liking this game.  Relatively simple rules, simple end-of-turn accounting, and a VP-scoring system that disfavors turtle-ing.

Non-negligible randomness is definitely built into the game's design.  But I only care if randomness makes the game less fun, and here it does not appear to. 

UPDATE: Plasma Missiles are OP. It's a shame because the rest of the game is awesome.  Need to find a house rule to remedy the situation.

RATING: 6
Finally played this thing.
Not a bad game, but it definitely was way overhyped. The hype and the bgg ranking made me expect a great game and it's definitely not as good as it's made out to be.

It's the first time BGG's rankings fail me. This, imo, should be in the top 250-300. Still a good game, but not great.

Reason: too much luck. You can be planet-screwed, tech-screwed, etc. To points where it's impossible to win whatever you do. I love a little luck in games, but not too much in a 4X game. Also: horrible components. Ships much too big for the hexes and artwork and presentation is meh. Have difficulty finding where techs go on the board because of not enough art variations between tiles.

For a similar game (civ/euro) i'd rather play Through the Ages...

I'd still play it though. Not great game, but definitely a good one.

RATING: 10
Eclipse is very nearly the perfect game as far as I am concerned. It has just the right amount of luck and depth combined with extremely intuitive rules. It also supports a variety of player counts (all of them well too) and plays in a reasonable time. The components are very high quality and the game looks pleasing on the table. Based on my plays, all worries about plasma missiles, bankruptcy and exploration draws have been proven wrong. I strongly believe that while there is some luck in Eclipse there are also enough ways to mitigate the effects. Bankruptcy is a viable tactic that can be used but is usually not worth it. Plasma missiles require different tactics to be used against but are by no means a huge game changer.

RATING: 8.5
This game is to Master of Orion, what TTA is to Civ. Although Eclipse is much more in the Ameritrash school of play, it has very elegant rule set.

That and the short playtime for its nature (4X) makes it a pretty remarkable game.  But it is still Ameritrash “King of the Hill” done up in space. Huge luck (in terms of alien space tech, and dice rolling)… but fun.   In the light of the next day (after a second play), it is not a game that I am totally clamoring to get to the table again and again and again. [The definition of a 9 or higher for longer games]. It is just below that threshold – an 8.5.  This is the game I would have played to death back when I was a teenager.

I will happily play it if suggested though. Quite remarkable really.

Reminder to look for Ipad version, when it comes out.

RATING: 8.5
Things I like:  This is the space combat/exploration game I've been waiting for since I got into boardgames. It has great production value, tons of plastic ships, loads of cool dice, interesting races with unique special powers, interesting technological upgrades, etc.

Things I don't like:  I hate losing really hard when the dice refuse to resolve in my favor.  Yes, there are plenty of strategies to mitigate this, but damn if I don't get my arse kicked time and again.

Also, the luck in what technologies come up can be brutal in a 2 player game; if 1 player is fortunate enough to get a good weapon upgrade and then another isn't drawn for many rounds, the player left with the pea-shooters is pretty much damned.

Also, the player boards and the tech board are too thin, and the corners curled up before playing even 1 game.  Plus, the art on the hex tiles seems to be peeling off quite a few of them.  A little disappointing for $100, though the rest of the components are really top notch.

Despite my complaints, I really like this game, and I think it will be even better when I get a chance to play with more than 2 players.

RATING: 8
Initial impression/rating: If this had been my first exposure to this kind of game, I might have rated it higher than an 8, but after having already played Through the Ages, I didn't get that rush from being exposed to something new (at least in terms of mechanics). I'm told this game fires Twilight Imperium as well, both thematically and 4X-wise. I've never played TI, and apparently now I don't need to.

However, I've yet to even try the other races beyond the initial humans, so I hope Eclipse's rating will go up with more plays and I look forward to what the expansion has to offer.

Update: More games played offer mixed reactions. The play doesn't get old because games can be so radically different each time, dependent upon what tech becomes available and when, what did you get when exploring tiles, who are your neighbors, etc. So that's a huge plus. But I had found my first few games a bit dis-jarring having to shift mental gears from playing a cube-pushing Euro for my first seven turns to suddenly finding myself in the middle of an Ameritrash dicefest for the last two. And the game really should be played among players with similar Eclipse-experience because it's too easy for someone to get out front and stay there unless people recognize that it's in their best interest to stop them sooner rather than later. It can be a pretty negative experience for a novice player going up against Plasma Missiles (PMs) in a non-Rise of the Ancients expanded game without a proper understanding of just how devastating PMs can be. Only experience can teach them they needed PMs as well (assuming they were available), or shields and improved hulls to hopefully survive a PM assault, or to have gotten started immediately on a pinning strategy by building a massive fleet of cheap interceptors, all in the hopes of taking away resources from the PM equipped player before they became too powerful. This is all theoretical, of course, as I've yet to even win a game, so what do I know? Apparently not much -- easier said than done I guess.

Yet despite the bitter taste left from each loss, I find I still want to play. It might be strictly nothing more than the desire to solve the game before being done with it, but I suspect that's not the case.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Eclipse is a very mixed bag.

On the one hand, the player boards give an incredible amount of interesting options... four different types of highly customizable ships, three different technology tracks and three different currencies. The price-based action disc mechanic is simply outstanding--deciding whether to take one more action, hoping you don't come up short on money at the end of the round is a tense decision-making experience. The actions themselves are also well-designed and the ability to take some weaker actions even after you have passed is just very well done.

But on the other hand, there's a huge amount of luck in the game. (If you choose to pursue a combat strategy, or if combat gets forced on you by aggressors, it's frequently going to come down to good/bad dice rolls. Combat often involves several rounds of Risk-like back-and-forth dice rolling.) Don't misunderstand me, though. Having everyone "play nice" would ruin a game like this, no question.

There's also a huge amount of luck in what you discover in your early turn explorations. Some players will get a few resources, others will get highly powerful alien ship upgrades which endure all game. Some sectors will be rich in resources while others have nothing at all. Two or three poor explorations early on will put you at a decided disadvantage.

Lastly, the reputation points you draw can be horribly variable. Some players will be drawing 3s and 4s while you draw nothing but 1s. At the end of the game, you'll have 4 points in reputation and they'll have 10 or more. (And this is not a very high-scoring game... about 30 points for a winning score.)

So, I'm conflicted. The parts of the game which are good are very good or outright excellent. But there are parts of the game which really make it seem like "Super Risk in Space". If the game was much, much shorter, the luck factor would be fine... but this is a long game with a lot of very serious strategic decisions to make.

I love it. I hate it.

EDIT: Repeated plays, including trying several of the variants suggested in the forum for reducing randomness, have not changed my opinion. If anything, I'm more frustrated by the randomness. I really wish I just disliked the whole game, but there are parts of it worthy of a '10'.

A final observation based on more plays... There's a significant "rich get richer" aspect to the game... which can occasionally lead to player elimination (or, more often, virtual player elimination where a player occupies only a hex or two... no production, no influence).

*sigh* For my tastes, the game is just fundamentally flawed. I wish, really wish, it wasn't.

RATING: 3
I can see the appeal of this game, especially to eurogamers, due to the action selection mechanics and scoring mechanism. The ship upgrades and combat are both interesting and easy, and the different colored dice are a nice, simple way of working with weapons upgrades. Everything just seems to fit together well.

Alas, all is not entirely well. I think the early exploration tiles can have a significant long term effect. Getting too many pirates early and consistently can put you a turn behind at least, and I'm not sure the rewards for killing pirates are really enough to make up the difference. Special weapons and shields are nice, but players need money most of all. The timing of the tech tiles and the luck of the draw on the VP chips could be game breaking as well. The ability to turtle by intentionally not connecting various warp points could definitely be an issue, too.

On top of that, there's definitely a rich-get-richer feeling to the whole thing and if you get picked on early there's really no coming back. In one game I played the guy who won did so handily, with myself coming in a solid but distant second. The other three players weren't even close.

One could argue that the other players didn't respond properly to the main threat on the board, but that's an issue inherent to games like this. In action selection games players tend to avoid investing in actions merely for the sake of confronting other players, especially if it doesn't coincide with whatever approach they've already invested in. The fact that eurogamers tend to be conflict-averse can exacerbate the problem, too.  This can be even more of an issue if you're playing with races like the Planta. You must connect to them early and attack or they're simply going to run away with the game.

Despite these problems I can see why the game is popular. It's clear the gaming community was looking for a lighter version of Twilight Imperium III with familiar mechanics and, for many, they've found it. As for myself, I think the game is good but not great. At least it's shorter.

UPDATE: More plays, rating continues to drop. Early exploration tiles can prove way too significant, and losing an early battle I should have won pretty much knocked me out of one game. Combined with lucky VP tile draws by the winner that game wasn't even close. In another I got cut off by my neighbors and couldn't really even get into combat, and the tech tiles came out in a goofy order. Sorry folks, but this is a game I will now actively refuse to play.

TL;DR - random exploration + random vp + random tech == random winner.

UPDATE2: I went and bought the steam app, thinking it might be ok against AI opponents and I could get better at it. The result was that my rating has dropped even farther as it only served to solidify my original complaints about the game. Way too much randomness that effectively determines the winner more than your actions. Oh, and missiles. Dear god, the missiles.

RATING: 10
Upped my rating to a 10 after a couple more plays. This is a fabulous game and everyone I've played it with, including people completely unware of the hype online, have loved it.
Classic 4X action with an elegantly implemented technology and ship development mechanism. This is all bundled into a tight time allocation. Players need to get the most out of thier limited number of actions through the game, but unlike other games which may have a hard limit to the number of actions, Eclipse allows players to take more, but wear the escalating costs to do so.
There are multiple paths to acrue victory points and the early explore actions will often force a player down a particular path. But this is the beauty of the game. Rather than being able to continually finesse the one strategy, a good player needs to be able to identify the main chance and skillfully implement it.
The evidence that this is a game of skill is there as player scores increase significantly with each play.
Definitely my hot, "I love it" game of the moment.

RATING: 6
[2012-06-09 Rating: 8 -> 6]
After playing Ecplipse some more, I feel the need to adjust my rating. As it turns out, my excitement for this game has dropped a little. While I do still think it's one of the finest 4X games that I have played until now, I also noticed that it is not really my type of game. It my be due to group think, but most of the game I participated in had far too much direct conflict for my liking. As a result of this, my rating drops from 8 to 6. Don't get me wrong: I still think this is a very good game if you like this kind of games and don't mind direct conflict in a multiplayer environment, it's just not for me. I do enjoy some direct conflict, but more or less only in a two player setting. Played with only two players, Eclipse still gets an 8.

[2011-12-22 Rating: n.a. -> 8]

The 8 rating was made after my first play which was with two players. So the rating might go up or down with further plays. Now on to the comment:
I was a little unsure whether I wanted to try Eclipse or not. Lately, I realized that I'm not a huge friend of games with direct conflict since often times the winner is the one who manages to stay under radar the best and therefore get's attacked the less. 
But Eclipse turns out to be another beast. It is more reminiscent of games like "Through the Ages" in that it is mostly a resource management game. You win the game by securing the most victory  points (VP). You get them for researching a lot of technologies in one branch, for building and keeping a special building, by possessing star systems or, but only to a minor degree and with uncertain outcome, by participating in battles. In order to get there, you do have to manage your resources in the best way possible. Since the game lasts only nine rounds, you should better make sure that you don't waste any of them.
The game itself is very streamlined and thanks to the turn structure, there isn't a lot of downtime betweens your turns. I guess, it's more euro than ameritrash in this regard.
The player boards are ingenious. There is no need to count your systems every turn or look at a myriad of cards to figure out which technologies power your ships. Everything is front of you.
To sum it up, I haven't had this much fun playing a civilization type game in a long time and I'm looking forward to my next play.

RATING: 6
Eclipse is a space exploration, tech tree growth, improve your space ships, and battle with other players game.  The core mechanics are very tight and clean, but there are so many things to research, that my first game experience was very muddled and over-whelming.  To add to the confusion, none of the icons made intuitive sense to me, so looking at the research options would nearly give me an epileptic seizure (seriously). 

By my second play, I noticed that the exploration tile flips of the first couple of rounds creates a huge swing in a players position.  Several people in my second game (6-player game) were essentially eliminated from play by the second round.  I consider this to be a pretty big design flaw.

My rating of Agricola is similar, but I like the game play of Agricola better.  They both have a clean set of core mechanics that are extremely captivating, but they have an added layer of card text options that muddle the experience for me.  

Only play Eclipse if you are planning to play it several times within the month.  If not, there are many other more enjoyable game out there.

RATING: 6
An 8.5. rating after our initial 4 player game (July 7, 2012).

I usually try and limit my initial rating to 8 for a game, as I have been fooled by the replay value of many, but in this case, I have decided to start at 8.5 as my expectation is that the rating will rise!

After all the hype, I expected to see a few flaws and be somewhat disappointed (as I was with Mage Knight - a good game but not my type) but Eclipse lived up to the hype. It is a clean and elegant design - uncluttered with meaningless detail either in process or specifics - tough decisions and I can see a 3-4 player game easily coming in under 2 hours with experienced players. Once you know the Techs and the tiles (and eventually the Alien powers) game play will speed up!

Everyone learned a lot in their first play and wanted to play again soon to apply what they had learned! A sign of a very good game IMHO.

EDIT: August 9th, 2012 - rating increased to 9 after another half dozen face-to-face plays with 3-6 people. Excellent game with lots of replayability - lots to think about.

EDIT: August 15th, 2012 - another week and another 3 games of Eclipse. This game is now a 10. Why? There hasn't been a game in recent memory that our Saturday and Wednesday groups have played consecutively for weeks on end like Eclipse. It's just so darned addictive. Highly recommended.

Edit: October 2012: Rating lowered to 9. This is a great game, however, it is a bit long and we have had several 5-6 player games where some players felt out of contention in the first half of the game and had to endure or play spoiler for the last half. Also we have had some kingmaker games which were unsatisfying. Still well worth playing and owning - wish it was a tad shorter though!

Final Edit: Reducing the overall rating to 8. It's a 10 when you're learning it - a 9 when you have 4 fast-playing experienced players and an 8 once you see that it has the same endgame and bash-the-leader issues as most other confrontation games. Still, everyone should play it a few times!

RATING: 4
Rating after a single, 6er game, with all human races.

The good:  For those fans of Twilight Imperium, you will love this game.  This is Twilight Imperium but with shorter playtime, and better chrome.  In fact, this game should ultimately obsolete TI.  Can't think of a reason to play TI over this.

The bad: This game has the typical flaws of a multiplayer battle-game.  You cannot afford to attack because the associated cost will cripple you with respect to the other players.  Exactly like TI, this results in a turtle-fest where big fleets are stacked and stare at one another.  Whoever attacks first loses.  Until the last turn..when the attacking opens up for points as players try to get an attack in that can't be countered due to the game ending.  Exactly like  Wallenstein, exactly like TI.  Man, I was hoping for so much more from this one, but it falls into the same traps.
That said, the chrome on this game is amazing.  The techs, the upgrades to ships, the 3 different tracks of production.  However, this is all just window dressing.  Your economic engine that affords you this chrome is heavily reliant on exploration tile draws.  Draw well, and your options open up. Draw poorly..say no tech planets, and you'll find your endgame at the mercy of other players.
And that brings me to the most negative thing about this game. If you find yourself behind the tech curve...as mentioned above, you can't upgrade.  If you are behind the money curve as well, you can't do any actions at all!  You just have to wait out the game and hope that brinkmanship from the other players will result in no one attacking you.  And while the game is shorter than TI, having no meaningful decisions to make is no way to spend half of the game (6 hours full --> 3 hours half).

Bring a book...in case this happens to you.

RATING: 6
Players run and expand a space empire, earning victory points for expansion, exploration and conquest.  Large... very large... game where players take turns taking an action to expand, build, research, move, upgrade their way across a hex map, expanding game board.  Expansion and conquest leads to colonization, which grows economy, which allows further expansion, research and growth.  Players earn victory points for taking over tiles, getting into fights, building and researching stuff, and so on.  Eclipse tries, and does, get a lot of things right.  Simple, elegant Euro based mechanics; a nice combat system; tech tree; tuning ships, and so on.  However, it's big, really really big, and it does take a long time to play.  The game also seems rather fragile, with several random elements (the exploration, the order the technologies appear, etc).  Games of this size and length are not my thing, hence the rating, but it's easy to see why others are adoring it.  I think this game will be a LOT better with four or fewer, as the playtime will reduce and action increase.  It also feels the sort of game with a fast half life ... a few plays will see it done, whereas I'll be playing Mage Knight The Boardgame for years and still discovering stuff.  Still, very good for it's target audience.

RATING: 10
This game is harder to find time to play than much of my collection, yet I've managed to play it quite a few times. This is one of those rare games where I appreciate just about everything in the game. Many other games just have that one or 2 things that bother you, whether it's the graphic design or one of the game mechanisms. Eclipse seems to get it just right on all fronts. It's clear a lot of love, time, and effort was put into the design, playtesting, and production. One of the things I appreciate the most is how intuitive the mechanics are. The rules are quite streamlined, and it is very easy to teach. And ship customization is really fun.

The only (very minor) downsides:
- It seems better with more players, but the play length can push the limits a bit. With the wrong set of gamers (AP or just chatty), a game with 4-6 players can get dragged out a bit. The estimated game time of 30/player assumes fast and focused play from all.
- I don't think Plasma Missiles are unfairly powerful like some others do, but I do think that with multiple plasma missiles in a ship build, the number of dice you end up throwing gets a bit ridiculous. I don't think it's overpowered, but it just seems a bit silly in comparison to the maturity of the rest of the design. I sometimes wonder if it would have been better to give them an energy cost of 1. But on the other hand this may have reduced some of the exciting moments of the game.

I'm really looking forward to seeing what they add in with the expansion.

RATING: N/A
2nd edition!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Eclipse is the Euro-ized 4x game.  I really appreciate the way everything's been streamlined, and how the game's mechanisms fit together seamlessly.  It's an impressive design for this reason.  

Ironically, though, this design is actually a lot more luck-driven in some ways than other similar games.  This stems from 2 factors.  
One, exploring the galaxy, while fun, leaves you vulnerable to bad draws.  What's forgivable in a short game isn't in one that takes 3 hours, and getting stuck without any decent planets is tough to overcome.  Even if you do get good systems, they may be occupied by neutral aliens.  This means that in order to get ahold of them, you have to build up at least a small fleet and send them in to clean out the inhabitants.  This can be action- and resource- costly, potentially putting you well behind players who get undefended systems.  
And even if you manage to get/clear off decent planets, the 3 types of resources in the game mean that you have a fair chance of being short in a critical area.  Expanding into a ton of systems with just pink (sci) and brown (prod) planets won't do you much good, since you'll have so many disks on the board and have so little money, you'll be unable to do anything.  (This is actually the 2nd best situation in some respects, because you can research the orbitals tech if it's out, then convert your excess production into new economy planets, solving your problem eventually.)  Being short on science is probably the most survivable of the 3 shortages, since you can save up and go the orbital route as above, or just deal with being behind in the tech race.  Having insufficient production, though, is the worst of the 3.  You can't build habitats to patch the problem, so the best you can do is try and get advanced mining (if it's out, and if that'll even help you).  Having a bunch of money and science means you can explore more (until the galaxy runs out) and research things and upgrade your ships a bunch, but without production you won't be able to build very many of them.  Plus, you can forget about building monoliths in the late game.
You can, of course, mitigate this by rejecting systems you don't want. This soaks up actions, though, and you usually don't have many to spare at the beginning.  The rules-as-written mean that rejecting things in the 1& 2 stacks will send them out of the game, but rejecting a 3 means that the person who explores the last 3 will get stuck with it, and know exactly what it is.

The second factor is the combat.  Since you're looking for 6s, ships can fire back and forth for a while and score hits only occasionally.  Obviously, computers help this a lot and are quite strong, but without them combats are highly luck-driven.  It comes down to who rolls above average and gets a lot of 6s early.  You could also get the reverse problem and roll buckets of dice while whiffing every time.  I've seen a player take on the GCDS and roll 40+ dice, scoring only 3-4 hits while it slowly took apart his fleet.  Naturally, he was quite unhappy.

I have a few other concerns about turtling being too strong.  Even though you're encouraged by point rewards to get into fights, you really have to have a huge econ base to try and invade & conquer someone else's territory, even on the last turn of the game.  Most of this comes down to military being way too action-costly on offense, and almost free on defense.  It takes so many action disks to move your fleets, and still more to claim any territory you get, that you can wind up bankrupting yourself.  To even get into position to attack, you've got to spend a bunch of time upgrading your fleets, and still more time building them.  The defender just has to do the upgrades, marshaling their resources until you make your move, then building a fleet where you send yours.  Of course, if you're attacking the leader, it may still be worth doing just to deny them points.  
Plus, military is made more difficult by the extreme piece-limit caps on ship classes.  Further, some of the races really encourage a defensive style.  In fact, most of the games I've played have been decided in favor of the player who turtles and build monoliths all over the place (usually me).

Despite these issues, I still like the game a lot.  If you're playing with people who know that they're doing and can plan during others' turns, it can move along at a fair clip.  The art looks good and is very functional.  Having the same budget spaceship minis as other games is a bit of a downer, but you can get the expansion to patch that if you really care.  Perhaps the game's best feature is designing your own ships tile by tile.  No other game I've seen has done this (with the possible exception of the new Xia, but that's not the same genre).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This game has some incredible aspects and I have played it many times hoping each time that all the good parts would come together.  What happened instead was a long drawn out game with an unsatisfying ending.  Ive spent a lot of time lamenting how good this game isnt

Space Conquest/War/Adventure Game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
Brilliant and revolutionary game design of a fairly complex space empire game. It's actually a well done, heavy 4x euro/amero hybrid. However I dislike two major luck factors in this game: Exploration random tile draw, which can ruin whole game for some players and bubble up the winners, and combat dice chucking festival. I feel bad when I score 3 sixes against superior opponent who rolled three ones. 
I bought this game expecting lighter version of Twilight Imperium which I am huge fan of, but  Eclipse is not a substitution for it as it turned out. Also in the beginning, length of the game is not what it says on the box. 
I love the modular hex board and the way it expands. All components are beautiful. And I am huge fan of having many conceptually different races to choose but I am not very fond of the artwork on Eclipse race sheets.

[b]Edit:[/b] With more practice and when all players are committed and when you include Rise of the Ancients expansion game becomes competitive and fun and slightly faster. I raised the score from 6 to 8.
[b]Edit:[/b] With Rise of the Ancients, Nebula, Pulsar and Super Nova expansions the rate went from 8 to 8.5.
[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] The resource/population/science track and the way it works. Also action/upkeep track which is probably the most revolutionary mechanism in modern board games.

RATING: 8
A thematically rich and strategically deep game. I've enjoyed it every time I've played. I've also been frustrated with it every time I've played, but still want to play it again when the game is done. 

Pros:
   -the resource system is brilliant
   -alien civilizations are well balanced, and bring a necessary amount of variation to the game (seriously, start playing with aliens as soon as possible)
   -exploring, colonizing, and battling in space are all thematically rich experiences
   -the artwork and layout is engaging

Cons:
   -certain technologies and ship upgrades seem to be over- or under-powered respective to others
   -chance and luck play a larger role than I'd like them to
   -the play area ends up being prohibitively large
   -runaway leader can become a concern, especially in games with fewer players
   -game runs about twice as long as they claim it does

All in all, if you have a Saturday afternoon or an entire evening (and a giant freaking table) to spare, the game is certainly worth the investment. Some of the community-suggested tweaks here on the geek improve the gameplay considerably as well.

RATING: 5
Eclipse is a euro/AT hybrid.  It's very much a Euro when you consider the strong economic aspects of the game: putting cubes from your player board to planets will increase your income in 3 types in subsequent turns.  The three types of currencies are as follows: money: needed for paying for your civilization and actions, science: needed to buy technology which helps improve your ships and can get VP if you specialize, and materials: this allows you to create ships, space stations and monoliths. During a round, you'll be removing discs from your board to take actions and control hexes of space.  For every disc you remove, you're increasing your civilizations costs at the end of the round.  It's very much a balancing act.

The ways it's like an AT game is that you are moving spaceships around hexes and combating opponents ships and taking over their areas of space.  You get to customize your ship with various technologies and roll a lot of dice when you get into combat.  The game tries to encourage combat as you will draw multiple VP chits of varying amounts from a bag after combat and so the more you take part in combat, the more likely you are to dig for the higher VP amounts.  The game also allows for creating alliances but you can also break these alliances as well.

Overall, I recognize that it's a well designed game but it doesn't suit my tastes for a number of reasons.  First, I don't really like the randomness of the hex tile draws.  Someone being surrounded by a lot of neutral ships could be a bad thing.  I also didn't really the dice for combat.  It works but isn't really appealing to me.  Finally, I don't like how it's mainly just a game of posturing for 8 rounds with minor skirmishes and then all hell breaking loose in the last round with everyone grabbing all the VP they can.

RATING: 8
What I like about Eclipse is that the rules are relatively easy to grasp and it's not fiddly. Yet within this ruleset, there's enough options to consider and enough tactical variations to employ. Nice if you like getting into planning tech and customising ships.

The game goes up to 6 but I think it will play a lot better with fewer players. First, less downtime (which is still an issue here with 6). Second, there's more room to really get into the 4X aspect of the game. With 6, there isn't much eXplore before you get to the eXterminate!

Overall, a game I enjoy playing but if part of the appeal of space games is the theme, then Eclipse shares a problem with non-famous settings space games. It's cool to play a Star Wars or Dune game because of the setting but you're not going to get the same kick with Eclipse.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Every action in Eclipse must be considered carefully because Eclipse is primarly about resource management.

Eclipse finds the balance between its elements. Resource management is critical but intuitive. Technology is great fun but does lean towards ship parts. Ship design is satisfying without being complicated.

Combat is enjoyable but not essential. There are enough Ancients (NPCs) on most maps to give players a chance to earn points without fighting eachother... if they do not want to. I really enjoy having the option of not being aggressive, though in games with five or more players things do get crowded and you may feel forced to.

Concerns are few. Combat VP has a large influence on most player scores, and 'lucky draws' can make the end result a surprise. I've noticed a tendency to avoid inter-player combat until late in the game, but this may just be that everyone wants their ships to be as 'awesome' as possible before engaging.

One of the greatest things about Eclipse is its play time. This is a 4X game I can actually get other people to play. If you have a group that is resistant to highly involved and complex games, you can convince them to play Eclipse... and they will thank you for it.

RATING: 5
I'm not the target audience for Eclipse, but I thought it was a pretty good euro. The economy/action board is interesting in how you decide to use your resources each turn or save them up. Deciding on which techs to take is a lot of fun, and they give you a kajillion to choose from; this is tech tree heaven for people that like that sort of thing. In our game, the guy who went into the center on turn 8 put a big ol' bulls eye on his back and was torn to shreds on the last turn like the unfortunate object of a piranha feeding frenzy. Seems like you're better off creating alliances with neighbors b/c the benefit is just too good and keeping things quiet until the last turn when you decide how to best bust your move. That's what I did anyway. I'm not sure why I'd want to attack someone before turn 9; seems like I can just attack aliens and get my VP tiles from them.

RATING: 7.5
I have to play it more in order to be able to judge it adequatly.
As of now, I think its rating is between a 10 and a 9.
It is beginner-friendly, balanced, streamlined, elegant and it offers a huge gameplay diversity.

Aside from theme, they don't have much in common.






Upgrade: vote goes down from 9 to 8

After many plays, I have to say it didn't "age" as well as I thought.
I have three main concerns about this game:

It is entirely based on economic power; tactical play is completely absent and the strategical element is relegated to economical planning.
Money (thus actions) is by far the most important resource: it does not only allow you to sustain a bigger empire, bolstering your science and materials output, but also makes up for inferior tech on your ships, allowing you to effectively swarm and pin enemy forces.

The combat system: it is based on technological might rather than the number of ships (this is something I can live with) but more disappointing is the fact that, again, it is economy who makes and breaks your game: the upgrade mechanic is designed so that being able to perfect counter your opponents' ships means you can score crushing victories over them; thus being able to upgrade perfectly your ships and react to your opponents' upgrades will prove the most effective strategy to win space battles in Eclipse.

Finally, I think this game has not a replay-value as high as one might think seeing some of his features: highly differentiated alien races, random available technologies, modular hexagon-shaped board etc.
I think this is mostly due to the fact that the game dynamics all revolve around the same mechanics, thus even if some variables change, the game feels very much the same.

After all, in my opinion, Eclipse is a very good game with many strong suits (I like the VP-scoring system and exploring mechanics the most) but it is a space-themed economic ("euro") game, definetly NOT a cross-over euro-amerithrash or a 4X game: its core dynamics make optimization and neat economical play the most important aspects; no fighting, no negotiating with other players and the likes.

The change in my rating reflects the fact that I think it does not offer as much variety as I originally thought.

RATING: 2
To be clear, I don't think the game is poor - for years I thought it was a very good game - but I am done playing it. Rating objectively, I put this at an 8; my desire to play it is now a 2 - after 28 plays, I don't want to play it ever again.

JAN 2018 - I've done with this game. It gave me a lot of good plays, and had appeal enough to get friends to be excited about it, but after 25 plays or so, I just don't find it fun anymore. Sitting through other players' battles can provide drama and amazing beat-the-odds results, but it's also time consuming and frequently uninteresting to non-combatants. I also don't like the tendency of my plays to have no combat till halfway through the game; and the slow crawl through the techs to tweak your ship for battles has just become rote. Nothing here is really the fault of the game, but after 25 plays, I'm just not interested in exploring the game any further, even with expansions.

Played 22 times (mostly 2p, also 3p & 4p) for 48.0 hours.

JUN/13 - Strong mix of Euro systems and Ameritrash theme-based mechanics. I initially gave this a 10, but on a second playing bumped down a notch to a 9. As I was playing, I found the admittedly well-balanced resource system to be such a large part of the focus of the game that the game experience felt too Euro (read system heavy) for my desire for a theme-heavy game.

I think a $15 expansion that consisted of a deck of 60-100 encounter/event cards would turn this game from a 9 to an 11, and make it my favorite game ever. (Just looking at the first large expansion makes me think the Hive ships and new player mats would make for a 10-rated game).

JUL 2013. Still incredible game design. I just want a bit more theme in the way of non-player alien encounters and other events. That would nicely supercede the focus on the resource engine that drives so much of the game.

MAY 2014: Still a solid 9 for me. better with more players, obvs. 

JUN 2014: Last play was only an 8 for me, but it was a combination of being tired, getting unlucky with early tile draws (Ancient hexes and a Draco neighbour), and having to teach the game to new players...again - which I find exhausting. In general, my enjoyment of the base game is an 8/9 depending on the group, and a 9/10 with the expansion.

22nd play: :star::star::star::star::nostar: DEC/14: I like the game with 4p, but Alliances have to be banned right now for us - 2 players with the best ship designs banded together to steam roll the other two of us, and is was distinctly less fun. Also, after the game ended, we removed the 7-9p techs out - they add too many power techs.

Rating history: 10,8,9...10...9....

RATING: 10
Great Game! love every aspect of it.
Likes:
-exploration
-alien races with asymmetric powers
-tech tree and upgradable ships
-graphic design is amazing and easy to understand
-space battles are intricate and mean something
-winner or loser you get some points for battles
-getting points is obvious (thanks to the graphic design)and remains a key focus throughout the game!
-Smooth Gameplay. Means plays really fast. Expect a play of 4 players first time to go 4-5 hours.  But experience players can play 2-3 hours. 6 players may still take 3-4 hours.  

what others may say because of luck that I see their point but don't totally agree with: 

-exploration draws are too random
(you can choose to keep the hex or not. wasting an action.)

-hexes are random with resources and ancient ships
(they are but if you played it more than once or looked further, brown hexes are more common in spaces further from the center as well as less ancients) 

-hexes on the third hex are empty.
(they most likely have a discovery that you may use or keep 2vp that no one can take from you)

-I am surrounded by ancients
(ancients may slow you down. but they are good hexes to take over because of the battle vp's and discovery tokens. +now your ships are most likely are built up to dissuade others from attacking you right away)

-Dice combat to random
1) techs offer you full customization to beat up ancients from almost round 2-3. Adding a computer, a shield, more cannons, and putting some extra hulls to beef up your ships.  Yes there is variability, but you can make your ships almost never miss if you have a couple +2 computers on board.  

2) Combat is not the only way to win the game. some combat is good. Vp's are won for winning or losing, and destroying ships.  Everyone wins in a way!

-Random tech draws
1)Knowing 1st player has a clear advantage to pick the tech that became available.
2) knowing you can not bank on a tech popping up to completely keep the same strategy.
3) Missed this the first 10+ plays.  before you pick your race in the beginning of the game the first techs are displayed on the board so you can plan a little more in advance.

If you played once and don't like something I think you should try it again. Unless you completely hate luck you should try and play 2-3 times to understand the concepts and learn how to play more tactically verse strategically. This game has so much depth and rewards more excitement and strategic potential each play thru.  A solid 10!!!

RATING: 8
Christmas 2011.

Fascinating game, this is.  There are some very neat ideas going on in this game.  It's pretty simple to understand, and plays reasonably fast for a 4x space game.  I've now taught this game to several people and have played at least 10 games now.  Good game.

I'm obviously a huge fan of Twilight Imperium III and don't agree that this game replaces TI3.  They both have a place in my collection.  If I want an immersive experience, TI3 is still my favored choice.  TI3 offers a lot more choices every game and leaves you with a feeling of having played something epic.  My wife still prefers TI3 (I know -- that's awesome).

I acknowledge that Eclipse is fresh and clever and plays very quickly.  It's a great game.  And I'll play it more often, for now for sure.  It's easily a choice for me over other medium-length games to play.

The more I play this game the more I recognize the cleverness of the design and nuances of play.

RATING: 9
Rules Complexity: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Strategic Depth: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Luck Factor :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
Negotiation Factor: :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Amount of Downtime: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Fiddliness: :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::star:
Component Quality: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar:
Player Interaction: :star::star::star::star::star:
"Take That" Conflict: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Theme Integration: :star::star::star::star::star:

Eclipse is a very elegant design: one gets the feeling that in the hands of most designers, there would have been twice the rules to produce the same effect. There are multiple paths to victory, and while some defensive strength is almost always necessary, going on the offense against other players is not absolutely required. One can see elements of Through the Ages and Hansa Teutonica in the design, but the heart of this game is all about customizing ships, exploring new worlds, and doing battle.  An amazing mix of Euro-style economics and action-selection, and good-old fashioned American combat.  The only reasons I don't rate it higher are that it may be a little longer than it should be, and there is a little more luck in the balance than exists in my very favorite games.

RATING: 4
Eclipse could have been one of the best game.
But it is far too random. Why for hell should we draw a random map, take our technologies randomly and even drawing a random number of victory points after winning a combat...
The problem is that, when all the tiles are drawn, if you are unlucky, you can be blocked almost forever. It's in that kind of game when the losers play 5 minutes while some can play during 20 minutes... just boring.
But remember, the victory is also random, and you can finish 2nd after losing all the game.
But that's the drawbacks. Eclipse is still a nice civilization game and the idea that the number of actions you have depends on how much you pay is nice. I would advise the pre-draw the board or find some rules to avoid randomness.

RATING: 8
This is my favorite game. I will play this one any chance I get. I like all the little details. I love the deep strategy element. In this game you must also have an adaptive strategy. I love the theme and mechanics. I like to play the races with different abilities.

My only issues is the resource pieces are so small and the dice and combat pulls can have profound impacts on an otherwise well executed strategy. With 6 players this turns into a 3-4 hr game (which is okay for me but others may be turned off by it). Also, diplomatic relations are important but I feel llike this particular mechanism can/should be expanded.

Also there is a slight race balance issue as the Eradani are handicapped but there is an easy way to solve the problem don't pick the Erandi as your race (unless you want a Challenge and bragging rights but you were warned). 

Finally, I would not recommend this game for casual players. I would recommend this game for its theme and its strategy elements.

RATING: 6
Is Eclipse the revolution of the 4X genre? Nah, not really. What it is, though, and it's true that this sets it apart from quite a lot of the competition, is a very well-developed game. The mechanisms mesh very well, it all makes thematic sense, and handling is still reasonably simple even with a perceived gazillion of counters (quite possibly because the designer wasn't afraid to incorporate a number of Euro-like features; a Euro, however, this ain't even though it uses lots of wooden cubes).

That the game takes less than a fortnight to play is commendable but unless you look at space operas only that in itself isn't too much of an innovation. At the end of the day what we have here is a game that competently dodges some of the typical implementation issues in 4X games but still carries with it the basic challenges of multiplayer conflict games, for good or bad.

RATING: 5.26
In the beginning of the game, your fate can be highly influenced by the discorery tiles you take. Start next to ancients and you'll have a hard time, because you do not have the required strength to defeat them yet, while other players are getting tiles with free resources and research.

After that, you spend hours setting up your economy and ships for the great conquest, and when you think are fine to go... the game ends. Then, each player counts how many random VP chits had been taken during the game an sum up with the rest of points. That's it.

In the other hand, the ship upgrades are awesome, and with the economy they're the best parts of the game. They're not enough to make me wish to play it again, though.

It is one of the most anticlimactic experiences I've already had with a board game. I had the highest expectations about it, but it was such a disappointment to me. Fortunately, I had the opportunity to try before buying this expensive game.

If you wish to play an EPIC space empire civilization game, play Twilight Imperium instead. Do not believe this game is like TE, because it is not. I am not saying the theme is pasted on (it is a very thematic game IMO), I just mean that the only resemblance between the two games is the theme. Some people say Exodus Proxima Centauri offers similar experience of TI3 in less time, but I've not played it yet and so can not comment on this.

As I alread said, the technologies and economic mechanisms are great, but there are too many other (best) euros with great economy and much less randomness than this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have always wanted to play Eclipse- love space, space battles, exploration, etc. I've sorta slumbered through the iPad app without really ever getting a sense of what to do. Read the rules and watched videos and still didn't get a sense of the clear objective here other than "get points". Eclipse's largest strength is that sort of sandboxy, infinite ways of customization- good, good ideas. Allows for great replayability and all under 4 hours. For all of its rules, it's fairly straight-forward and it only takes one play of it to really get a sense of what's going on. I'm sure 4 players who have a good sense of what's going on would have a real good time here.

I don't think Eclipse is for me. It has some mechanics that I really do not enjoy. For a game with lots of decisions to make, the randomness of VP tokens and exploration tiles can certainly direct this game. Not a terrible thing as there are players who love having to deal with random occurrences on the fly and I'm certain players with skill can handle this. I would not accuse Eclipse of being chaotic or unfair. In fact, it's a very fair game considering the randomness. But when it's not being overly random it has that: "the rich get richer and the poor die trying" factor that pretty much gets established in the first hour of the game. I think games that make you really stretch your resources can easily fall into that trap. It absolutely creates tension, but this tension can easily boil into frustration. In fact, a member of our game went bankrupt, but pretty much put himself in that situation after realizing an hour before the game was over that there was no getting out of the dire predicament that he had been put in after a devastating attack from an opponent.  And I knew that no matter what I did, there was no stopping one player. This is okay, really: great Eclipse players should be able to see when a player is getting overpowered and they can sort of "truce" together and take down the leader. That didn't happen in our game which unfortunately set the tone of our game for the rest of the night.

I'm also not a fan of the combat system, which feels rather uninspired and is just another rehash of a dice-chucking combat system with modifiers. Again, that can be okay given the right game but I would have expected something a little more unique and intriguing given all the physical beauty of Eclipse.

Best points? The rulebook. One of the best written.  The examples could have been a bit clearer but otherwise this is how a rulebook should be written.

To summarize: Eclipse is a good game. A very good game, actually.  It's just not a very good game for me.  Though I'd be willing to try it with less players in a quieter setting and see if that changes my enjoyment. Certainly knowing the game a bit better would have  positive effect.

RATING: 6
After playing other peoples copies of Eclipse a number of times, I was compelled to buy my own copy and collect the important set of expansions and promos. Eclipse sets a new standard for “4X” games, particularly because it is playable in an evening with a full player count. If you are in the mood to Explore, Expand, Exploit and Exterminate this will scratch that itch. It is an excellent example of a Euro / Ameri-trash Hybrid that leans toward Euro, with a little dice-chucking combat luck that can be mitigated by the players. It does an excellent job of translating the theme onto a game board – you really feel like you are exploring space and expanding your galactic empire. 

My only complaint: this game has the "three player problem" so don't play it with three.  Also, I'm not fond of the large space battles that tend to occur late in the game and just drag it on and on.  So, my rating reflects that.

RATING: 9
One of the best & most elegant systems around in a space combat/exploration/economic game. It's shorter playtime, puts it far ahead of competitors like TI3, even though comparisons to TI3 are understandable. As long as gamers know that this is first an economic game first, and a space exploration & battle game second, then Eclipse can be received and experienced in such a way that is deeply satisfying. If you want in-your-face combat games in space, there are a plethora already to chose from. Not too much downtime since there's enough to plan for. There can be enough negotiation as well, depending on players. Far better than Exodus, IMO- mainly because it feels far more satisfying to attack other planets with ships, than simply send rockets (from planets) to do so, and your fleet size is not as limited (as in Exodus).

RATING: 5.5
9.0 after 1st play, 4 players with human races
7.0 after 2nd play, 5 players with human races
5.5 after 3rd play, 6 players with alien races

Fine game mechanics indeed, but the VP system IMHO is broken. Played with 4, 5, 6 players. Every play ending like a Twilight Imperium's weapons race for Mercatol Rex.
The combat system turned out to be a very dice fest, particularly in the the final turns, when all the spaceships get stuffed with every available cannon, turret, missile, etc.
The VPs won for combat results are way too overbalanced vs. VPs gained for research.
Exploring a new tile is almost a matter of luck.
In the last two plays we ended with about 20 points between the first and the second player.
End of 3rd game: 42, 26, 25, 21, 21, 16 pts.


All this make me feel very disappointed by a 4 hours game which I put on my wish list since I returned from Essen.

RATING: 9
I was concerned that I might not like this, because superficially it resembles games with a lot of "incidental complexity" and unnecessary learning curves, traits which I do not favor.  I was pleasantly surprised to find that Eclipse is actually *not* a complex game; the rules are straightforward, the iconography is helpful, the combat is streamlined, and the number of actions to consider on any given turn is quite limited due to scarcity of resources.  There are a lot of bits, but I wouldn't describe it as "fiddly".

The variety of alien powers are interesting.  This should have good replay value.

RATING: 8
Very good euro/risk wargame - combines resource management and VP conversion with typically Risk like attacking and area control. Additionally the euro aspect of the game allows you to develope your ships to emphasise speed, strike power, to hit capability of defense, as well as your VP scoring capability - very good. There is however a considerable luck element in the turn of the planets you explore and a bad turn early in the game can severly set you back. 

Components are excellent and very functional with possibley the best player boards ever.

RATING: 5

Sadly way too long for the randomness involved...
Still better than TI3 though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fairly nice components...though they are not as nice as TI3, and I paid more for this. (not by much. :))

The rules have a few interesting ways of handling things like upkeep and technology tracks, which simplify some of the more tedious parts of the whole epic space-empire genre. There are a lot of icons and colors to remember as well.

The games theme isn't very unique but it works and it shines through in the gameplay. I do get the feeling of building a space empire, exploring, and upgrading ships.
Battles kind of fall flat, there isn't anything clever about them...roll some dice, compare some numbers, things explode...meh. I do worry about everyone jumping on the missile boat! The game may become scripted where the first few turns will automatically be geared towards building up defenses once someone starts investing in them!

Is this the holy grail of space games? Without hesitation: No. 
It is a good effort though, and I'd say it bridges that gap between Galactic Emperor and TI3.

My rating for this may go up or down with more plays...games like Ascending Empires come out that REALLY simplify what we're expecting from these space games. I see similar empire/tech growth in every one...the only thing that changes is the depth and specificity of choices available. Sometimes I think the only way we can REALLY get that epic space game feel...is to play the epic space games on the computer.

RATING: 5
The good:
1. customizable ships
2. streamlined design makes gameplay very straight forward
3. easy to teach and new players are not at a huge disadvantage

The down side:
1. Virtually no diplomatic or political system whatsoever
2. The wormhole system is absolutely terrible and allows people to turtle with virtually no way of countering it.
3. Very minimal interaction resulting from scripted and finite game turns. On turns 1-3 you almost exclusively explore. On turns 4-6 you kill neutrals and expand as much as possible. On turns 7-9 you maximize points and plan your final, and often only, assault on neighbors to grab some extra VP.
4. Besides how to outfit your ships, there are really no difficult decisions to make since all your turns are essentially scripted.
5. Due to the above reasons, low interaction, no diplomacy, scripted decisions, etc. this game is simply not epic. It is a mediocre euroy version of a space 4x game that sacrifices everything that makes a game an epic 4x game to streamline its mechanics. Unfortunately in doing so it also takes out all the complexities, strategy, diplomacy, and other interactions that make a 4x game fun to play. You are left with an efficient sort of engine building type 4xer without any of the teeth that draws me to the genre. The great parts about the game, like the customization of ships, are simply overshadowed by the dullness of the gameplay. I will play it again if others want but it is largely uninteresting albeit a smooth design.

RATING: 6.2
This game is a light version of Twighlight Imperium 3.  It has all the same problems:  too long for what it offers, lots of luck in revealing new locations and combat and combat rewards; and a new problem of very little player interaction.  The game is polished and those who don't mind a lot of luck and very little player interaction in their space games might like it but I didn't.

Edit:  After playing another game (about a year later) I found I enjoyed it a bit more than the first time and so bumped my rating from a 5.5 to a 6.2.  It still has a lot of luck but that goes down a bit once you understand what the odds are of you drawing different types of Type I,II,III systems as well as the impact of the different technologies.

RATING: 10
I have played a lot of Civ games over the years and this is by far my favorite in both the physical and digital realm and it only gets better with expansions.  It meets that sweet spot of complexity without really slowing down the game.   I do enjoy more complex games such as TI3 but they come at a cost of trying to find a play group that wants to sit down for 8+ hours for one game.  But I can get a lot of the same highs from eclipse in almost half the play time due to some really elegant game design in some areas and trimming back some complexity in areas that don't really harm the game.

 
Plays spectacular with 3-4, starts to get a little long in the tooth at 5-6  and I have never been brave enough to try the 9 player cap that the expansion adds because that would be a lot of down time between turns. I have enjoyed 2 player games but at least in the core game it can feel like you have a fairly clear winner by about the half way point.   The expansions help fight this back by adding more goals to reach for that do not come via direct conflict with other players. 

If I had to give it one con it's that its set up can be a bit of a slog if only because there are so many pieces to this game. 


I have owned the game for about 3 years now and it is till one of our top go to games to pull out even after all this time. I can't recommend this game enough if you like big sprawling civilization type games.
