RATING: 9.2
Reading through the rules tonight and hopefully getting in a 2-player game before bed!

Update: Wow! We had so much fun, just with 2 players and with neither of us knowing the rules. My girlfriend is completely unfamiliar with 4X games, and even she loved it - we both stayed up way past our bedtime to finish because we were that invested in what was going on.

As everyone's said, the mechanics are beautiful. Complex calculations and concepts are made simple through the design of the game. But most importantly, this game really gets the 4X feeling down. There are tons of decisions to make - each turn gives you such a variety of options, with deep and complex ramifications for each choice. I felt it in my gut the whole time, that special feeling you get from a really immersive, addicting and thoughtful 4X game, where the range of possibilities would be overwhelming if not for the grand strategy taking place.

Really good stuff, and that's with just one two-player game under my belt. Looking forward to more!

Edit: Played a 4 player game with 2 newbies, it was excellent. One guy went super-aggressive and conquered almost the whole galaxy, but the guy who was walled off in a corner building monoliths and slaying ancients still almost beat him. There were some tense attacks, counter-attacks and last-minute alliance breakings, and it all made for a supremely entertaining and satisfying conclusion to a long night of board games.

RATING: 6
After a few plays, this felt too much like rock, paper, scissors. Except that each player knows who is playing rock, paper, and scissors. Battles are determined before they begin depending on who has which upgrades. And the strategy your opponent picks dictates what you should pick.

I do love the exploration and resource collecting system. The way the player board works with the expansion of your empire is brilliant. Unfortunately the problems above overshadow this brilliance and sours me on the game as a whole.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A few years back, the light civilization game was a popular design goal. There have been many aspirants to the throne, but ultimately it is hard to do without trading some crucial aspects. This is a space exploration and conquering game in the same style as Twilight Imperium, but with much shorter play time and have less ambiguous rules.

There are no cards in the game and almost no secret information, which might make it less intriguing, but because of these decisions it wins on consistency, ease of play and game balance. The game feels streamlined and elegant, borderline clinical. In the beginning of the game, there is usually much exploration, but a few turns in it become highly interactive. You usually have to fight with the other races some time during the game because it gives a bunch of victory points, but not too much since you then easily neglect other goals. Balance is the key here. 

The question I query is if the game is fun in the long run and how replayable it is. The alien races are certainly different, but I can see that the openness does mean that there is not so much play of surprise. I generally like how the order system works where there are an upkeep to have many things and how much you have. The exception to this is late in the game, where it can become a chicken race in order to strike against the other players. I found the game a little bit lacking if all players play defensively. The game is good, but it doesn't always play out as well as it looks on paper.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Good strategy game in which you have to expand your interstellar civilization.  Surprisingly easy to learn for a game so deep and engaging.

On your turn you can : 
- Explore to add hexagon to the modular board and colonize it to produce more ressources
- Influence to take control or leave an hexagon (controling hex cost money but also give VP at the end of the game)
- Research new technology to have better upgrade for your ships, be able to build new things or gain other bonuses
- Improve your ships to increase their movement, attack power, defense, etc.
- Build to add your ships on the board
- Move to move your ships (and fight if occupy)

The winner is the player with the most victory point after the 9 round of play.
You get VP for every :
- Reputation tile received after battle
- Ambassador tile received when doing diplomatic relationships with other civilization
- Control hexs
- Monolith on control hexs
- Discovery tile received when taking control of an hex (by exploring most of the time)
- Technology track (the more you research, the more point you'll get)

You lose VP if you have the Traitor card (last player to attack a civilization with which he had a diplomatic relationship)

With all those way to score VP, There are many path to victory.

RATING: 7.5
If you judge a game on the number of bits that you get then this is a real winner.  The concept of resource management is excellent and helps to prevent players from quickly running away with things.  The upgradeable ships are also very cool and an excellent element that livens up combat.

However, this game really relies on people knowing what they're doing.  More experienced players will wipe the floor with anyone new to the game and it can be a long slow death for those being beaten.

Also there's not much player interaction outside of combat.  The diplomacy is practically non existent, but what little there is doesn't really work.  2 Experienced players who start next to each other can just form an alliance and crush all before them.

a 10 rating after 2 plays, might be a little presumptuous, but seriously.  This game.  Seriously.

RATING: 9.5
I can understand how the reputation chit-pull can seem random and frustrating for some players.  I don't mind it because attackers have to realize they may be handing more VP to those whom they accost.  In the long run, the victims of aggression may have the greater reputation and become the Galactic leaders.
I find the limit on reputation chits you can keep an interesting system.  You are encouraged to fight, and fight early, to get good chits before others claim them, but warfare has diminishing reputation benefits later in the game, and the value of the hexes captured becomes more significant.
Economic system is excellent.
Graphic design is excellent.  I can see what I need to and it makes sense.
It is tricky to avoid accidentally upgrading beyond your ship's power supply capabilities.  It is good if players can watch what others are doing to avoid honest mistakes.

RATING: 7
Interesting system design, and a bit less complex than might appear at first sight.

Do have a concern (based on limited play so far) that a player's ending position is too heavily influenced by a relatively small number of important "events" like sector tile draw (on explore) and fighting the ancients, not too mention if a player is on the receiving end of a sector raid. Especially if one of these happens early in the game, it appears that will permanently put that player's empire behind those that had better early luck. Yes, there are strategies, but it is a struggle just to try to keep up as the others move forward.

If it had a longer run time, that could even out. But having only 9 rounds in a 4X game seems too short to recover from "black swans" and/or launch a proper military campaign (especially without just being a kingmaker).

For that reason, I am thinking of this less as a serious planning game and more as a "Hollywood" game... lots of good looking parts and action, but not as much meat in the plot.

Still, at least it was fun to explore the game system and want to try it some more.
Folks seem to think very highly of this, but I need to play it a bit more to see why that is.

RATING: 8
Preliminary rating after 2 plays with 4 players.

Cons: not yet sure about how I like the luck factor: random rolls with 1D6, random alien technologies which range from powerful to "meh", random drawing of victory tokens and last but not least random drawing of exploration tiles which can easily lead to one player having a head start while other players still struggle to get their third colony.

4X de ambientacion espacial.

RATING: 8
Believe the hype.
This is the full 4X experience with no corners cut. It moves at a good clip, and does indeed not consume your entire day. It's easy to teach and grok, and it feels like a good Euro; until you get into a fight, when it feels like a good dice-chucker; and after the battle, even if you were obliterated, it feels like a good Euro again. Well done, people. The circle has been squared.

RATING: 8
With a stunning amount of bits (900+), it sprawls over the table and requires a setup time to rival almost any other game. Yet Eclipse's gameplay is easy enough to grasp that, despite its long playing time, it can appeal to almost any gamer. 

Some of the mechanisms here work very well, particularly the action tracks. Placing pieces from your playmat onto the board not only shows which planets you have claimed, it also reveals higher-valued options beneath. Of course you will have to pay more for these as well, but that system works very nicely too. In fact, mechanically, the systems all work together seamlessly. There is a lot to admire in terms of the design. 

If Eclipse has a flaw in design, it may be lack of interaction. The eXterminate seems to be the weakest of the 4 X's here, as mobility towards other players is often limited, a problem that worsens with greater numbers of players. It can also tend towards an excessive amount of planning, not AP so much, but simply taking into account a lot of factors each turn. 

Ultimately, Eclipse somehow manages to feel both extremely accessible and extremely overwhelming. It's an experience that is worth having if you are in the right mood and you have the time, but it's not as quick or streamlined as I was hoping. Despite any misgivings I may have, this is one I'd love to own and would have a hard time turning down an offer to play.

RATING: 8
This game strikes an amazing balance between military and economic contests. However, it is not inevitable that the game will be played that way. It is possible to focus on building your resources without initiating combat (that is, it's possible to turtle). But you can't initiate combat without building your resources. With a bit of luck, you can do well by focusing only on building resources. But it seems that striking the right balance between resourcing and combat makes for a more fun game, and the people who do that well seem to do better in the game. That point of balance is a moving target given how dynamic the gameplay is. The result is a really fun game that keeps you thinking. What helps all of this work especially well is that the game design is stunningly smooth in its execution. There is an amazing amount of gameplay that is squeezed out of such little amount of adminstrative overhead and fiddliness.

RATING: 10
love it
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Eclipse is- or was- something of a perfect storm game, smashing up a delectable mix of Euro-Wargame-4X-+-Civ into an attractive package with plastic minis and random hex board.  The game is not exactly any one of these styles- 4X most of any, I guess- but it has flavors of all of them.

It's not an incredible mess- in fact it's a great game.

I took a long time getting to play this in part because I couldn't believe that, but it is a sharp game that flows together well, makes sense as you start to play, enables different paths to victory, and has good (not stellar) graphics.

Players settle areas with three kinds of colonists providing three basic resources- but the kind is determined by the board, not the cube.  Players use discs as they take actions each round, and each action costs progressively more. Players also influence regions with discs, so maintaining influence requires money- the more discs are on the board, the higher the cost each turn. The more settlers are on the board, the more resource is revealed for collection turn-by-turn; it's really a pretty brilliant way of managing something that could have been overwhelmingly complicated if it was done by AH in the 80's.

Combat is handled when ships are in the same region- there are rounds based on weapon types, with some being far more effective than others, but the types available also vary.

Technology choices are randomly determined at start of game, and come out in dribs and drabs. Do I grab the key tech choice first, or influence the system between us. I need to build ships if I do that, but can I afford the actions?

Lots of delicious choices as you grow a Terran or alien civ to command a corner of space, and battle for supremacy in the galaxy's rim.

I am starting this in elevated company at an 8, after a 1st solo 3-player game. I can understand why it not just fans of the new and shiny who would love this- it is a tasty game, and I look forward to more plays soon.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A lovely economic game about efficiency, masquerading as a space opera. I love how you can customize ship schematic designs to adapt to the board situation, and variable player powers add to the game's longevity.

Just posted this on facebook in a boardgames discussion. It feels relevant to copy/paste.

"I just played Eclipse down at the games club I play at in London so I thought it was topical that I mention it. This should give you an idea on timeframes for the game.

It is possible to play with 4 experienced players in 3 hours and therefore possible to get a game into an evening. However this time we were playing with 1 newbie... 45 minutes into the evening we were done with the rules explanations... 30 minutes into the game someone had to take an emergency call from work (that obviously can't be helped)... 20 minutes after that we were back to playing.

We only completed 7 of the 9 turns and one of the other guys was keen to tot up VPs. We established he had 25 to my 23, the other 2 were miles behind. And so he declared himself the winner and said that it was the only thing that could be done as we had to pack away.

I was most irritated as I was building up to a big attack, I had 3 Plasma Missiles with +3 computers on each of my cruisers, I had 2 Plasma Cannons and a Plasma Missile on my Starbases, also with +3 to hit (which were placed strategically). Now I should put this in context I had 4 Cruisers 1 hex away from the central alien and worked out I could pick up 10 points in the next round with still 1 more alien to fight after that.

I was allied with all three other players but the only way for them to beat me was to attack (break the alliance and inherit the traitor card) then still lose to me and thats good for me still. I was in an unbeatable position and challenged the 'winner' to suggest where his final points could possibly come from. He couldn't but stuck to 'the game ended after 7 turns because it had to, therefore I won'.

Overall I found it thoroughly unsatisfying... Not because of the game. The game is fantastic. But be prepared to set aside a whole day for your first 3/4 games of it or be very irritated as the game reaches it's climax."

---

Edit: I still LOVE this game. I've loved it more with the more times that I've played it. Unfortunately I rarely get it finished because of how long it takes. The 30 min per player on the box is bullshit. In reality it's 45 mins per player that knows what they're doing + 1 hour per player that doesn't + 2 hours per idiot. Then add to this 30 mins set up, 15 mins packing away and 30 mins teaching (if there's newbies).

With 6 players expect to set aside a full day, unless you have the most awesome friends in the world (in which case it's still an afternoon).

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
(05/2012) Comment based on one play.

5-player game of newbies took 5.5-6 hours.

This is a brilliant design, in terms of innovative Euro and Ameritrash mechanisms, integrating meaningfully and seamlessly within a sci-fi theme/context.

I have always wondered if a [thing=1431]War at Sea[/thing]/[thing=1442]Victory in the Pacific[/thing] combat system could be applied to a [thing=12493]TI3[/thing] context, and it seems here is the answer.

While I am a fan of TI3, I have always been disappointed with the combat system. Ship types are generic and functionally (and visually) the same from race to race, with some minor differentiation based on technology upgrades and racial ability. Combat is a la [thing=98]Axis & Allies[/thing], where each unit has a different "to hit" number. For example, a lowly fighter needs a 9 on D10, a cruiser needs a 7, while a dreadnaught needs a 5. All ships, with the exception of dreadnaughts and war suns are destroyed with one hit. Combat is simultaneous, with ships on both sides firing everything. The total number of hits is tallied up for the attacker and defender. However, the most ridiculous and unrealistic aspect of the A&A-type combat system is that the each side gets to [i]allocate[/i] damage to their own ships, irrespective of the type of ship that attacked--there is no way to target a specific ship. The most common strategy is to produce carriers with lots of inexpensive fighters, which then serve as cannon fodder to absorb the hits and screen the more expensive units.

The War at Sea combat system was able to abstractly represent many different classes of ships from WWII using three numbers (each from 1 to 9). A lowly heavy cruiser was typically a '1 1 7', meaning it had a 1D6 attack, could take one point of damage before sinking, and had a relative speed of 7. If attacking, a '6' on 1D6 was a hit, with each hit re-rolled with another 1D6 to determine how many points of damage was inflicted on the targeted ship. The Bismark was represented as a '4+ 9 6'. The '4+' meant 4D6, but it needed a '5' or a '6' to hit. With 9x "hit points", it could take a lot of damage, but could not outrun a heavy cruiser (if it wished to disengage/retreat), due to its slower speed factor ('6' vs '7').

Eclipse seems to take the War at Sea system, and expands upon it along similar lines from [thing=1589]Star Fleet Battles[/thing], [thing=1540]BattleTech[/thing], and [thing=2891]Starfire[/thing]. It allows players to customize three different classes of ships and a star base class, with unique technologies that improve baseline armor, shielding, firepower, targeting, and speed of each class. The amount of "stuff" that one can pack into a ship class is constrained only by the number of hull spaces and power source (an idea SFB, BT, and Starfire share), the latter which can be upgraded with technology. For example, a cruiser template has six hull boxes, five already filled with subsystems: 1x armor/hit point; 1x "weapon" that allows 1D6 for attack, doing 1x point of damage, but consumes 1x point of energy; a "computer" that gives +1 to hit; a "drive" that allows the ship 1x hex movement, but consumes 1x point of energy; and a "energy source" that provides up to 3x points of energy, enough to power the weapon and drive, and possibly one other subsystem that consumes no more than 1x point of energy. In WaS terms, this is sort of like a '1+ 1 1'.

Ship class is further differentiated by an "initiative" rating. The cruiser described above as a '2' rating, meaning it will fire before a baseline dreadnaught, which is sluggish as represented by a '1' rating. The least expensive class, the interceptor (i.e., '1 0 1') has a '3' rating. By adding a fourth number, the initiative number, the interceptor can be described as a '1 0 1 3'. This makes sense as a smaller ship should be more agile and  maneuverable. Increasing the drive capability can improve both movement range (on the board) and initiative (in combat). The interceptor, cruiser, and dreadnaught, can be purchased for 3, 5, and 8 "material" points, respectively. Previous "build your own starship" systems have more granularity in terms of production/acquisition costs, but here, Eclipse keeps it clean and simple. 

As mentioned earlier, these units can be "upgraded" accordingly, with more powerful weapons, armor, shielding, computers, drives, and power source, provided that the specific technology has been researched in a previous action.  There is a "plasma missile" tech that provides "first shot" capability with 2D6 and 2x points of damage, which is similar to air strike factors in WaS and VitP. The most powerful weapon tech in the game is the "antimatter cannon" (reminds me of the "wave motion gun" in Starblazers, or the Romulan "plasma torpedo" in SFB), while only a 1D6 to hit, dishes out 4x points of damage. This allows players to have fun mixing and matching techs and subsystems to create their own "super" starship design.

For example, in my first game, with two randomly found ancient artifacts, I was able to upgrade the cruiser '1+ 1 1 2' template into a '1+3* 5 2 3' "super cruisers" (the '1+3*' means 1D6+3, so the weapon hits on a 3/4/5/6, with 2x points damage). Compared to a baseline dreadnaught ('2+1 2 1 1), these units were feared by the other players. Researching and customizing ships individually is probably the most fascinating and fun part of the game. As a side benefit, this now serves as the foundation for truly asymmetric alien starship designs, an available and desirable option, once players have mastered playing the terran race "baseline" ships. 

Eclipse manages to expand upon the concept of action points. As the player explores/colonizes/conquers other systems, they can progressively increase their incomes (in a non-linear increasing fashion) of three resource types: money, technology, and material, which are represented by three sliding continuums on their player tableau. A player may take as many actions per game turn, but each additional action taken (and expansion into other systems) has a progressively more expensive upkeep cost (non-linear), which must be paid in money. Thus, the amount of money they generate, as well as the money/tech/material (tech and material can be exchanged into money at a 2:1 rate) banked from previous turns, effectively constrains the number of actions they can take. Eclipse also allows a player to take six different types of actions: explore, influence, research, upgrade, build, and move, all which have mechanical equivalents in most 4X games.

Turn order is standard clockwise order, similar to classic [thing=181]Risk[/thing], [thing=15363]Nexus Ops[/thing], and [thing=23950]Viktory II[/thing], with each player taking one action or passing. The first player to pass gets the start player marker, and is first to play in the next game turn. Players continue taking actions until they pass. What is unique to Eclipse is that even after passing, they are allowed to "react" to other players' actions with build, upgrade, or move, albeit all three at a significantly diminished capacity. The traditional clockwise order tends to make surprise moves favor the player to the left. For example, if I pass, and the player to my left attacks me with three units, I can still react, but only with one unit. If I attack first with three units, and the player to my left hasn't passed yet, they can respond equally with three units. Clockwise turn order would normally not be an issue, however, in Eclipse, combat is resolved in all contested spaces [i]after[/i] everyone has passed. Thus, both attacking and defending players can continue to move in more and more units into the contested space, only constrained by their banked money/tech/material. This makes surprise attacks based on numerical superiority almost meaningless within the context of traditional turn-based games.

Although this is a minor quibble, I would have preferred a variable turn order, as in TI3, which is dictated by selection of a strategy card/role, [thing=28720]Brass[/thing], which is based on how much money was spent, or [thing=1491]Outpost[/thing], which is based on current VP status. Bidding for turn order, using resources like in the advanced rules for [thing=54]Tikal[/thing], would make it more interesting also. On the other hand, determining the variable turn order for the next game turn can potentially add some time and slow down game play.

The explore and influence actions are a means of expanding one's empire, to get more of the three types of resources. Research allows acquisition of one tech for X number of technology/research points. Upgrade allows customization of up to two subsystem hull boxes on the four unit types. Build is producing said units in controlled systems. Move allows up to three movement points, which can be applied to a single ship or divvied up among two or three.

The exploration aspect is one of Eclipse's strongest points, and it's weakest. With every explore action, a player may pick a random tile and place it on the board, orienting it in such a fashion to ensure legal entry via "wormhole" and to either inhibit or enable contact with other players' system hexes. This is similar to the various tile-laying mechanisms, such as [thing=822]Carcassonnne[/thing], [thing=1334]Entdecker[/thing], and most closely, [thing=54]Tikal[/thing]. Each system hex comes with an assortment of "goodies", such as VP for controlling the hex, planets (on which to place population, and thus improving your resource tracks), and ancient artifacts (which grant either VP or a one-time tech upgrade or resource boost). While this can be fun and fascinating to seek out and collect those, it is possible for bad draws, where a player is surrounded by aliens (with nasty ships), effectively blocking them in for several turns, which is what happened to one player in my first game. Since there are a finite number of outer rim system hexes, they tend to go quickly on a first-come, first-served basis. By the third turn, all of the system hexes were gone, essentially locking in the "known universe" for that game. The exploration action became useless, and the player that was blocked-in initially, had no outer rim systems to explore although he had the wormhole access and space. A similar situation can occur in TI3, depending on system tile draw there, and then the subsequent placement of those systems. It may be a simple fix to "reserve" a specific number of outer rim system hexes per player, although this may require more system tiles through a possible expansion.

There are several minor annoyances about Eclipse's movement, however. For one, each move action means that at most three ships will be able to move together, so even if one was to amass a huge fleet in one hex, it would take several actions to move them elsewhere. Of course, on the other hand, interestingly, a lone ship with "tachyon drive" (3x hex movement) could conceivably move [i]nine[/i] hexes on the board and attack an opponent's outpost at the outer edge of their empire. Another annoyance is the concept of "pinning" in Eclipse. It is possible for one/two/three ships to enter an opponent's hex populated with a ship or two, "pin" those ships on a one-to-one basis, and continue moving with the remaining ships (provided they have  the drive technology and upgrade to do so). This means that all fronts are potentially "porous"; if frontier systems can be bypassed by pinning, interior homeworlds are not necessarily safe. This is in contrast to TI3, where a single destroyer can "block" an entire fleet of dreadnaughts and warsuns (unless they have the lightwave deflector tech). Whether either scenario is realistic or not can be debatable, but given the enormity of each system hex (in either game), Eclipse's approach seems to make sense.

Combat is also slightly less satisfying, as it is held in all contested hexes [i]after[/i] all players have passed, and not "as-you-go" compared to TI3 or other turn-order based space games. Since movement seems to be more clumsy in Eclipse, "grand" conquest strategies may need to be planned over a course of several turns. Interestingly enough, combat is resolved in the outer rim systems first (based on a "system number" order), and spiraling in towards the climactic galactic center. Producing units is relatively expensive, in terms of actions and resources, so fleets tend to be small. Thus, there is no need for an fleet upkeep mechanic, or fleet size constraint as imposed within TI3. Because of this, the epic space battles I have seen in TI3, may be limited to small task force engagements in Eclipse.

The research aspect of Eclipse is done differently, when compared to the tech-tree implementations of TI3 and other space-civ games. A number of tech chits are drawn randomly from a bag, the quantity depending on the number of players. There are no tech prerequisites; if you have the appropriate amount of technology points, you can "buy" that technology chit, much like you can buy buildings in [thing=3076]Puerto Rico[/thing]. Of course, the more powerful technologies are accordingly more expensive. If you don't have the tech points, you can always "trade" your money and material points into tech points on a 2:1 basis (the trading can be done for the other two resource types as well). There are three technology types, designated in three distinct rows (or tracks), each emphasizing specific aspects. As one develops more technologies along a certain row, there are discounts that get progressively higher, although each tech has a minimum purchase value regardless of discount. As tech is developed along each track, the rightmost tech spaces also give VP at the end of the game. Unfortunately, there are only limited quantities of the more powerful technologies, so not everybody will be able to get them, which is similar to the limited quantities of buildings in PR, although in PR every building is available at the start. Thus, manipulating the turn order, by passing first, becomes key if one wishes to snatch up a rare tech chit that everybody is eyeing. 

It turns out that the technologies in Eclipse tend to be weighted toward ship design, as in more powerful weapons, armor, shields, etc., as described earlier, and less towards the economics aspect of the game. Once a ship tech chit is purchased, a player can then invoke the upgrade action, and "install" up to two subsystem chits on any of the ship blueprints on their tableau, each filling up a hull box and possibly "covering up" an existing subsystem. This gives players great flexibility as well as agonizing decisions, since they must either focus on upgrading one ship class, or spread the upgrades among several classes. The only minor quibble about Eclipse's implementation is that upgrades are instantaneous, regardless of location. Thus, that lone cruiser out in the middle of nowhere can suddenly be juiced up with more powerful weapons and energy source, for example. [thing=84419]Space Empires: 4x[/thing], by contrast, has separate counters to specifically keep track of fleets with older technologies. While this would have been more realistic, Eclipse's design choice again keeps it clean and simple.

The game lasts nine turns, where at the end the player with the most VP is the winner. This is different from TI3, which is a race to 9 or 10 VP. VP in Eclipse is awarded for controlled systems, alliances, collected artifacts (taken for VP and not the technology), monoliths (sort of like 'statues' in Puerto Rico, pure material points --> VP), and "reputation", which is hidden. Reputation is sort of a random assortment of VP chits that players secretly collect, based purely on their military exploits; a player gets to "search" through X number of VP chits in a bag, based on simply being in combat and the number and type of units they destroyed. This last aspect can significantly swing the game in terms of VP, so classic turtling and focusing on research will not win the game. There must be a moderate amount of (and preferable early) aggression to collect the best VP chits, since players are only allowed to keep a very limited amount of them on their tableau.

There is so much to like here in this design. In terms of game mechanisms, it is very simple and straightforward, with most of it being intuitive. It is possible to quickly learn the game (preferably, from an experienced player), with little downtime compared to some other conquest games, space opera or other. Because of its streamlined play, I see it serving as a rock-solid foundation for various additional house rules and extensive customization, and it already screams for an expansion or two, in order to more fully flesh out the Eclipse universe.

My initial play was very favorable, although I am concerned about balance issues due to the random nature of how the system tiles come out during exploration. In our game, the player to my left unfortunately was blocked-in during early expansion, by running into relatively powerful ancient units (that had to be destroyed, before he could expand any further). By the time he was able to "break out", by focusing on research and building more powerful units, the rest of the exploration tiles had been used by the other players. The technologies that are available for purchase also come out in a random fashion at the end of each game turn, so early turn order can favor certain players over others in gaining rare, but powerful technology. Also, each player ended up with wildly different resource allocations, thus making the mid-game somewhat unbalanced. Still, although there is some randomness, it feels appropriate for what one should expect from space exploration.

Another concern is that with repeated plays, the game may begin to feel "same-y", since there is very little flavor and variation to the overall back-story of the theme. This may be due to our initial game where we all played humans. With asymmetric aspects introduced by alien races, this may continue to be interesting. Although the flexibility offered by the ability to customize ships is absolutely wonderful, and a game in of itself, I am concerned that so much effort (and actions) went into customizing a ship type that only saw combat once or twice during the entire game. Granted, this had a side benefit of giving me VP. Thus, the "design your own ship" mechanism seems to be out of place, being more detailed and complicated than it needs to be in the space opera scale Eclipse is trying to emulate. (On second thought, I probably should have been attacking with these awesome ships!)

The components look very good, with good production values. There is a palpable Finnish minimalism that I must respect from a design choice perspective, as it is definitely muted compared to FFG's typical chrome and busy detail. The rules seem adequate, although there were some obscure circumstances that took some digging to clarify. As for theme, it feels somewhat sterile compared to TI3, however, where everything seems to be generic. For that reason alone, it is definitively NOT the TI3-killer that I was expecting. There is no "politics" aspect, save for the alliance mechanism (which is a brilliant way to do trade agreements). There are no "take that" cards, as represented by the Action Cards in TI3, so there are no unexpected surprises or intrigue. With the exception of exploration and available research tech, the game state is comparatively stable and quantifiable. Overall, the game shines in the smooth playability and intuitiveness of the game mechanisms. It is sufficiently different and novel given its "build your ship" mechanism, and significantly streamlined from TI3, for me to consider it a slot in my game library.

I am excited about this game, and eagerly look forward to many more plays. My initial rating is a solid '8', with plenty of room to move up.

Hey! How did a comment turn into a review? I must [i]really[/i] like this game. :P

Sorry about the length. :blush::whistle:


Update (06/23/12): Second play with own copy, with 5-players (2x newbies and 3x "played it once"), took 5 to 5.5 hours. Setup took 30 minutes. Rules explanation took 45-60 minutes. Takedown took 15-20 minutes. Everyone had a good time, although the initial 2-3 turns were clocking in at an hour each, making for a long slog. Final turn saw many scattered battles all over, with 29/29/27/17/15 points respectively with total resources being tiebreaker.

Played with several house rules:
1) Variable Turn Order [filepage=74846]variant[/filepage] using this [url=http://iresto.free.fr/bzh/eclipse/eclipse.png]image[/url] (using the cards only--if reaction actions were added to the "next turn" cards, this would be fantastic; no pawns necessary!)
2) Warp Sector [thread=755962]variant[/thread] for 5-players.
3) Designation of targets on a ship-to-ship basis (no splitting of firepower) [i]before[/i] rolling dice. 

All three house rules were readily welcomed and all agreed these were much better alternatives.

This session was more intense, with more combat involving more research and upgrades of ship subsystems. It alleviates my concern about so much effort going into ship design, since it was immediately apparent that better ships win more battles, and thus strongly determine who will be doing better in the game. The other concern that was alleviated was the "those who explore more are going to win" fallacy. I think I did the most exploration, but ended up with so-so system hexes. Several players were hemmed in early due to poor exploration draws, so they pursued research aggressively for the same explore actions, and ended up doing far better than my exploration strategy.

Although there are many random elements in the game (i.e., discovery tiles, system hex draws, reputation tiles, combat dice, research chits), it isn't totally chaotic like Cosmic Encounter; there is enough control (or the illusion of control) to manage the destiny of one's empire.

The population cubes/action discs uncovering the income/deficit value seems to be borrowed from [thing=43015]Hansa Teutonica[/thing]. This makes for an initially cluttered player tableau, but in terms of gameplay, it is simply fantastic. Upkeep is quick and intuitive. It is game mechanisms like this one, and the seamless integration of many other mechanisms, that makes this game smooth as glass.

I'm going to up this to a '9'. It is not TI3 by any stretch of the imagination, but Eclipse is clearly its own breed of game and there are no pretensions to being a replacement of TI3. Comparisons are inevitable with other space games, but this game stands on its own, based on its unique take of the "4X" genre. After pondering this awhile, TI3 is a [i]space opera[/i], while Eclipse is a [i]space war/economic game[/i]. TI3 has [i]drama[/i], while Eclipse has [i]action[/i]. TI3 is [i]subtle[/i] (remember, it is [i]not[/i] to be played like a war game), while Eclipse is [i]in your face[/i]. The game's minimalism in terms of mechanisms and well-integrated systems serves as a rock-solid foundation on which players can customize and tune Eclipse to their own liking, with house rules and variants, as well as for official expansions. This is exemplified by the sheer number of pages of posts in the various Eclipse forums. I don't think it is too hard a prediction to see that Eclipse will be considered an important watershed design in the realm of 4X, an instant "classic" when we look back at this in a number of years.

Update (08/18/12) 14 plays: Managed a 6P game in 2.5 hrs (25 min/player)! 5P in 3.1 hrs (37 min/player) and 3.7 hrs (44 min/player). 4P in 3.6 hrs from opening box to closing box (53 min/player). We've nixed the "designate target" rule, and have gone back to the original rules--it still bothers me that damage is allocated [i]after[/i] the dice are rolled, but it is much faster.

I am starting to wonder if Eclipse's narrative is the same every game: 1) There is almost [i]always[/i] a climactic battle in the center during the last turn; 2) A decent expansion for an empire seems tied to getting that critical "Advanced Robotics" or "Orbital" tech in the first round or two, which is dependent on the random first turn order, and dependent on if there are randomly one or more copies of these techs; and 3) The kind of systems that are drawn will relatively determine the money/research/material tracks for each of the races, and how well they will do in a given game. In contrast, TI3 may have varied narratives every time, due to the richness of the theme and game mechanics. It still is impossible to decide which is the better design, as they each invoke gaming nirvana in different ways.

Update (12/24/12) 16 plays: Two plays with newcomers (3-player and 4-player), after a four-month hiatus, provided yet another slice of the Eclipse experience. The "flavor" of a particular game can change depending on the selection of Ring I, II, and III hexes. The inner rings are loaded with better planets, but little or no discovery tiles, while the Ring III hexes are the opposite. Players that go outward will encounter more discovery tiles, and hence powerful Ancient techs that can conceivably steer the game in that player's favor. However, those systems tend to be relatively poor, thus offering little long-term economic advantages. The inner systems, by contrast, offer better economics, boosting the money, tech, or material tracks; the tradeoff is no techs for combat. Another interesting tradeoff arises in the number and distribution of hexes occupied with ancients. Although being surrounded by ancients may pose a near-term obstacle(s), it incentivizes actions toward building an offensive capability, which ultimately results in more reputation points. If one is posed with "easy" systems, the income tracks grow accordingly, but focus may be lost on building for war. If one does not encounter any ancients, there are no opportunities to gain better reputation points (the assumption being that drawing later in the game results in poorer draws), other than being forced to attack others after exploration has been exhausted. Attacking is rewarded, yet drawing another player's ire may put both at a disadvantage, while other non-combatants pull ahead in other areas. Fighting early and drawing early can result in a good 12-14 points hidden until the end of the game, contrasted with 12-15 points for 4-5 monoliths for a non-combatant.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
There are some excellent ideas here for a meaty 4X empire-building in space. Yet there are some odd and swingy mechanics that really blemish the experience.

Early exploration is hampered by random tile drawing effects. Drawing tiles with hostile alien ships, mis-matched jump-gates or fruitless planets is painful. Random tiles may sound like a good idea but the implementation here is too big a swing. Combat is a strictly 1-vs-1 since the rules oddly do not allow allies. Even weirder is that victory points are awarded to all combatants via random draw. Very swingy.

For such a long game with few victory points, these odd design choices simply allow too much overwhelming luck. Combat is unfulfilling and exploring can feel down-right unfair at times. Bearable if the game was 1+ hours but hideous for a 4+ hours experience. Though not nearly as hideous as the plastic ships ...

RATING: 7
A game we seem to have played many time before: Twilight Imperium, Galactic Emperor and probably many others. The formula is pretty familiar, explore, develop new techs and fight wars. What lifts this space epic above the ordinary is really two things: the presence of neutral enemies who can be fought and defeated for plunder, and limited connections between hexes and sharply limited ship range to cut down on arbitrary attacks. This doesn't mean, however that there isn't a huge random factor in which tile you get when you explore and what prizes you get when you fight. An early money boost, in particular is a massive swing in your favour. The alien races tighten the game up quite a lot, there's less money and so fewer actions available which speeds the game considerably, but it's still an incremental snowball and there's no way back once you fall behind. For all of the detail in the technologies and ship upgrades, combat still feels remarkably bland. You're just rolling for hits irrespective of how powerful your ships are and a decisive advantage is difficult to obtain. Several gaming buddies now own this, so I'm sure to be playing regularly, but it's just a little short of being a compelling game for me.

RATING: 5
First time playing a 5-player game with almost all new players, and my first foray into the 4x genre (so grain of salt and all that) but this game seemed too long for what it had to offer.  The high cost and limitations of taking actions made the game both too long and too short, as it took a long time to get things going and then the game ended before anything really interesting could happen.  Other comments about your tile draws dictating your strategy seem on the mark - get a lot of one particular resource and you're basically funneled down that path, get bad tile draws and you're pretty much screwed.  I ended up with a lot of brown planets (and 0 or less surplus money for the entire game) so I built a lot of ships because I didn't have much else to do.  Another player was dealt a crippling blow around turn 3 and spent the next 2+ hours unable to do anything, which was fun for neither him nor me (I don't like seeing people put in that position, even if it increases my chances of winning).  Our game did end with a ridiculously large battle for the center tile which was entertaining for the 5 minutes it took to sort it out, but I can't say it was worth the 3 1/2 hours it took to get there.

RATING: 6
OK, this is going to officially be old and crotchety.  But I am beginning to think my friends in the Euro community are going increasingly gaga over games like eclipse because they turned up their nose at "Ameritrash" for so long and didnt realize what the genre had to offer.  I liked Eclipse, but this is a very conventional 4x game (explore, expand, exploit, exterminate).  It has some nice Euro style refinements -- I particularly like the "post pass" options.  But taken as a whole, the game does not really tackle any of the hardwired problems of the genre.  For instance, there is downtime -- plenty of it, and more players just adds more.  There are no real catch-the-leader mechanisms, and the tech tree discounts tend to reinforce the problem.  The rich will get richer.  There is no reason that turn 9 will not become a silly Götterdämmerung, cuz those thips you've been buying are worthless at the end of the game.  These are problems that people who have been playing wargames since the 70s have understood for years.  I think to be a game getting this much hype, there should have been a concerted effort to get at some of them.

RATING: 7
With three or four players, Eclipse is an engaging, competitive, and well-streamlined Space 4X experience.

With more than four players, it drags. The playtime seems to shoot up non-linearly. Also, with fewer tiles-per-player, and less room between players, the luck factor seems increased. One game I observed had a particularly unlucky player crippled on the second turn, with no recourse for the next 4 hours.

Some games I've played have felt _too_ streamlined, with little story arc other than build-up-and-smash-at-the-end.

Finally, I like the Plasma Rockets just the way they are. Leave them alone!

RATING: 5
Eclipse is a fantastic 4x space game with a focus on resource management.  There is combat but you're focused on deterrence over outright incursions as each player tries to outmatch the other while parking their ships at the edge of their borders.  There aren't massive fleets here like in Twilight Imperium, but when combat does break out it can get bloody and intense.  Eclipse has plenty of options and depth to satisfy multiple playthroughs for anyone looking for a little more "Euro" in their trashy space empire games.

5/4/16: Being limited by money puts you at the luck of the draw. You may be surrounded by money generating tiles or end up in an impenetrable field of hostile NPCs. Eclipse is fun until you hit that wall then it's 2 hours of non-competition.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Yeah, its good, not without fault though. 

I'll put up more comments later, think TI3 (but WAY more streamlined) with a Tech track a little similar to FFG's Civ, and a playtime close to Civ. Eclipse is actually easy to teach, learn and most importantly PLAY.

EDIT - Well its been awhile since I wrote the above but I'll try to comment on what I remember about the game best I can. 

Seems to be pretty well designed and developed overall, calling it “Civ in Space” isn't too far from the mark, at least it reminded me a little FFG’s newest version, and of course TI3 (still have not played TTA!).  There is lots to like here, really liked the fast turns to keep things moving, I played with 6 and while it was a LONG game your turn still comes around fairly quickly each time.  Sometimes it seemed your options were really limited, for example from the Techs available you could only afford one or two due to your money or the draw, and I found some other examples like this where some turns felt scripted or limited especially near the beginning of the game.  

I think the game might be best with 4 or 5, with 6 there is no way you are going to interact with everyone anyway so you lose nothing and likely gain with lower playtime and less time in between turns (I wont even call it downtime because the turns were that fast). What did seem to take too long sometimes was combat, figuring out all the modifiers and then rolling, and rolling until things got resolved.  Overall it was okay, you have ways to modify your rolls with Tech, though these can be countered by your opponents with their tech.  

Speaking of luck, the dice rolling obviously which you hope would even out and in the VP chit pull, which I found a little concerning as well as exploration which many have commented on. For VP's I wonder if the chits should have been 1 – 3 instead of 1 – 4 but 1-4 could be fine, though maybe a chit pull for VP’s wasn’t the best route to go.  There are many other ways to get VP’s AND usually you are going to pull 2 – 5 chits out of the bag and keep only 1, also, you only get to accumulate 5 or 6 this way so again, likely things will even out and the more you attack and go to the bag, the better, that is a key point right there.  Overall I think the luck is probably okay but maybe a little on the high side for the length of the game, though if you suck at rolling you might not feel this way and if you get burned in more ways than one it could be a [i]really[/i] long game for you.  

I did find one little issue near the end of the game where if you did not have your VP track full you could send a ship or two on a suicide mission just for a quick chit pull or two, this felt wrong/off, but getting a VP chit for losing and not killing anything is a nice little compensation.  Rules are nicely streamlined, its really fairly easy to teach and learn overall. The thing they really did right here over TI3 was to encourage fighting by giving VP’s (although see my suicide note), that was one thing I commented on after playing TI3.  Has somewhat slow beginning like TI3, here your choices are fairly limited in the beginning just like there, but it is much faster than TI3's in comparison.  Going last should have probably been compensated, you miss out on some cheap techs at start of game (all anyone can afford) and you can be potentially boxed in slightly by the other players so maybe another small niggle here.

RATING: 10
OK. So I hesitated about my rating for quite a long time but finaly I went for the '10'. For many years I have been searching for a space empire building game that would suit my taste. 

RftG is great but it lacks a board and lacks the space fleet building aspect. 

Galactic Emperor is dull - it just doesn't stand the comparison with other non space theme games. 

Space Empires is good, but the bookkeeping and the involuntarily cheating during games are major flaws. 

And then there is Eclipse - it is fast, it scales well from 2 to 6 players, it is simple to explain, it enables ship building and technological research. It has my favourite board game mechanics: tile placing and in my eyes it has just an enormous re-pliability value. Not to mention that all the mechanics work well together and the game flow is great. No snowball issue either.

Is this my Holy Grail? After two games I am far from saying that but I do see such a possibility.

RATING: 6
There are too many things that go on in this game for me to really enjoy it.  I never really felt like I was expanding, exploring, exploiting, and especially exterminating.  Exploring is probably the only one that really shines here.  Managing the money, with random techs coming up, and bumping into the table and having all the cubes scatter...  I don't know, it was an alright game, but not very wow. Production was great, the pieces are fine, if not numerous.  The setup and cleanup was quite an ordeal.  It had kind of a "Monopoly in Space" kind of feel with all the banking that went on, and I'm not very down with that.  Not to mention it lasts longer than Monopoly, which just made it more boring.  A great game that lasts forever is perfectly fine.  A dull game that lasts forever is just awful.

It's not the worst game ever, but it could have been so great.  I wanted it to be fantastic - a grand space opera with exciting gameplay!  Hell, they could have taken out all the tech, the tedious exploration, the horrible banking (don't tell me it's not banking, that's all it is), the cubes, the extra bits, add in more combat, sped it up some, and had another Cosmic Encounteresque game, and I would have been fine with that.  But, it does have all the aforementioned items, and we have Eclipse.  Somehow not an epic space opera, but more of a bad soap opera.

RATING: 6.2
Was definitely worth a try, some interesting mechanics, but both the length (and yes, I've seen reviews saying it can be played quicker with out 1st timers and repeated plays but the same is true for all games), and the luck (and we're just no talking dice rolls) in a way just makes this a glorified Starfarers of Catan.

Regarding luck, there is the dice rolls for the combat, which can be somewhat mitigated by gaining research and then upgrading, but not only can bad luck at dice rolling hurt and good dice rolling benefit others, but just gaining the research is a luck fest of sorts... not all research is available, it's random each round which research (knowledge/tech) is available, and the luck of the turn order (which you really don't control as passing 1st to go 1st next round doesn't help as you don't know the new research that will be available until next round) decides who can acquire it.  Also luck of the explore action also hurt some players while helping others.

If it wasn't for the length though I'd be up for a 2nd play.

RATING: 8
This is a really well designed game. The systems in this game are brilliant. It's more or less the Twilight Imperium experience but in a elegantly streamlined form. And playable in a reasonable amount of time.

That being said, it still felt a bit too long for me, and surprisingly easy to avoid other players. I won strictly because my race got bonus points for having the neutral pirate ships on the board. My winning strategy: explore like wild and avoid other players like the plague. Not horribly exciting.

RATING: 6.5
2012-09-20

Initial Rating: 7.0

It took me almost a year to play this, but I finally did :). As the hype is still strong and overwhelming, I wasn´t surprised to find the game a little of a letdown. Eclipse is currently #5 on the BGG rankings.

First of all I have to say I played it with only 3 human players, perhaps my rating will go up when playing with 4 or 6 players.

On the plus side, this is my favorite theme of all time, the rules are intuitive and fairly easy to grasp (in spite of the 30+ pages rulebook which by the way is very well done), for me it has some resemblances to Through the Ages (which is a plus) and the play time is relatively short. The components are pretty clear and nice (Although I´m not crazy about the art) and the game came with a lot of them.

The gameplay is very streamlined and the game has your attention the whole game. I didn’t felt a high down time. I really liked the way eclipse handles the actions and the way you can customize your ships (this is a first for me in a boardgame) :D

I really liked the combat system, it allows you to pit your customized ships against other players or the ancients. Obviously the combat has a lot of luck, but with carefully customization (computers) the luck can be managed.

On the bad side, The art is ok EXCEPT for the depictions of the aliens races, those are abysmally awful. I know this is a very minor thing but as this is my favorite theme I would have loved to see more development of the aliens races…. Their pictures aren´t believable (as believable as an Alien can be :D) and seem put there as an afterthought. I have not yet played with the aliens races, but looking through them only 2 seem to play really different. In general I didn’t feel Eclipse was a thematic game.
 
I’m concerned about the missiles in battle. If someone developed them it becomes an arms race because they can be so powerful in battle. For me this detracts the fun from customizing your ships as there is clearly a (only) superior way to optimizing them (with missiles) :(

In my first game, I didn’t found any tension in my decisions. They felt somewhat scripted as it was always clear what was the best course of action and being first only counted in a handful of situations (although I believe this can change as we get better playing the game). In the middle game, it didn’t matter much if I developed first or built first.


Bottom line, I’m rating Eclipse a 7.0 due to the enjoyment I derived from it on the first play (I won). Eclipse is a good game, perhaps a very good game but I need to play it more to form a better opinion.

For now (beware blasphemy ahead :devil:) I still prefer to play Twilight Imperium. I think there is room for both games in my game collection as I feel they scratch different itches :D.  Twilight Imperium has an epicness feel that Eclipse just don’t have. 

Current Rating 7.0

2013-02-18

I’m downgrading Eclipse´s rating due to the fact that I don’t want to play it often, so a 6.0 is better suited according to BGG´s rating system. I want to play it with alien races and with more players to really see if the game gets exiting.

RATING: 8
Eclipse is a work completed at an exceptionally high degree of difficulty.  Many attempts have been made at civilization-light.  Those which have tend to come out as either not civilization (Innovation for example) or not light - which for a civ game means 2-3 hours.

Eclipse undoubtedly has a civilization feel.  There is exploration, economy building, and combat.  It also deals with some of the "problems" of the genre in novel ways.  Actions per turn, for example, are a simple function of one's economy level and the amount of systems one currently controls - and one always has the opportunity to blow past one's current economy level to deal with a pressing threat.  Of course the instability may cause the player to have to relinquish control over some outlying systems - which may have been the attacker's goal all along.

Movement is also rather innovative, with the wormhole mechanic restricting movement.  This leads to the somewhat visually off-putting result that sometimes you are not as close to your opponents as the board indicates due to the nonexistence of wormholes.  Going off and exploring solitaire has some drawbacks though - there is a small but perceptible advantage to establishing diplomatic relations with opponents, and at the end of the game there is a technology that can allow movement through "half-wormholes," which can lead to an unfriendly force swooping in on the unprepared.

The ship designs are a rather clever lift from the Master of Orion video game series and feel like an important and interesting part of the game without being overly fiddly.  Also meriting attention is the technology system which at the same time rewards specialization by providing tech discounts, but gives flexibility by making all techs in the pool available to one who is willing to pay the price.

Like any ambitious effort there are potential flaws.  A common complaint I've heard (including from some players in my game) was that alien ship parts are simply too powerful, and that perhaps it shouldn't be possible for someone to explore next to your home system, happen upon an advanced drive, and suddenly be able to mass a large fleet on your doorstep.  Also the tech availability is more mechanical than thematic - why can't I have antimatter cannons when I'd be willing to pay extra to focus my research on them?  Someone else discovered them first, and there simply aren't any more available?

Still, Eclipse does a lot right, and with as many headwinds as a design in this genre has, I am willing to overlook the flaws.  This game does a lot (if not all) of what I want Twilight Imperium to do, in 1/3 the play time.  That ensures Eclipse will see a lot of time at my table in the near future.

RATING: 10
It's funny the first time I played this I thought this was closer to a Euro than Ameritrash.  After my second play I really felt a bit different.  Random dice, Random Explore tiles, Random Alien Techs, Random VP chit pulls, and Random insertion of Techs on the market all point more toward an Ameritrash feel. 

I enjoyed my play more with three players and I'm thinking this is primarily due to the game length.  Random elements are okay but when you have that many in a four plus hour game my tolerance begins to waiver.  The most defined random event is the explore tile pull.  This can make a huge difference in a game paticularly with inexperienced players.  Those new to the game don't know any better but folks with a few games under their belt realize that they probably need to target the fortunate player(s).

Randomness aside this is a brilliant game.  A three player game with folks who have played a few times shouldn't run more than two or two and a half hours.  This scratches the MOO 2 itch for me...and that's saying a lot for me.   

***Update***
I've spent a considerable amount of time and money on this game. I've played virtually every expansion and seen most of what it has to offer to date.  The game certainly has flaws.  The best advice I can give to a new player is win your first battle.  That first battle it typically with a weak alien ship.  Defeat it...make sure you do because if you lose you'll spend the next few hours attempting to catch up.  It typically won't end well for that person.  Flaws aside, this game is outstanding.  How the techs work and the upgrading of the ships and the variable alien races all works so well for me.  Bumping this game up as best in class amongst 4X games that I've played.  Know though that my opinion is in the minority for much of my gaming group.  This is more of a testament for their dislike of 4X games than for this title specifically.

RATING: 9
I'm generally not a systems buff. I put much more weight on the feel of a game than the cleverness of its internal workings.

Eclipse, though, nails the flow of running your little 4X-ing faction so well that while the game can occasionally feel a bit dry and mechanical, and while the sessions can run long and have lots of downtime during big endgame battles for non-combatants, its systems are genuinely so enjoyable to work with that they easily make up for the downsides.

Eclipse manages to avoid the trap of being a thematic paste job on top of soulless Euro-style resource management, and while I wouldn't call it "epic" in space operatic terms, the theme and the American-style hybrid elements still make the game more than the sum of its parts. The theme is meaningful and playing the game just feels really good, easily carrying as much as a six-hour game of new players without breaking a sweat.

Combined with a very competently handled sci-fi space theme and vast replayability (even more so with expansions), Eclipse is easy to love. It's not quite a ten, overall, but it's a confident nine.

RATING: 10
Eclipse is the quintessential 4x experience. The decision space is perfectly balanced--wide enough to allow for a vast array of viable strategies, but narrow enough to remain accessible and minimize AP. The theme comes through brilliantly, and the visual presentation is stunning. Gameplay is dynamic, highly strategic, and rewards advanced planning. Even the various random elements play a key role in testing players' skill level and adaptability (i.e., you can't rely on a single strategy every game). These elements also add layers of surprise and replayability without compromising strategy. This game is a phenomenal achievement.

RATING: 7
An admirable design that I think hits the sweet spot for a 4X title in a way that TI3 could only dream of doing. The tradeoff is that everyone is a playing what amounts to a nameless, faceless civilization--I wish it had some more differentiation, but having that and game balance is easier said than done.

There's very little downtime, and I was impressed by the integration between the actions and upkeep costs. I'm curious how much less time a 4P game would take (as opposed to 5P). The randomness of the payouts from exploration draws is bound to bother some people, but I had no problem with that. My downfall is that I'm just not very good at identifying quick ways to get efficiency engines set up (income, research, etc).

It might have a smidgeon too much Eurogame feel to it, but ultimately I think I've determined that I just don't like the 4X genre very much.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Space themed Euro economic/military game. Some very interesting innovations:
 
- ship configuration. Being able to customise your fleet is cool. You feel that you are adding your unique touch to the ships and providing them with a bit of personality. 

- worker/action cost calculation mechanism. The complex calculation of resources, science and money are handled in a really tidy way. The only downside here is in game setup - where each player has tens of blocks to position. Also there is the 'nudge' factor! With so many pieces one small knock can make it hard to recall where everything was.

While I like this game, something about it falls a little flat. It's not a patch on TI3, which is a completely different beast with the same theme. I think the Euro elements actually make the game feel too mechanical. I like building an economy, but the options of how to build an economy are too limited - I have to expand, an there is too much luck of the draw in the early game - a good system drawn early gears your economy immediately; whereas an early empty or ancient heavy system is a heavy penalty to suffer. TI3 handles this better, allowing players to choose how their local sectors are mapped (albeit at the loss of exploration). 

I also feel Eclipse is weighted slightly too much towards early military rushes. If your neighbour begins to build new ships, you are forced to drop your economic build and instead focus on defence. I dislike being forced away from the game I want to play: I feel the game should slightly favor a solid economic build over the short-game rush.

The seeded tech-tree doesn't work for me. Too often I find one great technology is seeded that everyone wants to get. I also find myself having limited interest in early technologies when I could get a significantly better tech a turn later. However, this of course relates to my game preference - long game over short. I don't want to research a basic fusion engine, when I could bypass it for an advanced one in the next turn. 

Probably stemming from my wish to take my time and gear my economy before I attack a neighbour, I find I always run out of game turns and am rushed into a big battle. I know many already find the game takes too long, but for me the end is somewhat forced. Another 2 or 3 turns would allow a more natural conclusion. But then I recognise that I would like bigger fleets - more epic battles, more options for ship configuration etc. 

Overall, I feel the game is good, but short of great. There is something missing. Too much luck, not enough real choices, and too much advantage given to those who build early-game mini fleets with early-game (inefficient) tech improvements. This frustrates, as the elegant strategist should be able to outwit the route-one hoard in a well design game.

Issues:
-Too much luck for a 4 hour game
-Too much downtime.
-Runaway loser problem; potentially a runaway leader problem too. (38, 31, 31, 30, 15, 5 in my one 6-player game.)

Realistic (in the sense that some empires historically have militarily obliterated others), maybe. Fun, not.  Think Hiroshima & Nagasaki.  So, some major balance issues in the tech. 

I do give them props for having easier rules to learn than TI3.  But, for this type of flavor and game-play I'd pick Galactic Emperor any day, plus at 90 minutes I'd get to play at least a whole 2nd game of something
in the same time.

RATING: 7
I'm really really in two minds about this game. 

Pros:
The economic aspect of the game is beautiful... so simple but so effective.  The debt mechanics are ingeniously balance.  As a whole, all the stuff on the player's board works beautifully: the modular ships, the research track and the concessions for investing in one particular line of research.  Likewise: the exploration, the numerous ways to gain VP etc. all make for compelling stuff and immerse you in a really galactic experience...

BUT

Cons:
Eclipse is a tease! sure you can play it safe, but how will that give you the edge when your opponents build a menacing armada on the fringes of your empire? Do you risk it and head into the middle? what are the odds on beating those ancients guarding the handsome cluster of planets you so desperately need? Therein lies the problem: get the lucky dice rolls and you'll be smiling your way through... roll snake eyes and prepare to watch your opponents gobble up all the nice things on the board for the next 3 hours.  The moral seems to be "play it safe and you'll muddle along. Play it dangerously and you'll either roar to victory or spend the rest of the game licking your wounds".
Oh, yeah, and missiles are stupidly OP.  build yourself Kamikaze missile gun boats with the cheapest ships and watch as your opponents fry...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Provisional rating of 9 after two games (1 2p, 1 3p). Eclipse is an extremely clean and well-designed hybrid Euro/Ameritrash "solution" to the 4X problem. After the first couple of plays, and these not even at the likely optimal number of players (guessing four), everything seems to click and pretty much everything seems to work. Like most hybrids, it's best not played as a conquest game--see Space Empires: 4X and others for such--but rather as an economic efficiency engine. Components are very well done and, in 2012, pretty lavish for the price point (can you imagine FFG giving six-player potential out of the base-set box?). Gameplay is tight and tense. While it takes (or at least takes me) about 30-45 minutes to explain the game to those who haven't read the rules, by a round or two everyone seems to get it. Initial playtime of 45 to 60 minutes per player should decrease some. (My second, 3p, game played a bit shorter than my first 2p game.) Lots of tough and interesting choices here. Highly recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5

These are my issues:

:thumbsdown: The ease of being able to set hexes so they don't allow invasion.

:thumbsdown: The fact that the GCD's are found randomly and so if you first set up your borders to not be invaded, you then can explore at your leisure, attack the GCD's at your leisure, and still get reputation tiles. If I ever was to play again, that's the first house rule I'd make, no reputation tiles for fights against GCD's.

:thumbsdown: The diplomacy rules encourage turtling even more. Oops, can't fence off your neighbors? Offer them an ambassador early in the game when they desperately need money. This works particularly well if you are on a 1 VP tile, as it doesn't make sense for your neighbor to take a -2 hit on a risky combat.

:thumbsdown: Attacking is really penalized in this game. Someone moves into your hex, you just upgrade and add to your stack. 

:thumbsdown: If you attack someone, win and get damaged, the next guy comes along, attacks you before you're able to build back up, she gets damaged, next guy comes along attacks her before she can build up ad nauseum.

:thumbsdown: Too many tiles (and yes we reduced the III tiles to the proper amount). This encourages turtling and discourages attacking as the tiles aren't worth much anyway. You get plenty of points attacking GCD's, why take on a high risk battle with a player (or at least until the end of the game).

There are a lot of good games out there. I'm fairly sure I could house rule this one to death or just go and play a game that works for me/our group out of the box.

Note that I do not play with the same people from session to session, so whatever is on the table is what is played. By that I mean that there's no "hey get Jennifer because she won last week" no meta gaming, stuff like that. It's very likely that the players have just met in fact. Thematic/Ameritrash games seem to work best when you have a set of friends who know each other fairly well and who want to play a game. That's not the situation that I'm in. Most times players don't know each other well at all. Had I realized it was more of a thematic game, I would not have bought it.

RATING: 7
A mechanically and thematically strong offering that takes parts from ameritradition and eurogaming and adds these together. Basically this is Civilization in space. Biggest positive for me is the super clear user interface with differently shaped tiles to differentiate uses and the player board controlling player's actions, tech and fleet. I also think that the technologies and races have been really thought out properly, although the gamble with Plasma Missiles may be a bit broken. The big issue for me is the epic battling occurring in the last round. This is unfortunately typical for this kind of games as there's no penalty for losing as the in-game future ends. However, the game has evolved from late prototypes to the published version on the diplomacy side which nicely lessens the end game all-in behavior. Further smaller issue for me is that I can sense the game being a bit scripted in long term. I'd like to see the designer using this user interface also in more games in the future.

RATING: 10
I love Eclipse, and it is even better with the Rise of the Ancients expansion. The design is beautiful and deeply intuitive, and the theme is perfectly realized. It just feels good to play, and the customizable ships are a delight to toy around with. 

In comparison to my other favorite economy-focused Euro, Terra Mystica, I feel that Eclipse offers a lot more immediate and accessible fun, without as much room to grow as Terra Mystica offers. On my first time playing Eclipse, which was also the first time for the three other people present, 3/4ths of us scored in what is considered the "good" range according to the forums here, where our (and one other's) scores at the end of our first Terra Mystica game were all significantly lower than the agreed-upon "good score" range.

Eclipse feels right, is deeply enjoyable, and has enough depth to keep your mind ticking. It also lasts exactly as long as it needs to. A great game.

---

One addition: whenever Eclipse is brought up in a discussion of games that are "overrated," the complaint is usually made that Eclipse isn't as 4X-ish as it supposedly purports to be, or that it is insufficiently Civ-like. I don't think it is particularly Civ-like, but it doesn't need to be—taken on its own terms, without having to compare the quadrant exploration to terrain expansion in a typical 4X, it's a lovely game that is, yes, very much an economic Euro while also having lovely space-themed flavor, and just enough map creation and exploration to spice up the mix.

RATING: 5
Economic snowball engine... in space! And with much randomness. A poor tile draw could see you boxed in or slowed down and in for a long time of waiting to lose in either case, while combat VPs reward those who get off to a good start. After one play this doesn't seem like a TI3 substitute to me, as there's basically no politics but instead a queer focus on spaceship tech upgrades, as well as various elements typically attributed to soulless Euros such as multiple currencies that can be spent towards the same mechanical goals and abstract VPs that are awarded for basically everything. You're not expanding an empire and generating narrative, but placing cubes to spin your tech snowball faster: several players could sit in their respective corners of the galaxy for a few hours, generate points in whichever ways, experience plenty of down time and ultimately not achieve much of substance. Perhaps I'd have to play TI3 more to see if these are things that really set the two games apart. Rating for this could go either way.

Update: Rating going down because it's just so long for what it ultimately offers. I'm open to the possibility that multiplayer politics can work well with experienced players but they haven't really in any of my games. Risk aversion, scoring uncertainty and punishing mechanics all work against informed, let alone coordinated, action.

RATING: 7
I like it, but I absolutely do not love it as much as some people appear to. It is a worker placement game in its heart. I am not sure why people think the space theme is strong in this game, but to each their own. In my opinion, it is a worker placement civ-building game. There is a well designed tech tree and customizable aircraft blueprint is just awesome. The problem with this game is that it gets samey very quick. RATING: 10
All those "bad" reviews saying this game was basically a resource management euro set in space made me really want to try it, and I'm glad I did.  It took a few plays to see how all the different systems interact, particularly vis a vis combat, but what emerges is a nice hybrid design that combines the streamlined mechanics of a euro with the direct player interaction and immersive theme of an ameritrash game.  And it's actually playable in 2-3 hours!  On the negative side, the game takes up a LOT of table space, so much that I've had to pull out a second table just to accommodate a 4 player game (for comparison's sake, my usual table can fit a 5 player game of agricola albeit tightly).  And although the graphic design is excellent, the artwork, if not bad per se, is a bit uninspiring.  But overall, a current favorite, and a rating that could rise with more plays.

Update:  I've upped this to a 9 (from an 8).  A current favorite, and after 10 or so plays, feels like there's a LOT left to explore.  I just wish we could finish a game in under 3 hours lol.
