=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Includes the Expansions:
Eclipse: Rise of the Ancients (English first edition) (2012)
Eclipse: Supernova (2011)
Eclipse: Nebula (2014)

CRITIQUE OF ECLIPSE
Eclipse is a 4x (explore, expand, exploit, exterminate) game set in its own fictional universe. It includes plenty of exploration, expansion and extermination, but exploitation seems to have gotten lost in the shuffle. It plays anywhere from two to six players, which is always a plus for me, since I never know how many people are going to show up.

Setting up the game is a beast. First, this is a "hexes on the table" game, so if you don't have some sort of mat down on the table you are going to regret it. Second, there are so many different kinds of counters that it is a feat to stack them all up and keep them straight. Once you bring this game to the table (and it had better be a LARGE table) you are committed. There will be no easy transitions to other games.

Managing your alien species is a fairly straightforward Euro civilization game. You have three different things you are trying to advance: production, research and of course your economy. Each is handled exactly the same way: colonize a planet of that color, put a cube on it, advance that track. Easy. While it looks daunting, even non-gamers get the hang of this very quickly.

The thing is, once you expand a bit, you come into contact with other aliens who are also expanding their empires. This is where the game really gets interesting. I love the posturing, the diplomacy, the bluffing, the outright attacks, the backstabbing, and everything else that happens here. It is so well done. If you use the expansion you can even form alliances, making joint attacks against a common enemy.

Combat is handled using lots of dice, which I am not fond of. Still, without the randomness of combat the game would fail. Basically you are weighing the offense, defense and speed of your ships against those of other players, and it's nearly impossible to create a "balanced" fleet. The dice let you play out the battles fairly quickly to determine a winner.

I didn't like the way tech wasn't scaled according to the number of players, so I made a variant. In the original game, the fewer players the more random the tech draws became. Using a variant I get the same amount of randomness regardless of the number of players.

All in all, Eclipse is a great space-themed 4x game. It overstays its welcome a little, and there is a bit too much downtime for me to rate it a 10. Also, unless you play with alliances there is no catch-up mechanic. Once someone gets vastly superior ships they can simply own the board. It's not so much fun playing a game for three or four hours when it's obvious after 90 minutes that you aren't going to win.

Other things I really enjoy are the variable player powers, the modular expansions, and the fact that you could tailor the game to suit your group of players. I am happy to have this game in my collection.

RATING: 10
I've played Eclipse many, many times. I've just re-discovered this game after not playing it for a year or so. It's just so good! No other game manages to put this epic scale into a very manageable time frame. You have the constant impression of progress and at the end of the game, you really have created an empire! This game is just so extremely satisfying to play! 

This is the best Ameritrash-Euro hybrid on the market.

It's only problem, is a perceptual one: People on the Ameritrash side of the spectrum might find it too dry and restrained. People on the Euro side might find too random and combat-heavy. 

But if you are open for a good mix of the best of the two worlds, this is the game for you. Rated 10 in the honeymoon phase and very pleased to rate it 10 now (3 years later) and forever!

RATING: 6
Don't let others fool your: Eclipse isn't Twilight Imperium. While aesthetically similar, the strengths of each are radically different. In particular, Eclipse is mostly focused around economy and space combat, while Twilight Imperium has a much larger emphasis on diplomacy.

Differences aside, Eclipse would be an instant favourite if not for a single reason: I detest the technology draws. I tend to love games which force players to adapt, but I want that necessity to arise from the actions of your opponents, not because a bag forces you to do so.

It's a pity, because all the other elements are great. I love how you must balance your economy and how ship customization enriches combat. But I can't get over the super random tile draws.

Rating: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Enjoyable game with a lot of variability. After 4 2-player games (the last of which I finally won!), it has stayed fresh and intense. Balance is very good: there's strong weapons, yes, but you can counter with shields and missiles. You can build a fearsome armada or cause back-rank havoc with a swift fleet. Tactics in the game vary too: you can explore and try to avoid conflict, and technology and military allows you to build up even when you're geographically constrained. The hard part in this game is money management -- it's such a key internal struggle and one that's hard to master. Armed conflict is almost unavoidable, especially if you have a belligerent neighbor. But rarely does the game become so one-sided that someone gets steamrolled and eliminated. More often, mismanagement of money causes a player to undermine their own empire. Fun, but very long (2-3 hours) and tons of setup due to the numerous pieces.

RATING: 8.4
Rating should increase if my group can get this to the table. we can't because it takes too long.
I think 45 minutes a player is more correct. 

Explore,Expand,Exploit, exterminate



Somehow it feels like a more developed risk. Be in control of your civilisation (not only money but also resources) build up a decent army . And just go for it. You will have the most fun.

a comment about weight. despite that you have a plethoria of options how to play and each game will be unique . I think weight it is a medium light game.

There is not a single action that is confusing. (most difficult part are the missiles but that one 
even is a piece of cake to explain)

Despite it being a light game in my book and despite it's playing time. (you could argue it is too light for the time investment you have to make)
playing it was just great fun. 

So much infact that I'll acquire this on my ipad next time it goes on sale. And I probably acquire a boardgame copy for myself too. so I can pull it out even if that means just every two years.
It's totally worth it.

edit: So last week it was on sale on Ipad and I've played around 15 games now.
the second time was with my regulars in a pub. 
Explaining it was easy and it's nice that the Ipad does the bookkeeping. You lack however the physical feel of your workers. I made the mistake of conquering some areas I didn't have workers for to claim. 

About the lasers. Well they are really strong and adapting your playing style to cope with them is harder than to play it yourself. Or you should get the ancient three hull technology soon. 

there is a serious luck element to the game. what areas do you discover and what technologies come up. but they are true to the game. I'm fine with that. some people won't. This means that each game will be different and you have to adjust yourself to the chances.


the races put something new to it but more like in the human race I feel you are depending more on what technologies come up. You have to adjust your playing style accordingly to what your ships are capable of and there is a difference. this makes it more unbalanced. 


About player count well at the moment i really like the three player game that way everybody is involved with everybody. some multiplayer games and most gatewaygames fail at that number. 

Playing this game has got me interested in Twilight Imperium. 
Because the downside to the game is that the feeling of its lightness is confirmed in each play and the game is AP prone. 

The explore action and the right tile make it possible to win a lost fight. that's the biggest downside to me . It makes for an exciting powerswitch though. 

Edit:

I like this  game a lot. It is not the best game I have ever played and it probably takes too long for what it is. The time issue is somewhat solved by playing this on the ipad. I've played it a couple of times in a pub.

what I am telling here  is tha I am unsure of acquiring the boardgame version for myself as the Ipad implementation does a great job.

RATING: 9.5
Minimal, eye-pleasing artwork, lots of tidbits to move around. The first time is engaging. From the second time on, it gets more and more captivating. 
Solid mechanics that make sense. Despite its complexity it appeals to non-gamer video gamers. I've (sadistically) successfully taught it as a first boardgame to a few video gamer friends.
I love the relative quickness of the 2p game and I love the table-filling epicness of the 6p game.
Limited number crunching in the end for human calculators however it's not hugely prone to AP. Some hate the dice aspect of fights. I don't mind - even real fights are hugely governed by luck. All you can do is equip your self to the point where you're near sure to win, or you can risk it and jump in head first. 
Fun game, strongly recommended. This was my first game purchased after Monopoly and Scrabble. I didn't know what I was getting into. What a journey it's been since!

RATING: 5
UPDATE: Having played with house rules numerous times, stock rules feel more and more terrible. I probably won't agree to play stock eclipse ever again.

I've been watching the game evolve and managed to get glimpses of it while it was still under playtesting. I felt I have to get to try it, it looked so good. Now I own my copy, just played it for the first time and how do I feel? Well, its a mixed bag. I found a lot of very nice mechanics, a lot of interaction, and a nice balance between actions and option the players have. I also found lots of luck involved, with a bit more luck and a little more luck.

The dice rolling is obvious. Its hard to feel good when your opponent luckbags 1 out of 36 shot with one try against your 1 out of 3 with two tries. There is no good fix for this, so I grudgingly have to accept it. The hex drawing is another thing. Getting only ancient tiles at the beginning is huge disadvantage, and having to discard explored tiles even more so. Finding ancient treasures is also purely luck, and they are not in balance. Pulling the reputation tiles from the bag is also totally random. By sacrificing one interceptor, a player might earn 4 VP where the winner gets just 1 VP. Drawing the tech tiles from the bag to table is also completely random.

Game rules are very well written!

We have now played several games with the following house rules, and the game works IMO much better:

1) Each hex stack is turned upside-down. This lets every player know where they are exploring to. This basically kills the luck factor in hex drawing.

2) Instead of placing discovery tiles face down, place discovery tiles face up. This reduces unnecessary randomness and lets you plan how large risks and / or sacrifices you should be willing to take to get the tile. 

EDIT: Also the ancient tech tiles are way OP. Either remove them, or make the following arrangement: Put all discovery tiles face up on the table, and use them normally on discovery hexes. When a player is awarded a discovery tile, he may take tile of his choosing for the discovery tile stack instead of having to take the tile on the hex with the following restrictions: If the hex had one or less ancient ships, the player may take any discovery tile but technology. If the hex had two ancient ships or more, he may choose any discovery tile.

We have decided to rather play without the tech tiles.

3) Instead of drawing reputation tiles from the bag, put 5 reputation tiles face down on the table. After each combat, the combatant who gets to draw most tiles ("the winner") draws his from these 5, chooses one and returns the rest which are then shuffled. Then the rest combatants draw theirs in the same "most-order" manner. When everyone has drawn his tile, the tiles are restocked face down to 5. This greatly reduces the randomness in combat victory points, and rewards the winners of large battles.

4) Instead of randomly drawing the tech tiles from the bag, just make them all available at the start of the game (and ban hydran race), or make X/2 of each tile rounded up available at the start of the game, where X is the number of players (and still ban hydrans). 

5) Ships need to have a VP value at the end of the game. Perhaps small, but anything that prevents the optimal strategy for the last round: Get into as many combats as possible with all of your ships, to draw as many reputation tiles as possible, and usually decide who wins the game. EDIT: Starbases and interceptors ½ VP, cruisers 1 VP, and battleships 1½ VP, count ship VP's together, and round up.

With our house rulings, I rate the game at 8.

RATING: 6
First impression: quite interesting. We played (all rookies, 4 players) with only terrans so I haven't seen all the possibilities there is. But what I've seen so far is a resource-tech-wargame with extremely well-done resource-money upkeeping so now you don't have to use time to calculate all the costs. You can use all the time to PLAY (and wait for your turn). Our first game took 140 minutes to finish the whole game which isn't bad and I expect that future games will be faster. The biggest issue here is the last round battles where you can "do what ever you want without care what would happen in the future rounds..." 

Now after more games I have to drop my rating a bit (7->6): even with 30min/player there is too much downtime. There just comes situations where you know your next 1-2 rounds (and I don't mean turns), but you just have to wait quite a while when others are playing. Another issue here is, that the game is too stabile - this really needs more surprises and possibilities for interesting moves.

RATING: 8
A straight up replacement to things like Twilight Imperium or Starcraft.  Smarter, faster, funner, comparable scope and depth.  Typical space 4x board game (explore, expand, exploit, exterminate) with sharp, solid euro mechanics, up to par combat and quick play for the genre.  Hard to not recommend assuming the time & learning investment are not a problem.  The dice really hurt this game however.  Combat is very very random can easily result in a stronger force getting wiped by a much weaker force.  I guess you can pursue non combat strategy but it's a very big part of the play.  In a game where little is left to chance and accountability is high, combat resolution has turned out to be a big turn off for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is just an awesome game that I have been waiting for years. It is the game that Twilight Imperium failed to be. Right now, I think it is the best space conquest strategy game ever made,

It's a real 4X game, which is simple, flexible and expandable. The game really has an Euro-Trash feeling and it is the game that describe this style the best. It's really a combination of exploration and war game with a victory point and action system like euro games.

There is some issues that can be easily fixed without any conflicts. So you might have to make a few adjustments to get the optimal experience. But otherwise, it is a very good game.

-------------------------------------------------------

After playing a few games, the thing I don't like about it is that there is little player vs player conflict. You just build up indefinitely and then the game ends with little chances to fight.

This is due to the fact that you are always short in resources and the non-proportional actions force you to spend a lot of action to attack another player. So it's just easier to just stay where you are.

I intend to make a variant that will make the game more war oriented by adding more resources and making the actions more flexible.

RATING: 6
This space thriller is a nice resource managing wargame.  It has a innovative design mechanic of populating control discs and resource cubes. Very creative mechanism that I've not seen yet in any designs of the multitude of games I've played.  The game is long with four players but very good. RATING: 5
This is my favorite space/civilization game at this point in time.  Nicely streamlined, one can focus on the basics of growing a civilization with a nice touch of being able to specialize how one builds three different types of spaceships.  I sort of wish that there were more models of the bigger ships available, but I suppose that could create balance issues otherwise?  Each civilization also will generally choose to specialize in their techs for other purposes as well.  As you expand, maintenance costs increase dramatically and you also potentially have less actions as you claim more territories.  Make sure to have a strong financial base or bankruptcy can be painful (in the same way, don't fear bankruptcy).  This game is easily taught and learned and can be played very quickly - once everyone knows what is going on, this game could likely be played in 2 hours or so.

RATING: 8
After 1st half of 1st game (2 players):

+ Streamlined rules, with many details represented graphically on the components. Details that are not mentioned are easily found in the rulebook during play. Not many questions (in the 2nd rulebook printing).

- Less of a feeling of variety / epic-ness / flavor in situations than with Magic: the Gathering (dramatic card effects), Race for the Galaxy+first 3 expansions (many different tableaux), Glory to Rome (with the many possible building combos), or Netrunner (strong flavor of many card), or Agricola (with the numerous cards). Maybe things get richer in this department in the second half, when one gets richer, stronger (more attack opportunities), or with more people (alliances, etc.)?

- 1 hour per player for a *half* game on Vassal.

RATING: 6
Finally got to try out one of the new hotnesses of 2012. I like sci-fi as a theme, but sci-fi games tend to come in one flavor: long-ass epic space conquest. New innovations in sci-fi games tend to be: how do we make epic space conquest less long-ass? Now, as someone who isn't much into long-ass games these days, I appreciate the thought, and although epic space conquest kind of isn't my thing, that's largely because it usually came bundled with long-ass. Eclipse is a manageable game for me and I liked a lot about it. I like that the system kept records automatically. I liked that you could get some protection from other players, so you didn't have to fight everyone at the table if you didn't want to. In fact, I liked nearly everything about it. 

Unfortunately, what I didn't like, I didn't like a lot. I didn't like the wildly varying tiles. Every tile I drew at the beginning had aliens on it, which meant I was hemmed in right away. (Oh sure, I could have not placed those tiles and instead simply thrown away my action.) Because I wasn't getting all the goodies others were getting, it took me forever to build up my ships against the aliens so I could finally spread out, but by then I was hemmed in. My only neighbor had gotten lucky with his chit-pulls so he had massive ships -- even if I broke the treaty with him I'd get slaughtered. Meanwhile, another player was sending his small ships into suicidal battles just to get chit pulls. Against my aliens, I got a total of 6 points from chits. He got a lot more from this silly stuff. Luckily I used my tough neighbor as a shield and got monolith tech and thanked the stars other people were giving him a hard time. Also, the final turns consisted largely of people just buying tech they didn't care about for the victory points. 

In the end a lot of this worked against the game for me. I felt like I never really had a chance to play against the other players, as I first got slammed by the game. Then I saw as what got a lot of rewards was dumb losing battles and buying tech for no reason. That just wasn't too exciting for me. (To be fair, the person who won did so by actually performing epic space conquest, but I'm not talking about what wins, I'm talking about what's fun.)

However, there was nothing dealbreaking here, and I'm aware that the randomness of the tiles would mean that the experience would be different in that respect at least.

UPDATE: Another game endeared this to me more, though I still don't know about the victory chits.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Initial impressions: my opinions might be biased by the fact that Eclipse might be a bit too heavy for me, but if this really is the definitive 3 hours or less 4X game I am rather disappointed. Don't get me wrong, each aspect of the 4X is implemented to at least a decent amount and the pseudo action point allowance of being punished more and more harshly the more actions you take is quite mechanically sound, but it has all the game weight without the epic feel to back it up. For example, the races all have quite different stats, but as these mostly modify bonus points or how much of one resource you have over another there is an abstraction the thematic nature of these differences, making it feel more like you have different modifiers on an economic engine. There are a ton of different upgrades you can buy, but the economic hurdles you have to face to install them combined with the drabness of the tokens' appearance means the feel is more of the drab logistical aspect of spaceship construction rather than the cool spacefights. I do like though how the upgrades that are available and when they are available change from game to game. Finally, it is possible and potentially profitable to have it be quite difficult for other players' ships to come into contact with yours, making player interaction potentially quite variable (and if interaction is low this adds to the spreadsheet Euro-ness of theg game rather than the 4X feel).

The game also has an issue of throwing a ton of options at you without really guiding you on what you should roughly be doing. This would probably go away with repeated plays, but it would be helpful if I knew if taking that extra action would actually be detrimental to me.

Combat while more exciting than deterministic combat uses the outdated Axis and Allies system of try to roll sixes back and forth until someone has all their ships blown up, with priority rules that only sometimes have a significant impact. In explanation, nothing could be simpler, but in terms of execution it makes battles take forever despite having basically no tactics or strategy after the battle starts. For the point chips you draw after winning the battle, I have no idea why this is randomized and not just predetermined. I know that over the course of the game it probably more or less evens out anyways, but the only thing I can think of of what functionality the randomness serves is it makes it so you don't necessarily know who the winner is until the end of the game.

All the above may make it seem like I disliked the game, but I did enjoy playing it. It's more that it felt like half the time I was playing just another soulless Euro rather than an epic space opera. Enjoyable, but nothing to write home about.

RATING: 10
ANOTHER UPDATE.  Two more plays with four, and this game is now up there as one of my all-time favorites.  So much is going on, there are so many decisions to make, and each decision provides a lot to mull over.  The economic engine at its core, and which cleverly forms the basis for how many actions can be taken in a turn, is genius.  The granularity of the techs is perfect.  Your decisions about what techs to research truly affect the course of your game.  Finally, Eclipse provided one of the most cinematic, stand-up moments our group has ever had in gaming.  Pure gaming gold!

UPDATE. After two more plays, one with three and the other with four, my group is still getting the hang of this game.  The biggest learning curve has been with combat.  We still are having some difficulties being able to predict how well our fleets will do against our opponents.  The result has been a couple of games where there is not a lot of combat until the end.  The result has been two games that feel much more like an engine-building euro and less like a true 4x game.  But I suspect that we might be playing a bit too tentatively.

After one play with three, it's too early to rate.  So far, so good, though.  There is a lot going on and a feeling of engine/civilization building.  Maybe it was the fact that there were only three, but in the beginning there was very little tension, although it did begin to mount near the end.  With three there is the potential problem where two players duke it out while the third explores to his heart's content - and the victory.  But that concern might be allayed by some balancing mechanisms, like the alien powers and what appear to be some decent bonuses for attacking (and even being involved in a battle).

I'm enthusiastic about the game.  There is a lot to explore, which should be pretty fun.

RATING: 7.5
[microbadge=5][microbadge=419][microbadge=5389]

Eclipse would be very easy to describe as Through the Ages in space, and with a map.  That might do a disservice to the complexities of Eclipse, but it's also bluntly accurate.  The cube system from TtA works well here, supplemented by the addition of "bureaucracy discs", which are spent to push the governing and progressive limits of your empire.  It is possible to lose the game around turn 5 or 6 out of 9, leaving you to carry out the motions of a futile game, but experience can mitigate this.  The alien abilities are all unique, and all worth trying once.  They must be especially commended for not making Humans just the vanilla race; they more than hold their own with their logistic speed and trade efficiency that you'll find yourself missing when playing any of the aliens.

RATING: 10
The best 4x game out there.  The game features a simple economic system, simple exploration mechanics, technology developments, discoveries, and customization of military ships. RATING: N/A
My first introduction to the 4X genre, and is very fun.  Played first at my first Con on the Con.  Was really impressed, then after seeing other games thought since the combat was dice-rolling it wasn't really all that great and there were better games (like Hegemony, newer and therefore more expensive).

Since Cody got it, though, found the dice rolling to make fights interesting, since without you can just use math to determine what will happen, and often fights wouldn't happen anyways, but with dice you can still get some "eh, fuck it, let's see what happens moments."  And dice, despite meaning some people will have to just sit back and rest while other people do combat, DO make for suspense.

30 min/player play, and part of the 4X genre: eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, eXterminate.  Despite being heavily strategic and looking foreboding, found I can explain the basic play pretty easily, and then the rest comes along as you play, so beginners can take to it without a lot of trouble.

The problem is we've had 3 fights now with Cody, 2 with me and the last with Henry, and we've decided that it's just unhealthy for him to play. I've bought it from Cody to play with others and replaced the GameTrays gift I got him for it with a Tiny Epic Galaxies that will hopefully go a lot better for us.

At some point, though, it just became so foreboding to get this large box off the shelf, with the table space needed and mental steeling and such. Did get to play once more with Abigail, Hannah, Caitlin, and LeeAnne on the family cottage vacation, without conflict (and very little dice rolling conflict even), so that was nice.

Sold on the marketplace here with everything else for $115, that covered some shipping, including the Game Trays I had gotten Cody and Broken Token resource trays I'd gotten for myself, so not too much a loss for the single game I played owning it.

RATING: 7
Rating after 3 plays. Need to play a couple of times closer together so I have a better idea of what I want to do in the game, and to work out how much I like it as some of my initial optimism has been slightly undermined. The exploration seems the most fun part of the game, but there is a great deal of luck involved here and twice I've been on the receiving of that and struggled to get myself back into contention all game without success. The battles too can be a little underwhelming... I did not see anything in the way of fighting until the last turn or two, when a host of dice were rolled in what were slightly disappointing climaxes for a game of this length. I think ultimately Eclipse might fall between two stools - it wants a euro-style economy management mechanic and diverse tech trees to mull over on the one hand, and in stark contrast a wild ameritrash dice-fest for the ship battles. A bit of luck in combat is easier to justify than the luck in the exploration tile draw, IMHO, because when exploration goes badly for you the result is a slow death that you can see coming almost from the beginning of the game. Update: the 3rd game with 5 players was more enjoyable with a close (1vp separating 3 players!) finish. It did take a very long time though for what is ultimately not that deep a game, and there was significant downtime (up to 10 minutes per round) towards the end.

RATING: 9
Eclipse is a rare game in that it appeals both to fans of mechanic-driven Euro gamers, and to fans of theme-driven games. The sheer number of bits included in the game is impressive, but even more impressive is that fact that all those bits manage to have a use, and despite that, the game is fairly straightforward to play.

One thing I love about Eclipse is that way that new technologies come into play: while you can reasonably expect to see all of the rare technologies in a game, depending on when they come out can have a big impact on the strategies that players adopt, and this in turn means that each play is fresh and interesting.

The play time is good for a game that feels so epic, although it's still long (purely in terms of the time it takes to play - it doesn't feel long). This means it probably won't get as many plays as some other games we have, but it's the sort of game I'd play every time there's an opportunity to.

RATING: 10
The best 4X game. The rules are quite intuitive and the game is relatively easy to teach. First turns are fast as players mostly eXplore new sectors to gain better resource (money/science/material) production. Researching, building and upgrading space ships, destroying NPC Aliens to gain bonuses or more points. A player can win through combat and conquer or by expanding his empire and acquiring Monoliths or by researching. Usually it is a combination of many factors. The game has 7 different races which play differently.

Our games tend to take 45 mins per player. The game tends to slow down towards the end as more and more agonizing decisions have to be made. This is the game that we can talk for hours after the game what went wrong, who should've done what and what to try in the next game.

Works well without the expansion and the promos, but all of them are highly suggested if you enjoy the base game and intend to play it more than 10 times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I was apprehensive about buying Eclipse. There was so much hype it was difficult to discern the truth in either the excitement or criticism. However, after multiple plays with varying numbers of players I can confidently say Eclipse is the best space 4X on the market (Twi Imp lacks true eXploration and lasts too long for what it's worth). And with the ship blueprint rules, Eclipse is the board game that best captures the feel of Master of Orion. The only thing Eclipse lacks is a thematic end game. The game ends due to number of rounds and victory is determined by a point tally. Eclipse also doesn't offer divergent paths to victory (like victory by conquest, politics, or technology). All of your accomplishments just sort of aggregate into points. But those are minor disappointments in an otherwise amazing design. Let me address some of the criticisms: Are there dice in combat that, even with all the technology available to control probability, sometimes have unanticipated results? Yes. Are missiles extremely powerful in combat without the right technology to counter them? Yes. Can your initial attempts at exploration result in resource stagnant hexes that make you envy your wealthy neighbors and force you to adapt your strategy? Yes. Can the random discovery of ancient technology lead to temporarily unbeatable ship designs that other players must slowly build up to the point of defeating? Yes. Are those "shortcomings"? I don't think so. These are the kind of disparities expected in a 4X game. And most of the criticism seems to be generated by people not expecting those aspects of the 4X experience. In short, Eclipse is a game that has lived up to the hype.

RATING: 8
a very well designed game, with a little bit too much randomness to be perfect.

Gameplay:
+ very solid and clever, but still highly intuitive mechanics
+ a lot of possible actions and decisions
+ a lot of exploration
+ extremely cool resource mechanic
+ EXTREMELY cool ship-upgrade mechanics
+ intuitive combat, which is strongly decided by how well your ships are upgraded

- a lot of the mechanics used in this game are determined by randomness: 
 * system tiles (determine planets, enemy encounters, victory points and discovery tiles) 
 * research tiles (determine what research upgrades are available each round)
 * reputation tiles (determine how many victory points you gain for combat)
 * discovery tiles (give you random boons. can be extremely advantageous, if you are lucky enough to draw the good ones in the 1st or 2nd round)
 * and of course the dice (determine combat outcome)
- if you are unlucky with all the randomness that is happening, it can very much ruin your game experience. while all others around the table can do multiple things, you may only be able to do 1 or 2 actions per round due to lack of income. this is simply not fun to play


Components:
+ high quality components
+ a TON of stuff in the box
+ the game comes with baggies

- the plastic ships are ok, but definitely not as cool as those of Twilight Imperium or Forbidden Stars for instance

RATING: 7.9
Highly enjoyable. Decent blend of theme, player interaction, brain-burning, strategy, and management just before becoming "epic" size game. It's like TI:3-lite with some improvements minus the politics. Being able to design your own ships is incredibly satisfying and makes combat very interesting. The resource management system (almost exactly like Through the Ages) works great for Hex-based empire expansion and felt "real". The more you push your empire per turn, the more costly and it can become to other areas of your empire. The "reaction" actions after passing is a nice touch removes any sour tastes from being ambushed by opponents who wait till your done activating to attack you. Overall, this game is top-shelf. Nothing about it felt clunky, it moves at a perfect pace, it's not possible to fully "Euro-game" the final rounds, you're going to have to take some chances against an opponent with randomness.

RATING: 8
Space exploration games with a combat element always run a big risk of being unbalanced, and the designers of Eclipse upped the ante by including rules for changing the capabilities of your fleet, an enticing idea that has crashed and burned horribly in countless predecessors, be they boardgames or computer games.

But right from the start, I felt in good hands, because it was clear that this game has the heck developed out of it. Actions, colonization and sector control are admirably handled as a seamless package, and although the combat system looks a bit clunky at first (the ancient chestnut of d6 hits on a 6), the ship upgrades soon introduce interesting rock-paper-scissors dynamics between the various fleets.

Together with a non-epic playing time, there is quite a bit of glitter in the initial impression this game made, and I’m looking forward to more plays and finding out whether there is solid gold behind the glitter.

RATING: 3
Wow, I did not have any expectations about this game, so I wasn't really let down, but I thought it was terrible.  There was way too much luck for my taste.

Luck sources: explored tiles, discovery rewards on new tiles, available technologies, dice in combat.

In particular, I did not like the dramatic swings of power that could happen with a single discovery tile or tech that has only appeared once so far in the game.

Playing a 2 player game taught me two important things.  
1. how to play the game.
2. that I don't want to play the game again.

I realize that having more players would create additional dynamics due to the player interactions, but those would not replace or mitigate the randomness from my perspective, so why bother.  I also realize that this is a popular type of game and I do not begrudge those who enjoy it, but I am here to reassure any dissenters that you are not alone.

1 play, 2 players

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A fun space civilization-building game. The worker placement mechanism and the feel that you cannot do everything you want makes this game remind me of Agricola, in a way.

It is lengthy (about 4.5 hours with 5 players) and, if you make a bad move early in the game, you will almost surely be quasi-eliminated from it, as you will be locked inside a poor system with few resources and no chance to fight back. You will lose for sure.

This means spending at least 2.5 hours doing just a couple of actions per round (as you will be short of resources) and hoping to survive.

It is not so much fun to play in this condition. All you can do is try to undermine the game of the player who was responsible for caging you. He will eventually reduce you to dust for it, and that's it. 

Not to mention luck, which has to be seriously taken into consideration: it can decide who will have the upper hand in the early game and, if the chance is grabbed by the lucky player, they will put a good advantage up and march to victory for the rest of the game.

Despite these drawbacks, this is a rich-flavoured game in which there are a lot of paths to victory and, therefore, a lot of strategy going on. The theme is also very good.

Update: the rate have risen a bit after I noticed that the semi-elimination can be mitigated when playing with 4 or less players, as people won't be as aggressive.

Update: played with 3 and 4 players, and indeed it was not as aggressive: with 3 players, got overwhelmed by Planta. The fewer the players are, the stronger Planta and Draco get.

The 4-players' game was much more balanced and fun: Eclipse is best with 4.

Update: the Rise of the Ancients makes the game MUCH better. Upgraded it to a 9 after playing a 4-player game with it.

After learning the game, it gets more and more interesting. There is so much that can be done!  and it's really interesting to analyse strategies with other players (after the game is over). Must be played with similar kind of gamers, though. (2014)

RATING: 4
Initial rating is an 8 after 2 plays (down to 7 after 4 more).  Good game, not great.  Way too few races for extended replayability.  Nice system, well organized and executed, not terribly original in any single way - the meshing of mechanics is very good and different.  But, the game is heavy on luck, plays are 'same-y', and the play feel is far from 'epic' as some claim.

The game reminds me of others like Through the Ages, Nexus Ops, and TI3.  All good games.  This game seems to be a good game - but no, it isn't THE game, just another good game that will get lots of play time.   So, don't believe the hype and don't waste your money for an over-priced copy, wait until the reprint.

First comment before playing - the typeface for headings in the rulebook was poorly chosen.  I find it distracting and harder to read.  Sure it is nifty, who cares?  Rulebooks should not add artificial things for aesthetic purposes only that then hinder clarity.  The rulebook lacks an index.  So, again, far from a perfect rulebook, but still decent.

The flimsy giant sized cards are a minor issue also - the cubes slide around since the boards do not lie perfectly flat.

I would say the art is weak, the pieces average to weak.  If the game were average it would not have anything going for it at all.  Thankfully, it is an okay game.

One last note - for our 4P games, eclipse takes 2 hours, TI3 takes 3 hours.  TI3 is far more interesting.  At this point I doubt I will ever play Eclipse again - for our 4P group TI3 plays in a comparable amount of time.

RATING: 9
I was really excited to play this game after looking at "let's play"s and reading reviews, but I was concerned that my girlfriend (we play mostly 2p; wtb friends that game?) would find it too slow or complex.  I was dead wrong; she loves it.  This is not the slow epic space-drama that some of the reviews and videos might suggest.  There is plenty of complexity and variability to make it replayable and unpredictable, but it never feels slow.  My previously non-gamer girlfriend will be talking about our last Eclipse game (base game only for now) for several days after playing.  

Even when you lose, it doesn't feel like you were robbed, or subjected to undue abuse by the RNG-gods; you just ponder the journey (laaaaaame), and where you went wrong.

This is a brilliant game, even for 2p.  It's extremely accessible for casual 2p gamers (contrast: my gf refused to play even a 2nd game of Twilight Struggle), but not the least bit oversimplified for the foam-core-building, miniature-painting meeple of the world.  Strongly recommended.

RATING: 7

I think this game is a bit overrated (though some components are really fun!), and it cannot replace something like Twilight Imperium in any way.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Everything about this game is random, random setup, random explore tiles, random sciences, and random combat. Random, random, random.  I am not a fan of random elements in games usually, but I love Eclipse.

Eclipse manages to control the each of the random elements. In combat, you are rolling to hit, but you can influence what you need to roll, and how many dice you are rolling. With the science tree, you are pulling many of them each turn, so it is unlikely that NOTHING good will be available. In exploring, the tiles differ by where you are exploring. While they added random elements to everything, you can't blame losing on them.

At Eclipse's heart, there is also a beautiful economic engine which you are manipulating in order to boost your production and economy. It is one of the few games that I would recommend to both Ameritrash and euro players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Twilight Imperium (lacking the political aspects) in 1/4 the time.

This game is extremely elegant.  Things you would have to calculate in other games are handled automatically by the design of the game parts.

The rules are well written but long.  With a person to explain them- you can start in 30 minutes.  On your own, perhaps 45-60 minutes.  But no major ambiguities or rules holes found after two plays with different people.

The theme is the game is the theme even tho it is 90% a euro.  The war game / dice aspects may come up a few times in 3 hours.

Luck is a factor and bad luck can surround you with ancient warships or empty sectors.  

This was a very satisfying game to play.

It will run 3 hours-- about 30 minutes per player.  If you get an AP'er, it will be longer of course.  6 new players and 1 Ap'er ran 5 hours to read the rules, play for the first time.

RATING: 9.9
Best game of 2011 and one of my favorite heavy games.
Fixes many problems of Twilight Imperium, some of the fun parts are gone in the process but it's easily worth it because Eclipse can actually be played by an adult, you only need a free evening (2-5 hours,depending on player count) and not whole day.. Components are good quality and replayability is great, especially with expansion.

2-Player Comment:
* Follow the race suggestions of rulebook. Rise of the Ancients is highly recommended for 2p for more (and more varied) Ancients to battle. Eclipse is decent 2p game, great with 3-4, best with 5-6 and 7-9 is occasionally fun (but long!). I'd rank it 5-6>7-9>3-4>2. Setup is the worst part, it's almost as long as 2-3p game.

RATING: 9
It is true, this game is great!

When you play eclipse, you really have to think through your actions, because, everything you do will affect your oponent attitude. In the game you are playing against real human not some clunky mechanics. If you are he leader in the game, then there are thing others can do. 

They can team up against you, and send their fleets in your homeworld. However, there are a lot things to manage, and player elimination is really unliklly (at least not until the final rounds. 

This game is about negotiation and geopolitics. It is really elegant combination of war/economy/area control/euro combination. However, it also create story as ameitrash games.

My negative things about the game are the issue of game lenght, which can be also 5-6 hours (45 min per player). However, there is almost no down time and time just fly by when you play. But better consider to play this with (3-4 players, because 6 could be to long)

Other issue is size of the game, you need to have enormous table, for it. The game take some table space.

And it might be a bit complex for new boardgamers, and teaching takes about 30-40 minutes. But when it is done, the game is really elegant and intuitive.

It is an excelent game, and even if you won't like some of the mechanics, you will remember how this game made you feel. The game doesn't end with final turn, but stay live in your conversation several hours after the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Whilst this is a decent enough, relatively fast-playing 4X game, I do have some issues:

The things I really like about the game are as follows:

1) clarity - the rulebook is excellent, and the mechanisms are all designed to show the information you need in the situations where they are relevant. The system of wealth versus earnings is very simple, but brilliantly executed. More games could learn from this;
2) for a 4X game, it's really quick;
3) there are tough decisions every turn;
4) the traitor mechanism: the last player to break a treaty loses 2VPs;
5) modifying your ships is cool. I can have tachyon drives on my cruisers;
6) the flow of play during the action rounds is quick.

The things I don't like are:

1) what the hell are you doing for the first five turns? All that happens is you explore and try to build your tech to a level where you can compete with the Ancients or with other players when you meet them. It's fine, but it drags a bit;
2) because of this for a 4X game, combat doesn't tend to happen until later. If you fight early, you've used actions you could have used to research, so you'll be sorry later;
3) the traitor mechanism - the last player to break a treaty can't form another until an opponent breaks a treaty and takes the card. Whilst I can kind of understand the reasoning, this is pure artifice;
4) hey, wait a minute - I've discovered Tachyon Drives. I've can put them in my fighters and my cruisers, but I have to WAIT to take another action before I put them in my big ships...? Unless I have nanotech, of course;
5) the system of discounts for tech has no relevance to the type of tech being researched - for example, computer types do not all fall within the same tech-type, therefore there is no benefit to researching a Positron Computer (+2 attack) then a Gluon Computer (+3 attack). This is counter-thematic, if not plain idiotic;
6) combat is slooooooooowwww;
7) the turn order mechanism is rubbish.

Exploration: it could be argued that real-world empires don't all start on an even footing; nevertheless, games are a construct. A little imbalance is fine with me, but I can see how one player's situation might be greatly disadvantageous. This is slightly mitigated by the fact that you have a some choice where you place - or whether you place your tile at all. It's an OK solution, but I think I'd prefer an open galaxy with a Settlers-type mechanism of placement to mitigate advantage. I'm not saying specifically a Settlers mechanism - just something that allows a bit more starting balance.

Technology: I agree that, given that actions are limited by cost, there is no reason to artificially limit the tech types by chit draw as no race will ever be able to research them all. This is another artifice because it feels like, rather than a directed research spend, these future 'advanced' civilisations are basically discovering new technologies by lottery. One solution, given that there is already a discount system in place, might be asymmetric technology costs for the different races to encourage diversification. In fact, this is a good idea. I claim this idea for a future 4X game that I'm now going to design (and Dave and others at the club can tell me what I'm doing well and what I"m doing badly).

Combat: I don't so much mind the initiative idea, but the combat just takes so long - and I think that the system of I-fight-you-first-then-you-then-you-then-the-ancients means that someone who has a huge fleet can be beaten by someone relatively weak because they've had their fleet mashed by all the previous combat. It should be simultaneous. As far as the mandatory combat for entering someone else's territory, even that of an ally - this has been a known mechanism since the first Sid Meier Civ. I didn't like it then and I don't like it now, but I think it's perfectly reasonable given it's now a convention, otherwise there might be very little combat in the game.

Reputation: this is a bit artificial too, but it's better than the chit-draw system that scores at the end of Louis XIV. At least you get to draw a number of tiles and keep one. This mitigates the randomness a little, and I quite like the fact that some of the scoring is hidden just to add that little frisson of tension. Of course, it could be argued that this is a way of ramping up tension which should be inherent in the playing of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fascinating empire builder, with so much going on, yet so easy to handle. Nice, organic economic engine balanced just right, and kept simple. On the second half of the first game there was hardly any need for the rulebook anymore, because of the effort put into usability. Plenty of routes to victory even with playing just the human factions, but other selectable races introduces yet some more significant variety. Great game, all around.

The only thing I'm not entirely in peace with is the constricted, nine turn limit, which I can totally understand from the game design point of view, yet almost every game ends abruptly and sometimes unnaturally. Someone finally launched his mighty Armada ready to crush everything, nobody can stand in its... oh, sorry, times up; the dude with the three monoliths won. Again, I understand the reason behind it, but can get a bit weird thematically. Wouldn't change it though, you should adapt to it, it makes the game better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
4X-themed space empire-building board game with hexagonal tile placement sub-mechanics. As is the current trend, the game combines some euro mechanics with a lot of ameritrash theme and dice rolling. The most innovative feature is the empire expenditure mechanics where the same tokens used to select actions are used to claim space regions, and every subsequent token used entails greater costs in the turn upkeep reckoning. This means that every action taken is much more expensive for expansive empires. 

The problems with the game: It relies too heavily on chance, and an unlucky start situation might make it very difficult if not nigh on impossible to catch up; or alternatively, fortunate players could easily win because of being lucky. Battles are dicefests of the kind more usually seen in Games Workshop products. Runaway leader could be a significant problem. It is to geared toward conflict with few other realistic avenues to victory. And as all games of the genre, slooow: our three-player game took some 200 minutes. 

Recommended to fans of 4X games and for Twilight Imperium players that wants a similar though perhaps less involved game with more luck that plays less slowly.

RATING: 9

If you want the best space empire game that covers the 4Xs without making you feel like taking a nap between turns, skip TI3 and get Eclipse.

Never again. Just say no to Eclipse.

I think it's best I just copy/paste some comments about my most recent play:

6 players, each race with its own benefits/drawbacks, each player with 4 types of ships, each with its own unique stats all on top of the randomness of the way the techs come out, and each player having their own techs...it all became too much information to try to keep track of, particularly in a game I'm not enamored with. I made an alliance early on with my neighbor who had the race (red) that starts out with a lot of money. He ended up with a booming economy and had his ships decked out to be essentially unstoppable. In his late-game rampage he looked over at my board and said "you're not a threat" and moved on. I suspect he didn't know my racial "+1 VP per colony" power. Combined with my racial "explore twice instead of once" ability means I should grab as much territory as possible and hold onto it. Which is what I did. That's fine, that meant I just needed to focus on my own stuff. I was ready to be done at about the 90 minute mark, and the game ran a little over 3 hours. Red was the military powerhouse, and while he was out warmongering White came and stole a couple of his colonies in the last round. This cost Red 5 points and allowed me to win by 2. I didn't care.

This game is just too long, too much to track with a theme I'm indifferent to. I understand the appeal, but it's not my thing. The randomness of the dice, the exploration tiles, the available techs and the bonus tiles on top of all the stuff to track makes me feel like the outcome isn't really in my hands and I sort of tune out. For example, in my early game explore actions (where you draw and place a tile to reveal new areas) I got all areas with resources as opposed to alien ships, and the bonus tiles I got early on were two +8 money tiles. This allowed me to take more actions, and the resources meant I had more stuff coming in. The blue player, in the meantime, kept drawing tiles with alien forces he'd have to fight before claiming the resources. I think the game has a bit of a snowball effect going on, a runaway leader issue. The way the tiles come out can elevate one player and hammer another. Some players will have a problem with this, some will not. I'm the former.

Again, I can really see the appeal of Eclipse, but it's just not for me. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Eclipse is basically your usual resource management engine builder, which is fine for an hour or so, but this has exploration and combat added to align with the space 4x theme. While these aspects make the game different from, say, Goa, they're also the most annoying--i.e., random--parts of the game, with lots of dice chucking and random tile draws. Unlike other epic conquest games like Struggle of Empires, which also has all sorts of upgrade options along with random elements to combat and movement, there's no central mechanism that makes this game different (like alliances). It's just develop, move, fight, develop, move, fight, etc. I like a good space theme as much as the next guy (The ships are sweet!), and I suppose there's some nice variety in trying out the different races. But overall I haven't gotten enough of a wow factor out of this game to feel like it belongs in my collection.

RATING: 6
One of the coolest and most epic games that you can play with 9 players (including expansion here) within a relatively short time (approx 4.5 hours).  The biggest downside, particularly with experienced players who know the tech, are missiles.  Specifically, missiles combo'd with gluon computers.  Sure, you could build up somewhat of a defense against this.  Interceptors, of which there is one tech like this.  Perhaps shields, though even these, with enough dice/computers on the other end, aren't gonna help you.  But really, you need to spend the entire game building up this defense - getting the size of your army large enough to take the initial blast, moving large fleets into strategic locations so there aren't any small battles and, during the large battles, you have some survivors.  All of these take turns and aren't as high a rate of return as the gluon computer/missile combo. 

So, get missiles.  

I still have a blast playing these large games, but always, always, always, I am left unfilled at end of game once the final large battles are fought and the missiles reign supreme.

RATING: 8
iOS and analog versions. 

This is a great game of 4X. The combination of special empire abilities, exploration and building an empire come together really well. The combat is simplistic but fits well in the game. I'd give Eclipse a 10 but deduct points for:
-0.5 for setup, breakdown, playing space requirements and artwork. There is a lot of components in the game and the playing footprint requires a big table. Players really need to stand up to see whats going on sometimes and access the common tech track. The artwork is a bit drab and the use of pink and brown for resources adds to this.
-1 for downtime, which tends to limit the game to no more than 4 players. I haven't played 6 players analog but would imagine it would be much worse.
-0.5 for teaching and learning the rules. Although the rules are relatively simple and intuitive it is a lot for new players to take in and new players will get pasted by experienced players.
-0.5 for risk of player elimination. A player can bankrupt themselves accidentally and there is significant risk of being exterminated from map reducing their game to just going through the motions until game end.

The iOS version eliminates the setup, table space requirements and has much better artwork so I give that version a 9.5.

RATING: 8
My friend's favorite game. This game's most unique feature is the ability for you to upgrade your ships. In most games you can buy upgrades but upgrading ships in Eclipse works by first unlocking the upgrade via research. Second building the upgrade and placing it on the your ship's layouts, then building the ships. You upgrade the layout of a ship, and then it will effect that ship type every time you build them. 

In addition to ship building you have exploration, fighting NPCs, and unique abilities per your starting race.

RATING: 8
Played another 5 player game.  Although I like the ideas behind the game.  I stand behind my previous statement.  I don't care how skillful you are and how you've outfitted your ships or maneuvered them.  If you can't get the correct dice rolls you are screwed.  Game takes 1 hour per person PERIOD!  Which means I would never want to play with more than 4.  Too LONG, requires too much table space, and bad luck can screw you over.  Can't rate this higher than an 8/10.

This is a very good game!  I like the Euro-style economy that you have to build, and how slick the mechanism to track the progress of that economy is.  However, I'm not sure if the skill/luck ratio is quite right for a heavier game of this length.  My opinion may change with more plays.  Due to the heavy time investment, I'm not sure how often that will be.  Our 1st play took 6 hours with 6 newbies, and the 2nd took 4 hours with 4 who played once before and 1 newbie (add to this 1 hour for setup and rules explanation).  I can see this game eventually taking less than 3 hours with 4 people, but only if everyone is fresh with the rules and technologies available.  And this just won't happen in our group, because we never play the same game more than 3 times in any given year period.  As a side note, it also requires a LARGE table to play.  

Got a chance to play my first game last night with 6 players. I got both bad tile draws and was connected to a militarily heavy neighbor. Finally got exterminated completely in the last round of the game, because I could never grow my economic engine due to bad tile draws (couldn't get rid of my cubes to expose higher income levels) and was constantly fending off my neighbor military giant. I would have had a chance if other neighbors came and took some pot shots at the military giant, but everyone just kept to themselves. Afraid to instigate the wrath of the military giant. In the end the military giant won the game with a score of 41, and second place was 32. So I had a total blast getting hammered for 5 out of 6 hours that the game took. I should have just thrown in the towl half way through the game and saved 3 hours of my life. Unfortunately, I won a major defensive fight against the military giant giving him a black eye and bruising his ego. All it would have taken is 1 other neighbor to attack him at this point to give me some breathing room. But everyone else was keeping to themselves building up their empire. It didn't do them any good in the end.

Second game went much better, but I did make a mistake in the end game with which technology I upgraded on my ships(plasma missiles intead of plasma cannon), and forgot about the 'ship pinning' rule.

RATING: 4
Después de mi primer contacto con Eclipse le iba a endosar un Rejected con todas las de la ley porque la partida entró en mi Top 3 de las peores experiencias lúdicas que he tenido junto con Twilight Struggle y Circus Maximus pero no me podía creer que el juego fuese tan malo y aburrido con todas esas alabanzas y hype. Así que me armé de valor y le dí otra oportunidad. El juego me ha parecido aún peor pero por lo menos no me dieron ganas de cortarme las venas como con la primera partida así que le quito el Rejected y se queda con malo a secas por aburrido, aleatorio y descompensado.  El juego consta de 9 turnos en los que en los 3-4 primeros solo sacas losetas y la colocas en el tablero. Y lo peor es que marcarán lo que puedes hacer durante el resto del juego ya que te darán unos u otros recursos, azar puro y del malo. Durante los siguientes 3-4 turnos coges avances tecnológicos y los aplicas a tus naves mientras te enfrentas a un par de naves neutrales. Los avances están hiperdescompensados y no salen todos y de algunos no  habrá para todos así que vuelve a salir el azar a relucir. En los turnos 8 y/o 9 te das con los otros jugadores en unos combates que o están descompensados y te crujen de un plumazo o es una tirada tras otra hasta el hastío de lo largas que son y carentes de emoción. Y siempre igual, partida tras partida. Si el juego durase 45-60 minutos vale pero ¿3-4 horas para esto?. Va a ser que no.

¿Hablamos de la edición?

Los "tableros", he visto hojas con mayor gramaje.
No sabía que se podían hacer naves espaciales feas. Reto superado.
¿Hablamos de la edición española?, ¿si me compro un juego en inglés e imprimo las reglas tengo una edición en español?. Pues eso.

RATING: 10
When I fist played Eclipse, I had this weird experience of playing a game that I SHOULD have loved, but I didn't. I gave it a second chance and I also felt something weird about the gameplay.

Then, and finally, I gave it a third chance... with a totally different group and... VOILA! That was it. The game was ultra fun this time, and I realized that this is not a game for everyone... and certainly not for every group.

For me, this game is a blast, but I don't understand why so many people is in love with it.

This game has it all for me. I enjoy it a lot.

RATING: 8
One of those games that seems amazing if you don't know any better. Player elimination can happen early and really sucks. The game is really, really long. Needs at least four to play well. Other than that, it's a great game of epic space combat. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A very clean civilization-and-war game. My introductory games at 3p (all Terrans) were not quite as fun as a huge 6p free-for-all with one alien each.

The more I play it, the more I appreciate some truly genius design elements. For example, the reputation tiles system encourages (a) fighting; (b) fighting early; and (c) not fighting too much, all with a simple set of rules.

Another example: the economic system allows you to have a large or small empire without overly penalising one or the other. A large empire can give lots of income, but is also costly to maintain, and it all balances out.

While the hex map can be a little bland (I appreciate actual maps), the ability to create chokepoints with wormholes is another great design element and adds lots of replayability.

I'm in the camp that thinks Plasma Missiles are overpowered. Yes you can counter them, but nothing else requires a specialised counter - you can beat everything else just by doing your own thing better. If the PM player is not countered then his fleet is simply invincible.

RATING: 8
First impression (5 players): Always a sign of a good game that rules are rather simple - for this type of game - but they offer plenty to play around with. Eclipse feels to be a mix of euro-ameritrash gameplay, rules are pretty euro being rather "clean" but the gameplay with all chaos, randomness and gameplay narrative (or perhaps the table talk it encourages) feels more like traditional american design. There is plenty of randomness in the game as battles (dice), exploration and tech "tree" (tile draw) but it feels there is just a healthy amount of it. Sure, some games you most definitely will lose due to a bad luck and in tight games you can always blame luck but it also enables some of the most epic comebacks that I feel are part of this type of games.

I like how player board design makes it easy to keep track of production, upkeep and discounts. Although it feels a bit too fiddly to keep all those pieces there. If I would have to name one specific part from this game I really love it would be how you can customize your ships in Master of Orion -style without making it too much of a hassle. It sounds like a gimmick but it works very well and adds one more layer to (a threath of) battles.

Overall the game feels very good and not least because it seems to be playable in 2,5-3,5 hours with experience with right people (with my regular group it seems to take 4-5 hours no matter what) but still offers a feeling of a galactic civ game with all the necessary pieces in there.

RATING: 3
Too much randomness.  When exploring, you draw random hexes; early on, they can be manned by hostile aliens you can't defeat, making you waste precious actions.  Have that happen a few times and you fall behind.  The combats are still, despite all the modifiers you can tack on, driven by dice.  The weird scoring mechanism for combats makes it seem like a lot of space battles, especially at the end of the game, are best negotiated in advance!  But worst of all, the true deal-breaker -- the random victory point chits (value 1 to 4) you pull out of a bag post-combat.  The winner of a game this long should NEVER be swung by tiles drawn randomly from a bag.  Unacceptable.  Will never play again.

RATING: 9.5
Salo had some Eclipse comments that were so spot on, all I can do is copy them, and add my comments:
[q]* Tech Tree: random tech draws give variability between games. It's fairly open what you can develop, but if you have researched a tech in a particular field already, it's cheaper to develop new ones in the same field. The result is a simple yet elegant tech tree that nudges you in certain directions but is not too restrictive; highly efficient.[/q]
You can gain efficiency in building up with primitive techs first and getting to advanced techs later, but you don't have to do that. If you do get advanced techs first, you can't use the full discount on the smaller ones. Pretty ingenious. The randomness of the tech tree creates quite a bit of variability in the game, apart from the explore  and discovery tile draws. It also makes turn order fairly important since you might want to pass first in the hopes a good tech comes out.

[q]* The Resource System: using Through the Ages's idea of removing cubes on your player board as you expand your empire without that earlier game's fiddlyness; a wonderful design solution to the problem of bookkeeping.[/q]
I've worried over the fiddliness of [thing=25613][/thing] for quite some time, and I cannot develop a more efficient system of tracking economic impacts. Increasing population has several impacts in TtA: consumption, happiness, and new population costs. Similarly, expanding your population in Eclipse impacts your economy, science, and materials. It may be fiddly to setup, but it completely streamlines the remainder of the game. No need to count planets or anything.

[q]* Building your Ships: my favourite part; you can upgrade your own ships so that each player's ships are individual and each player can develop their own military doctrine, so to say. This is all done in a way with ship blueprints and tiles that removes any form of bookkeeping.[/q]
This is the cool part of the game, and there is a lot of room for strategy about what to get, when to get it, and how to best attack whoever. that's it's tied into the economy, tech tree, and victory point system makes it even better.

[q]* Action System: a brilliant method of action selection, whereby taking actions and expanding use the same resource (action disks--which like the other resources you remove from your board, exposing the increasing upkeep costs as you use more disks), thereby balancing how much you can do and how much you can expand. [/q]
Another neat innovation. I can't think of another game that does it quite like this. The larger your empire, the more your actions cost you. A smaller empire can actually afford to take as many or more actions simply because they have fewer influence discs managing their sprawling empire. This forces some nice choices about # of actions and  rate of expansion. However, this is somewhat mitigated by the bankruptcy mechanism, which I am not sure I care for. I take that back. I am [i]sure [/i]I don't care for it. Bankruptcy should have a harsher penalty, IMO, such as losing permanently losing an influence disc, or something more drastic. You should be able to use it as a way to get influence discs back on your board.

[q]* Incentive to Fight Early On: the method of awarding VPs for combat (which you draw from a bag and choose the best) give you an incentive to attack early on, as the chances are that at the end of the game only the low value chits will be left.[/q]
Related to the reputation VP scoring, this neatly solves the turtling issue that most 4x/economic games suffer from.

[q]* Expansion: the explore action is cleverly handled so that you quickly expand, bringing you into conflict with your neighbours very soon. There is no long build up before you get your empire onto a war footing.[/q]
Also, the wormhole system allows you to try and manipulate avenues into your territory.

[q]All in all, a wonderfully designed game that is a lot of fun to play; you will end up thinking the game a lot after playing it.[/q]
Agreed!

RATING: 7
Eclipse is a good game, although it could take a very long time with more than four players. It also requires that everyone is very organised and rather careful not to scatter the components: do NOT play with someone who is careless when rolling dice. Also, you need a very big table.

Positives:
Eclipse captures the theme beautifully.
· The economic mechanisms are intuitive, and present interesting challenges.
· Once players "get" the game, play is quick with little downtime.
· The breadth of options encourage experimental play.

Negatives:
· It is intimidating to some newcomers, and a challenge to teach.
· Poor luck in early turns can probably be overcome, but might easily be discouraging.
· The sheer amount of space required to play. No pun intended.

We will need to see how fast players become with greater familiarity. At present I am a little worried that Eclipse may take too long, or be too heavy, for frequent play. Much like Dominant Species or Antiquity.

RATING: 8
Cela fait un moment déjà que l'on m'en a parlé de ce jeu, et qu'en bien :-). Voici donc Eclipse un jeu de type 4X Sur fond de thématique SF. Le moins que l'on puisse dire c'est que le pari est réussi. Esthétiquement, je le trouve beau pour commencer. Après au niveau des règles, il a fallu tout de même pas loin de 45min pour qu'un expert en fasse le tour sans trop rentrer dans les détails de la pratique sachant également que son auditoire est habitué de ce type de jeu. Eclipse est donc selon moi à ne pas mettre entre toutes les mains : de par sa richesse et sa complexité, je doute fortement qu'il intéresse réellement des joueurs autres que des passionnés de jeux et de SF également.
De ce que j'ai pu voir les races me semblent équilibrées (à part une en particulier) et c'est un réel plaisir de faire ses actions au travers du mécanisme bien rodé qui nous est proposé dans le jeu.
Les combats m'ont également beaucoup par leur simplicité et leur efficacité : il s'agit de lancer de dés mais ceux-ci sont conditionnés par des équipements sur les vaisseaux. Cela rend la partie toujours plus attrayante.
Parmi les points qui m'ont moins plu c'est notamment le plateau de jeu des joueurs sur lequel "glissent" trop facilement les pions. C'est un peu facile à dire de dire ça avec 4 ans d'écart entre la sortie de chacun des jeux mais je préfère largement le plateau de jeu de Scythe dans lequel les pions s'emboitent parfaitement sans que ça glisse partout.
Viens ensuite la durée du jeu qui me semble assez aléatoire selon comment va se dérouler la partie mais qui reste relativement assez longue.
Ces parties qui trainent en longueur (même si on ne s'ennuie pas) et le fait que le jeu ne soit pas très accessible font que celui-ci est assez difficile à sortir. Je lui mettrai bien 9 mais pour moi ce point fait la différence pour lui donner la note de 8

RATING: 8
Two plays as of Nov 2011. One 3p and one 6p.

Excellent game - it's astonishing to be able to play a full sweeping 'space opera' type game with six players in 3 and a bit hours.

That said, Eclipse still features most of what makes this kind of game Ameritrash, even though the rules are streamlined and fairly 'Euro-ized'. Dice rolling a-plenty, luck of the draw when exploring - there is certainly a healthy dose of luck in the game so if that kind of thing turns you off then this might not be for you.

If you don't mind the AT style (which I don't), then this is a hell of a game and well worth picking up. Certainly this runs circles around Twilight Tedium, which takes about 2-3 times as long and doesn't do nearly as good a job of encouraging aggressive play instead of turtling and empire-building.

RATING: 8.5
規則:
*對應版塊跟資源放到供應版，回合標記放在起始格，科技版塊丟袋中抽人數*2+8塊，所有區域版塊根據背面洗勻放置，III根據人數2/3/4/5/6人使用5/10/14/16/18塊，名譽分數版塊丟另一個袋中，探索版塊洗勻放一旁
*地圖中央放中央版塊上面放防禦系統，根據人數放對應的起始版塊到對應位置，隨機起始
*每個人選起始版塊跟個人版(如果用不同種族倒序開始挑)，並拿一個顏色所有配備跟3個殖民船版塊還有一個總覽卡，所有資源格放滿方塊，最右邊三格露出，影響力軌放滿圓片(多的先留著)，資源柱放在對應的起始資源格，然後擺一艘小船一個影響力圓片(到中央)跟三個資源(到對應星球上)各一到起始版塊
*遊戲進行9輪，分數高獲勝，平手比三種資源和，每輪分四個階段
1.行動階段 由起始玩家開始輪流放一個影響力圓片到行動區，直到所有人pass，行動6選1
*先pass的拿下輪起始標記，總覽卡翻面，之後輪到仍可以做較弱的行動(上限都一次且不能靠科技增強)
*自己行動階段隨時可以翻面殖民船來放方塊到對應星球，灰色可任選，有星的要有對應科技
>探索 從你有船(該版塊必須比對手多)或有影響力標記的版塊相鄰空格選一格做，翻對應位置版塊並選擇是否要放，棄掉就結束，放的話邊界半圓要剛好相接(有額外科技可以不用相接)，板塊上放置對應探索版塊或古代戰船，如果是空的可以馬上放影響力標記上去
*放影響力標記上去可以馬上拿探索版塊並選擇要拿獎勵並丟掉還是拿2分留著，探索版塊堆用完棄掉區洗勻在抽
>影響力 拿最多兩塊影響力標記場上或影響力軌的放到只有你船的地圖版塊，你的影響力軌或是跟你有影響力標記相鄰(要半圓連結)的空版塊(沒其他船)，並可翻回最多兩艘殖民船
*兩個半圓相鄰兩個版塊才相通
*如果影響力標記離開版塊，場上的資源方塊也要回來，如果是灰色資源星回來不一定要回當初拿的軌
*外交 兩三人不使用，兩個版塊上面有相鄰的不同玩家影響力標記可做外交行動，互換大使並拿一個資源放在大使上，同對玩家只能外交一次，個人圖版有大使數量上限，之後如果破壞外交，大使互回手且背叛的要拿扣兩分的背叛版塊(跟之前擁有者拿)
>研究 拿一個科技版塊放在對應顏色欄位的個人圖版最左格，付左邊金額減掉該格上的減免，右邊是至少要付的金額，科技不能重複
>升級 最多拿兩個升級版塊放到任一艘船上蓋掉上面的版塊，該船能量要夠支付，船一定要至少一個引擎，基地台不能有引擎
>建照 造最多兩個船或建築，付對應資源
>移動 可最多移動3艘船(可同一艘3次)對應其移動力步數，如果經過有敵人版塊至少要留跟該版塊上數量一樣多的船才能繼續通過
>反應(PASS之後的行動) 可做升級 建造 移動 但是都一次
2.戰鬥階段 版塊從數字大結算到數字小，由最後進去版塊的開始結算，如果該版塊有你的影響力標記，你最後結算(古船跟防禦系統都最後結算)，最後進入的都算是進攻方
>戰鬥根據優先值結算，平手防守方先攻，每艘船上的方塊符號丟對應顏色骰子，1不中，6命中，2~5可會根據自己船跟敵方船上的裝備做修正，方塊中的星星幾顆代表有幾點傷害，每艘船起始1滴，每個圓形加星號增加一滴
>船上有傷害但沒爆就先用紫色方塊算，爆炸的先由敵方拿走，戰鬥結束在還
>打中立由其他玩家代骰，中立先攻擊可以打爆的最高血，在攻擊不能打爆的最高血
>戰鬥順序 飛彈先結算一次之後進入第一次遭遇，選擇撤退的放到該板塊邊緣(要到的版塊要有自己影響力標記且沒有敵軍，全部結算完進行下一次遭遇，之前撤退的就撤退成功，結算到只剩一方為止
>沒船後如果還在敵方領土可擲骰攻擊資源方塊，飛彈不行，每個成功的攻擊移除一個回到該玩家圖版的棄置方塊區
>戰鬥結束後根據結算結果抽對應個數名譽版塊(上限五)，留一個蓋著放自己圖版，有船撤退成功就不能抽戰鬥的
>如果船在的版塊沒有其他資源方塊可返還該影響力標記，然後放自己的上去
>最後所有傷害標記移除
3.維持階段 
>可馬上啟動剩餘的殖民船，但不能移到有敵軍的領土上
>金錢軌扣行動軌拿資源(負的就付資源)，不夠付可用其他資源轉或是拿場上的影響力標記回來直到夠付，還不夠就輸了
>科技跟材料收入
4.清理階段
>根據人數2/3/4/5/6抽4/6/7/8/9塊科技版塊放供應版
>行動區影響力圓片放回下方軌，資源方塊在棄置區的移回對應軌
>翻回所有殖民船跟總覽卡，回合標記前進一格
*遊戲最後分數有
>名譽版塊跟大使分數
>版圖有你影響力圓片的分數
>探索版塊每塊2分
>遺跡在你占據的版塊
>科技軌分數
>背叛卡扣2分
>特殊加成
**兩人遊戲建議不要使用Decesdants跟Plants兩個種族

***SOLO***
*起始板塊在中間，直線放一塊蓋著的I跟原本的中心板塊，探索起始板塊相鄰的放II，其他放III，III板塊沒上限
*科技 起始有三個發展科技，然後開12個科技
*拿一個人類面板並放在自己的下面只露出飛機設計圖，放一個interceptor bay tile(擴充科技加一血)到基地設計圖一血位置，每個基地戰鬥是會派出兩架小飛機
*回合軌2468放小飛機，357放基地，warpgate科技板塊(SOLO自創的)放9
*敵軍升級卡要自製，起始時做一次I升級(抽一張I放對應升級裝備到所有單位的空格)，第三回合做II升級，5/7/9回合則做一次II一次III升級，抽對應等級卡片執行對應升級，引擎只能被新的取代，照表格數字最小的被取代，小飛機至少有一個武器，其他則至少要有一個非飛彈武器，引擎升級卡要擲骰，並放該卡對應面到圖板上，敵軍沒有能量限制
*2468回合開始時擲骰決定進攻的飛機組合，地點也擲骰看攻擊卡，如果沒限制到一個地點就重擲，第二次仍沒限制到則符合的你選
*戰鬥由你是防守方結算，如果戰鬥完敵軍仍在該地點則該地點所有東西回手，板塊翻面並放對手的影響力標記，結束會扣分，只有蟲洞科技可以穿越該板塊
*戰鬥抽名譽板塊個數減1，上限4
*敵軍攻擊順位 還能攻擊的(飛彈發射的先跳過)>攻擊最高的>可毀滅的最大飛機>最大艘
*遊戲過程中可以付對應回合的資源(任意組合到對應數量)來移除該群飛機，放一個大使板塊到你的圖板
*357回合敵軍殖民，擲骰順時鐘從I板塊繞著你的起始板塊數(第二圈就往外數)，空格跟你沒殖民的才算，數到該位置放敵軍基地跟外交官還有資源星上去，每個採資源的上面都放方塊，7回合額外放一基地跟紀念碑，上面原本的板塊都不動
*攻擊殖民地 先打完殖民地才打原本該板塊的古代艦隊，基地都會有兩艘小船出來防禦，資源要清掉才能放你的
*可跟該殖民地建立外交，同外交規則，只是只有放一個產資源方塊到上面，背叛一樣扣兩分，之後可減免3點買warpgate科技的花費
*第9回合才能買wrapegate科技，花費扣除所有名譽板塊分數跟大使分數，每個敵軍大使扣3，還有科技軌上的減免，該科技允許行動階段把任意飛機跟基地放到外面，戰鬥階段進攻敵軍主基地，敵軍為防禦軍
*最後計分，每兩個敵軍基地存活下來的部隊扣兩分(你的每個大使可少扣一分)，每個有敵軍影響力的地點扣3分
***多人合作**
*每一個玩家就加一個敵軍，進攻跟殖民都沒別各自結算，殖民的大使只能有一個人結交，最後科技每個人要自己研發
