RATING: 7
Nice 4x implementation, coming in safely within the usual evening timespan, with the VP system encouraging non-turtling, but plenty of points on offer through building rather than combat. Meaning there's lots to explore. You've got three currencies to manage, so the first choice (which may be inflicted on you via the luck of the exploration tile revelations) is whether to concentrate on developing your research, build or extra actions capabilities. Basically you want all of them. There's a fair bit of luck in the combat system so getting tech upgrades to alleviate that luck is important if expansion and combat is your strategy. Like most in this genre, falling behind in the tech tree and the arms race is probably a death knell, so even through the game disguises it well, it only takes a turn or two of being knocked around and you're off the pace, so it's as ruthless as any. So you need to be ok with that aspect to truly enjoy it. I'm not sure I'm quite there yet because I'm a turtling pacifist at heart, but I definitely want to explore the game further to fully understand it.

RATING: 4
What I like:
- Cool theme, exploration, plastic ships
- Clever mechanics (influence/actions, colonies, etc)
- "Reasonably" short (my first 3p game was under 2.5 hrs)

What I don't like:
- The game is geared around fighting each other
- Definitely more complex than I prefer
- Randomness is pretty high for such a long/heavy game

There is a lot here, so I think the 3.5 weight is justified. 

It reminded me a bit of Tempus, where the world is just small enough that you *must* fight each other, whether you want to or not. But where Tempus had a lot of aspects that I really liked, Eclipse doesn't. Aside from the annoying focus on military, Eclipse isn't bad, but it's not great either, for me.

RATING: 9.5
After first try:

It takes a lot of space and a lot of time to setup. Mechanics are very good. I like the similarities with Through the Ages use of population. Also like the dual use of action/influence discs.

Tech advancement and exploring is more or less like many other 4x games. I like the non-linear tech advancement system. 

Fighting is less than many other 4x games (at least in our first try) and that's the way I like it. I'd like to see a 3x game (without fighting) with all the rest from this game. 

Played it several times now and still like it. Some races are easier to win with (Planta & Draco) than other especially when the opponents don't know how to hurt them.

We actually managed to crash a four player game after three rounds. One human player went bankrupt and another player was so small he didn't want to continue squeezed in between Planta and Draco, so we ended the game.

RATING: 8

It's really an "apples and oranges" situation.

All things being equal, I'd play TI3 first.  But rarely are all things equal and Eclipse is a good alternative.

RATING: 9
7 Plays - Brilliant game. It's played over nine rounds. During each round you explore, research and build combat ships. Usually during the last 2-4 turns people will be ready to duke it out with their fleet of uniquely equipped ships, with the final combat rounds usually determining the overall winner. Great set of different themed races (6 different alien races, and a human race = 7 total). Quite a lot of different parts to setup and manage though, and you will need a large table to play on. Looks great however, and also a lot fun. It is possible to get smashed the whole game though, which can be a little demoralising if you don't handle that sort of thing well.

RATING: 8.5
Based on one play: I really enjoyed my first play. You build up an army of ship and you upgrade each type of fleet with research. You also explore and sometimes fight (mostly near the end of the game). One frustration is the exploring as you may draw a tile that does not fit and lose a turn and action doing so (turns out we played this rule wrong). Actions cost you money, getting more expensive each time and you need science to perform research and material to build ships. A lot of cool mechanics that work great together with a nice theme. Definitely would play again (this time the advanced version where each race has a different specialty).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is one of my most played games and was one of the first I got into after getting into the hobby a couple of years ago. The theme really clicked for me and the people I mainly game with and we were all used to this style of game from playing video games like Masters of Orion.

It can be a long game, around 45 mins per player in my experience but it is worth the time as it really does a good job of creating a 4x feeling with a heavy slant towards economic management. But you also get to explore, build fleets, research technology and upgrade your ships. The latter being one of my favourite aspects of the game, I really like to see the different kinds of builds I can create as well as the builds that other people come up with, then pitting them against one another or the Ancients.

I'd estimate around 50 plays of this (I haven't logged them all) and I am a little bored of it now; the last few games I've played just haven't excited me like they used to. It is still overall a great game but I have found that the experience can be dulled by players making odd choices like not going after the person who is clearly in the lead and going on a mad revenge binge when someone attacked them, even though the original attack was a reasonable tactic. 

Even taking what I have just said into account. If you've got the right group, enough time and a big table I would thoroughly recommend this.

There is also way too much luck for a game this long (e.g. exploration in the first round).

Expansion is fantastic, as just a handful of Rare techs cans be used to counter missiles, but not nerf the missile player entirely. Love the neutron-bomb negater.

RATING: 2
Initially I rated this game a 9. It was a euro version of Twilight Imperium, right? It felt fun, battles near the end of the game were interesting, ship upgrades and research were a nice touch. So why do I rate it so low now? It feels rather random and combat isn't really that interesting. You roll a handful of d6's and hope to hit on 6's or possibly lower with computers. This can go on for quite a while, while the other players sit and watch. It doesn't have any of the flavor of Twilight Imperium as all the races are slightly different, but not really more interesting.

Rich typically get richer and you can also get rather screwed over by not getting the right tiles when exploring. The game feels too repetitive and by round 6 or 7 I feel like the game should be over with. The rating may increase slightly with 2 players, but for now it stays put.

I'd much rather play TI3. Eclipse with 4 players takes about 2 hours and TI3 with 4 players takes 3-4 hours. I'd play it any day of the week over Eclipse.

Optimal Player Count: 6-9 > 5 > 4 > 2 > 3
Plays well with all player counts but the more, the better. Also, if playing with 5 or more, use the 2 pawns to play simultaneously.

RATING: 10
Space opera/Empire management 4X game or Masters of Orion, the boardgame. 

I think there are several good things happening here. The resource management is clever and streamlined so the game doesn't feel fiddly. Combat is quick and filled with drama, like it should, and very well integrated with the ship design. 

There's enough variability to keep each game unique, the alien races introduce some flavour and they seem fairly balanced. 

Luck is present in reasonable doses but good play usually overcomes bad luck.

Eclipe feels epic, like a good space opera 4X empire management game should feel and yet it still manages to play in a very reasonable amount of time. A 4 player game usually take us two and a half hours. 

I think this may very well be the long sought after Holy Graal of the genre. Great work, formerly unknown finnish designers!

(12/2013) Traded.  Here is why.  This is not the 4x situation that I believe in.  The game design is constrained in certain ways and I feel it is a detriment.  The game ends up being more about what you couldn't do than what you COULD do.  This is a fact of life in economic games but I will thank you not to make my 4x games into economy engines.

4x designs should be open in terms of possibilities, sandboxy, and strategic.  This is closed, economic, and tactical.

RATING: 7
Edit 4/23/13:  Rating raised from 4 to 7.  I was wrong, so wrong.  I see the light.  Long story short:  Never play a game for the first time with someone who does not know the rules.  That said, while I like how the game is centered around trying to have the best economy (after now enjoying these types of games having played and loved Le Havre), I wish Eclipse had true diplomacy (voting, rules changes) and more flavor such as missions and hidden objectives.  Trying to explore and conquer in the most economic way possible is a fun brain burner, but I wish there was a little more flavor to the proceedings.  My issues might change the game too much which is fine, but it would be nice to at least have these more flavorful options and make the game close to a 10 (the resource management is oh so very awesome and elegant, the game just needs a little more oomph).  The first expansion doesn't look to fix my qualms, but adds more (now mobile) enemies to fight which does add more flavor in 2 player games which is appealing.

5/21/12: Elegant resource management, but overall boring.  Fun to anticipate new upgrades (if you can even get them from a random tile draw) and build up ships, but just as you build something substantial there's a few boring battles and the game ends.  Something missing here, needs more flavor like missions.  As far a theme and being ranked as #1 thematic game on BBG -- the game is bland and boring.  I wish I had the Kool-aid to drink that everyone else has so I could enjoy this "fun" and "thematic" game -- as it stands now, the game is neither.

RATING: 8
A good multiplayer space 4x game.
Works well with large numbers and easy to finish in an evening (less than 3 hours). Combat and interaction is encouraged, although it is possible to be cut off or isolated.
Not as dry as something like Space Empress 4X, which is a game that I like but does not quite engage me.
The tech research availability works well enough in the context of this game where it is more a case of what research can you do for a single confrontation of perhaps a few years than any feeling of guiding your race across the centuries. Think Babylon 5 - you just get the five years of the show, not any of the thousand years of history that got them to the show.

RATING: 9
Played the prototype.

Quite easy to learn for a gamer. You get the feel of the game and it's easy to develop valid strategies even as a first timer. Soon you end up very much drawn to the game. It took us 4 hours to play as many were newbies and we were 6. 

The game involves a low amount of downtime as the players take actions around the table. 

The actions are quick and don't involve furious anal-paralysis.. Most of the time you can choose among a couple of decent actions. The order of the actions you take during your turn doesn't matter cause theyre available to you no matter what actions the other players choose.

It's more of a long-term strategy game, which i like very much. If you get involved in a galactic war you have to think short term too.

RATING: 9
Wow.  Epic 4x in a playable length of time.  I haven't found a mechanism I don't like -- customizeable ships, the way it handles the economy, the techs, diplomacy:  all good.

My only (minor) quibble is the turn order deal; like Railroad Tycoon, you can randomly benefit/be hamred if the person on your right/left passes unexpectedly (depending on if you wanted to go first or last).  Easy fix though -- have two sets of turn order chits available (one for marking your order on the current turn, one for choosing when you go on the next turn), and when you pass you get your choice of the remaining chits.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I enjoy a good resource management game, but it's a rare treat to be able to enjoy it in space with cool space combat. The tiles are beautiful, and I love the way you drop cubes from your board onto the plants, revealing better incomes from the resources the planets produce. Very clever and thematic! I like how the tutorial race (humans) are completely playable against the advanced races on the flip sides of the board. I also like that even though the game uses dice for combat, you can alter your ships with computers and shields to alter the probabilities of sending and receiving hit rolls. The upgrading ship blueprints and grabbing technologies is really fun and satisfying.

Spending actions on bad explore tiles can cause you to fall behind early, which is perhaps unnecessarily random. I'm always tempted to house rule it and say look at 2 and pick one or something of that nature.

There is also a technology called Missiles which allows players to get one first strike ahead of normal combat, but then they don't fire again. When stacked up, they can create warpy battles.

Additionally, with more players the game can become difficult to keep track of who is in the lead in victory points. Most points in the game are public knowledge, but many aren't easily visible by other players, particularly if you sit across from them on the map. This game could really use a VP counter of some sort.

:star: Art, Iconography and components functional
:star: Clever or interesting mechanisms
:nostar: Reasonably low downtime between turns with mildly AP players
:star: Multiple plays stay interesting
:star: Low or mitigatable luck elements
:star::star::star::star::nostar: Raw enjoyment

[b]Good expansions:[/b]

RATING: 7.4
Eclipse is often described as a euro game disguised as a space opera, be that as a compliment or criticism. I expected smooth mechanics, low randomness and a less than great battle system.

The gameplay is smooth: using future income to take turns, which lets you increase your income on various tracks balances out beautifully. And because you only do one action per turn, the game is not hugely AP inducing. In a 6 player game you do have quite a bit of time to think about your next turn while waiting, especially because the turns of the non adjacent players (in the galaxy) don't really matter for you, unless they take a research that you wanted.

Researching and upgrading ships is fun. Some low cost technologies  (e.g. improved hull) seem straight up better than more expensive ones. The battle system is not as bad as i thought. It's still dice chucking with no decision making, but the ship upgrading mitigates this sufficiently. 

Randomness in other parts of the game was the biggest issue for me:
- random tiles during exploration, which can hugely affect  the early game
- random research tiles, in combination with galaxy tiles and the ressources on them.

For example: you draw a 2 planet system, one of which needs advanced mining, there is an ancient ship on the tile. You can't beat the ancient ship yet and there is no advanced mining availble until 2 hours later. Your opponent draws a 3 planet system (1 advanced). You draw a one (white) Planet system. Your opponent draws a 2 planet system. 

This is exacerbated by the alien races. Theoretically you can choose your own strategy, but the races change the value of your actions (as they should) and the relative value of each planet type. Your strategy is limited by the ressources you find, and if these don't line up you end up thinking: "I wish I could do these cool things my race can do, but I can't."


Other random thoughts:
Snowballing in economy (random) -> upgrades is likely impossible to overcome.
The art is alright. Looks impressive on a desk.
The galaxy feels small.
Time is often spend searching through bags and piles of upgrades or rolling dice instead of making decisions.
Some actions are much better/used more often than others.

All in all I like the game and see its upsides but the underlying randomness made the game a slight disappointment. Without the randomness the game would still not feel as exciting as I wish it would for the length. There are better economic games, better area control games and maybe even better economic area control space 4X games than this.

RATING: 8
I was very impressed by my initial game of Eclipse. This is an excellently designed game that had plenty of tough and interesting decisions at every turn. The variable player powers of the various alien races ensures there is plenty of different paths to explore in this 4x game. 

I was also very impressed with the player boards which alongside Terra Mystica are some of the best game aids I've ever seen. Both do a great job of communicating a lot of information to the player quickly and easily. The other real genius in Eclipse lies in how you get to customize and outfit your ships with the various technologies in the game. Want to make a bunch of super fast ships armed with missiles? Go for it. Want to make something that is super tanky and can take tons of hits? All yours. Want to just load up on guns and targeting computers? Can do that too. And all the options seem nicely balanced such that one can viably take all of these various paths to success. 

I'm looking forward to getting to play this again, and may even want to buy this for myself, even though the long playtime and fairly heavy ruleset means I'm not likely to play it very often. I can see this rating rising with recreated plays as well as I learn more about the depth of the game. 

Overall though this is an impressive design that manages to capture the epic feeling of a space 4x in a nice playing time.

RATING: 10
Boy, where do I start... best 4X game I've ever played. I just love the diversity, the setup, the configuration and how the game unfolds in time. You have to optimize, you have to react. It's a great conflict game, carefully designed and balanced. There are different ways to win and you cannot determine your strategy at the beginning, as the world will change around you. You are forced to maximize your score, but also to fight. At the end, it's still uncertain, who gets the best score, which I think is great. Love the game, even when I'm losing. 

It has a lot of components, but you'll quickly find that you don't have to be concerned with all of them. Great mechanics and game interface makes it very easy for you to have all the information you need. With proper storage solutions (baggies, GMT trays), game setup and operating is a breeze (though putting the game back in the box still takes some time). People complain about quality, but I don't see it. Yes, ships are plastic and they're might be not very detailed, but you look at them from some distance and it's easy to distinguish what is what. Maybe the starbases being the cardboard token and not plastic ship is a little bit confusing. Tokens are very informative and easy to read/understand. Player mats are a genius at work example. Only the race graphics feel a little uninspired and flat (especially the constant-PMS human ladies).

RATING: 7
Played this Essen 2011 hype monster only once. It is a neat game but all in all, it is not as good as people make it out to be, at least, not for me. The theme does not interest me at all. Whenever people moan about the same old generic fantasy mumbo jumbo, like orcs, elves and dwarfs, I get excited, I am a post-Tolkien man through and through. But talk to me about wormholes, plasma guns and planets and I start snoring sooner than you can say 'Bones McCoy'. 

Apart from that, I found that the game lacks interaction, where is the trading, diplomacy, sweat-inducing negotiations, alliances, laws that bind you you to do certain things, interactive victory conditions (apart from wars. Most of the time, I found that people just build and dwell on their little separate boards in Agricola style and I general don't like games where people have their own boards, that spells multi-solitaire like nothing else. 

Also, just like many 'old' wargames (Game of Thrones / Risk), this game has no catch-up or balancing mechanism in place for players who get left behind. Unlucky tile draw in the first few rounds ? Tough cookies, you are probably out of the winner's race for good. Two players decide to crush the last player and eliminate him from the game ? Call your grandma, your coming home, but the game does not help you at all. How about bonus chips for whoever has the lowest in science, resources and money each turn ? Something like that would cut it, so the design, while elegant and polished is outdated in my opinion.

On the upside, I do like the playing time, rules are clear and the design feels polished so that the flow of the game is very good, when compared to similar games such as Twilight Imperium.

If you love space games that are a tad dry and Euro, this is for you. To me, it feels more like space tax return than space opera, too much work, not enough fun.

RATING: 7
There are a few things that really bug me about this game that make it go from exceptional to just really good. 1) Hidden victory points - I have no idea who is winning and what I should do about it. This is fairly common in Eurogames and I am generally not a fan of that. 2) Exploration is highly luck-driven. Both games of Eclipse I've played, one player drew a set of bad hexes and really was at a disadvantage. 3) Nearly impossible to win without combat - the game gives too many victory points for combat vs. other aspects. 4) Lack of true diplomacy/trading. The diplomacy that does exist is more a "if you attack me, you'll lose points" swap. Player cooperation and negotiation is pretty limited. It's still a fun game, but I think it could be much better.

I have not played Twilight Imperium yet, but I have high hopes that it's going to be the space epic I am looking for. I have a high level of tolerance for long games, so that's not going to be an issue.

RATING: 9.5
THE space empire building game that you always wanted games like TI to be (but somehow those other games always let you down).

A realistic playing time of 30 minutes per player once you know the rules, a tech tree, military expansion being one way to win but not the only way (and military defeat being something that it's perfectly possible to recover from), the usual Euro agony of wanting to do 5 things but only having 3 actions left this turn - this all adds up to a very good game.

My favourite game from Essen 2011.  The first time I played it (taking about 3.5 hours), I immediately reset the board and wanted to play it again. (The second game only took a shade over 2 hours).

I've played the game over ten times so far (pretty unusual for me), and can discern only three flaws.  I could live without the dice rolling for combat (largely because my rolls are almost always indescribably bad).  The plastic space ships are mediocre.  And it needs a big table (even 3-player takes a fair amount of space).  But these are small flaws, and in every other way the game is fantastic.  

Increased my rating after having logged more plays.

RATING: 7
This is a quite interesting space-themed civilisation game - with all the expected technologies and battles and exploration and so forth, and also various different alien species to play with different abilities (and drawbacks!). Perhaps the most interesting feature is that, using the technologies you acquire during the game, you can customise your own ships, to allow them to move faster, have better weapons, superior defences, or meet whatever other needs you require for them. There is also a very interesting economic system - aside from science which you need to research technologies, and materials which you need to build ships and a few other things, there is money, which you need to pay more of the more actions you take in a turn, as well as the more tiles you control. This is nice and thematic, you feel that you have "overstretched" yourself, and this limits the number of actions you can take without going bankrupt and knocking yourself out of the game.

Despite all these nice features, though, this isn't a game I've played many times, nor one that I am particularly keen to play again. Playing it, while interesting, is just not all that fun an experience (although it certainly isn't bad), and it does feel very dependent on luck - not only dice rolls in combat, but also what tiles you draw (this is probably the most consistent frustration, you desparately need money or materials-producing planets and can't find any, or you find ancient ships everywhere which you don't yet have the ships to be able to safely take out), and how the new technology tiles come out. I can understand why there is such love for this game here on BGG, and as I said it is a very interesting design, but for me personally it is not a game I can fall in love with.

RATING: 4
Vielleicht das (auch von mir) am meisten überschätzte Spiel der Jahre 2011/2012. Meine – freilich nicht repräsentative – Erfahrung mit dem Spiel zeigt zwei Hauptprobleme, die sich auf eine falsch oder nicht konsequent getroffene Design-Entscheidung zurückführen lassen: Die Entwickler waren unentschieden, ob sie eher ein Wargame oder eher ein Eurogame abliefern wollten - und haben sich dann tendenziell doch für ein Eurogame entschieden. Zwei wesentliche Konsequenzen: Zuviel Ökonomie (obgleich mit intelligentem Mechanismus, aber das kann Ökonomie grundsätzlich nicht retten) und zuviel Zufall (eigentlich ja kein Charakteristikum eines Eurogames): das Ziehen von Victory Points, die Zusammensetzung der Galaxis, der zufällige TechTree, die Kämpfe. Als ein kleineres Problem kommen eine teilweise hohe Downtime und wenig ausbalancierte Alien-Rassen (ich sage nur: „Orion Hegemony“) hinzu. Vielleicht werden einige dieser Mängel mit der ersten Erweiterung abgestellt oder abgemildert.

RATING: 6
(Based on one play so far)

Eclipse has a lot of things I like in a game. But it does have problems in the randomness and luck.

Like any exploration/resource game, early development can snowball in future turns. And so, following some poor exploration, I found my economy almost completely tanked by turn 3, making me a very clear "4th player" in our 4 player game. I launched a war on the top player, just to give me at least a slight chance of doing something in the game. All I really did was allow the eventual winner to turtle his way to a very easy win.

I'd give the game another try, but I do feel like there is something severely lacking in this game. I don't know much about the expansions, but I'm hopeful that they help address the issues I see.

RATING: 8.4
(+) Develops interestingly 1: the way space exploration plays out with the 3 different sectors, stimulating players to first go outwards and explore and when they are more powerful to grow towards each other in center space. The central tile with the strong elders' station also brings in an interesting dynamic.

(+) Develops interestingly 2: the way tech upgrades are aquired is nice: a limited amount of possible technologies, and a rather dynamic tech tree (a technological leap costs more tech points than slowly building up, but it is possible if necessary). Technologies feel meaningful and are fun to play with.

(+) Develops interestingly 3: alliances with mutual advantages, adaptations to space ships, ...

(+) Rather easy and structured gameplay. Few to no fiddly rules or exceptions. Rather easy to explain and really a reasonable play time for a game of its epic scope.

(+) Lots of races (different factions) to play with, bringing variety to the game. They all play very differently.

(-) For a long and epic space exploration and civilization title, there is too much randomness. This can mainly be problematic while exploring (tile draws), hoping for technologies to come up, tile draws after conquering and combat (dice rolls). However, usually the game evens out and normally it rewards good gameplay.

(-) The result of combat can be rather devestating. It is probably hard to win the game only by combat, but it is easy to lose when a stronger opponent crashes your civilization. A good point in the game is that the advantage always goes to the defender (he doesn't have to spend actions on movement, the initiative advantage goes to him and he can muster up cheap but effective star bases when under attack). These principles should avoid unreasonable combat outcomes, but still: it can be hard to impossible to defend against a single player with unique powerful military technologies without spending all your actions just on pinning his entire fleet down.

(-) It is possible to be eliminated from the game before it is over, however, this is highly unlikely to happen.

(-) Minor complaint: very poor choice for colors to represent science, economy and materials: pink, brown, orange - but really, they all are a different shade of brown -> can be confusing :)

Approx playtime: 45 min / player
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
This is a really great game.  I can see it maybe eventually getting old, but for now, it is just super fun, deciding how to tailor your ships and whether you want to focus on exploring a lot of the outer region, or push in on other players.  The competing over limited techs adds just enough variation between games, as well as seeing how to best play each of the aliens against each other. The only reason I don't give it a 10 is that it can go a bit long.  I think reducing the number of III tiles and reducing the number of rounds by 1 or 2 might be a good way of shortening the game time a bit while not losing any of the enjoyable mechanics.

Update: Still enjoying it, but the last few turns do seem to drag.  I like the idea of a house rule that you start rolling a die at the beginning of rounds 6-9, with increasing chance that the game will end; this will give some uncertainty of how many turns you have left to do what you want.  I do also feel that there is still an advantage to hunkering down and let others fight with each other.  Apart from Orion, attacking other players only hurts both your chances of winning.  I also wish there was more diversity in tech, or some species-specific techs, so you really felt like each alien had different ships and tactics a la Star Control.

Update Update: I still really like this game, but I'm feeling it is a bit too long for what it is, and the combat is feeling less fun for me.  Unless you are generating so much brown income that you are maxed out on ships and basically want to lose them so you can build more, combat still seems unattractive, boring, and random to me, compared to my other multiplayer wargame favorites like Maria and Game of Thrones.  The basic attraction for me is trying out all of the races and different strategic paths, but the actual game play is becoming a bit same-y for me and I am just wishing the game was under 2 hours.  Maybe I just need to stick to 3-4 games and avoid 5+.

Update Update Update: Just too random for me to bother playing anymore.  Bad tile draws can really screw a player, putting them in an unwinnable position after just 3-4 turns - it's not fun to have another player not having fun.  And combat is too random - it's sucks to roll badly, but it's almost worst to defeat a player that should have won easily but got really unlucky.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a BRILLIANT game, one of those whose quality really strikes you the first time you play it. It is THE space opera, empire building game that I have been looking for: epic yet streamlined, sufficiently deep yet highly playable.

HIGHLIGHTS: 

* Tech Tree: random tech draws give variability between games. It's fairly open what you can develop, but if you have researched a tech in a particular field already, it's cheaper to develop new ones in the same field. The result is a simple yet elegant tech tree that nudges you in certain directions but is not too restrictive; highly efficient.

* The Resource System: using Through the Ages's idea of removing cubes on your player board as you expand your empire without that earlier game's fiddlyness; a wonderful design solution to the problem of bookkeeping.

* Building your Ships: my favourite part; you can upgrade your own ships so that each player's ships are individual and each player can develop their own military doctrine, so to say. This is all done in a way with ship blueprints and tiles that removes any form of bookkeeping. 

* Action System: a brilliant method of action selection, whereby taking actions and expanding use the same resource (action disks--which like the other resources you remove from your board, exposing the increasing upkeep costs as you use more disks), thereby balancing how much you can do and how much you can expand. 

* Incentive to Fight Early On: the method of awarding VPs for combat (which you draw from a bag and choose the best) give you an incentive to attack early on, as the chances are that at the end of the game only the low value chits will be left.

* Expansion: the explore action is cleverly handled so that you quickly expand, bringing you into conflict with your neighbours very soon. There is no long build up before you get your empire onto a war footing.

All in all, a wonderfully designed game that is a lot of fun to play; you will end up thinking the game a lot after playing it.



HOWEVER, in the interests of balance, two RESERVATIONS:

* It's not so good as a two-player game: one player often gets a technology advantage over the other and is normally in a dominant position by the 6th or 7th turn; it can be interesting to match up the different aliens against each other, but you really need other players to balance out any lucky advantages one player may get. Buy it for multi-player, not two-player, play.

* I do think the plasma missiles are a tad too strong, especially relative to the anti-matter cannon. I look forward to the expansion and the promised plasma missile countermeasure. Still, players should be aware of the danger of an opponent fitting up dreadnoughts with missiles and +3 computers and be able to counter it before they become a threat.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a great area control game with economical elements and an awesome ship customization mechanic.  I've always loved acquiring technologies in games, but I haven't seen anything quite like this, where you then take what you have researched and implement it on your ships as you see fit.  The attitude towards combat depends on the players' attitudes, but I think leans more towards the tendency for players to control an area using the "threat of combat", which is a style I may prefer but some players may not.

I have seen too many discussions comparing this game to Twilight Imperium, and many comments on both sides which I disagree with.  I think that the idea that this is "Twilight Imperium-lite" is silly; they're very, very different, having almost none of the same strengths.  I think those knowing comments that "Eclipse is really a Euro game" are facile; it's somewhere in between, like most games, and anyway, who cares?  Above all, I think the two games are both good, and so different from each other that I almost doubt that anyone who would pit them directly against each other has played both games correctly.

One definite complaint: this game claims to support up to 7 players or 9(!) with expansions.  These seems to be a lie.  The map changes little to accommodate these large player counts, and in the one game I played with over 6 players, we encountered serious issues and the game took an absurd amount of time, after which everyone was quite ready to be done with it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Through the Ages meets Twilight Imperium. Mechanics are elegant and promising, but not everything works as it should. The main problem here is that, for a 4X game, you're very limited in your options for expansion. Bordering with only two players and being in alliance with at least one of them early on for the extra production it gives you, you essentially have no choice of your victim. The road to other players leads through the centre of the galaxy, occupied first by powerful aliens and then by the strongest player, so you attack who you can rather than who you should - the leader. There's also no way to gang-up on someone, so it feels overall more like a euro then ameri, albet a long one, clocking at least 45 minutes for player rather then advertised 30. This however means that the high randomness of battles and luck in discovering new sectors as well as in getting the more powerful (missiles next to imbalanced) technologies feels out of place and is not welcome. You don't want to carefully calculate your options, wait for the other 5 players to complete their turns and then have it all spoiled by bad luck.

(Edit after a second play, 3 players): The timing of conflict is important in this game, and will change depending on the actions of players. The game rewards early conflict, but I guess that Monoliths and Plasma Missiles between them provide two very effective answers to a purely military strategy - by all means, build your killer fleet, but don't expect the game to be a walkover. With 3 players was a very fun way to spend 3 hours, and my earlier experience was considerably mollified. Rating upped!

RATING: 6
Upgrading ships is a lot of fun, and gives some control over combat. The technologies are interesting, and help give variety to the game. I like the way the economic aspects of the game are implemented; the game is so streamlined that you just glance at your player board and know your income. All this without moving those cubes around very often. 

My main issue with the game is how randomness is implemented. There are a lot of options that go on ahead of time that go into improving your chances in combat, but the combat itself feels more random than I want in a game that is otherwise largely about economy and long term planning. Both the economic system and the combat system are functional, I guess it just feels a little odd that the two systems are included in the same game. The economic aspect is well implemented for a longer game of optimization, but the combat feels like it belongs in a shorter game. There are certainly many things you can do to improve your chances, and the better player will win the majority of the time, I just wish the combat felt more in line with the rest of the game.

RATING: 10
Best game I ever played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Feels like after my first play of Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization: the game seems awesome, but you're too much of a noob with tunnel vision to enjoy it for now. All of us could barely track our own stuff, let alone opponents', didn't dare to fight, and were too busy ironing out inefficiencies to worry about strategy (e.g. I'd upgrade my ships, then not use them, then research a better upgrade next turn... now I have to upgrade the suckas again, argh!!).

But I definitely want to play it a lot more, unlike with other games where I appreciate the design, but interest steadily peters out. Beats Through the Ages because the rules language is so much simpler and more intuitive, and it has an interesting board for real conflict. The game time is very manageable, the rules are unexpectedly simple, streamlined and intuitive (I can explain this to new players in 15min), but wow they nevertheless managed to fit [i]everything[/i] into this game.

Reputation Tiles - Nexus Ops Mission Cards (getting random VPs for small successes in battles)
Upkeep - any civilization game (I call this the main pre-req for a civ game), Agricola, Dungeon Lords
Combat - the Axis & Allies system, most similar to Hammer of the Scots. Also in Nexus Ops.
Discs/Cubes - Through the Ages (Happiness/Production) - more discs in play = higher upkeep, vs more cubes in play = more production
Player Mat and Action Cost - Hansa Teutonica - peel cube/disc off and read what's underneath. Both games allow uneven # of actions, but HT makes you weigh # of actions vs. ability of each action, while Eclipse makes you weigh the # of actions vs. monetary cost (can you afford to postpone the action to next turn, when it's cheaper?)
Supply Track / Tech Tree - a supply board like Puerto Rico, and discounts are possible (but to a certain point, like Quarries)
Start Player - like Agricola. Grab it first, the rest follow in seat order.

Not a lot of super-innovative stuff in this game (really just the cute ship customization, and the upkeep-for-variable-number-of-actions concept), but it's amazing how so many elements are packed so tightly and smoothly, with no confusing rules or ambiguous situations at all, like some fine vintage of extra virgin olive oil that just [i]glides[/i] down your throat without some grassy shit smell. It's ambitious and it pulls it off.

The perfect marriage of Eurogame and Ameritrash, uniting gamers of both types at a single table.

[u]Potential concerns[/u]

- Does the game railroad you too much into a strategy? (definitely not, right now, since I'm too overwhelmed to think long-term). I do like reactive luck though, and would have no problem with this, unless it completely handcuffs me from certain strategies.

- Missiles make battles lame when paired with good computers. 

- Boring components. Generic ships that seem to be from a parts store. Cubes/Discs. Money cylinder is shit brown and Material cylinder is dark shit brown, gah.

- Player differentiation is tacked on, 7 Wonders style. Not a big deal, just how it is. Probably even a compliment to the game that it runs so well on its tightly condensed engine, that any attempt at variable player powers just rings superficial.

===========

drunkenKOALA says, "Personally there is nothing awesome about Eclipse, but there is nothing bad about it, which I find very impressive. They managed to get all the chrome and essential elements of a space empire game (military, tech, economy, etc) together with almost no text. Every other space empire game has something "bad" about it complexity-wise. Eclipse is really simple and streamlined for its genre which is a huge plus for me. I think the custom ship upgrades is the best part, because there is actually a rps-like counter going on. I like the best part of 2v2 Starcraft a whole lot better than the best part of Eclipse; but I like the worst part of Eclipse a whole lot better than the worst part of Starcraft. "

Couldn't put it better myself. The high highs and low lows of Ameritrash are tempered by the mechanical consistency of Eurogames. Biggest complaint about Eclipse everywhere is [i]over-design[/i], engineered to the point of little dynamism (e.g. no cards, no 'unexpected'), which is the only thing that stops this from being THE game.

===========

Dreads with Missiles + Gluon Computers suck. Not broken, but does force all the players to react or die, which is too much of an impact on the game. And combat could be wilder: the fun's all in customizing the ships beforehand; actual combat is hard to pull off without hurting yourself, since you need many discs to build, move ships around, customize them, then have the bandwidth to colonize afterward.

[u]Four common rule variants[/u]
 - 18XX-style turn order (no-brainer, only left out of the game for lower complexity)
 - Ships moving through allied player's hex (not stopping) do not betray.
 - Variable game end, or (my likely preference) play to ~45-50 VPs, with Reputation Tiles only revealed when you announce you're past the game-ending VP limit (e.g. Catan).
 - Some kind of Missile+Computer nerf (like introducing an energy cost).

===========

On the downside, this game abstracted away all card luck (which I like due to the fat tail) in favor of dice luck. I miss cards sometimes when bringing this to the table.

5+3

[color=gray][b]Favorite 3-player Med-length - Runner-up[/b][/color]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I bumped into this game completely by accident, being oblivious to the apparently significant hype levels.  I'm certainly glad I was able to play it as I completely enjoyed the experience.

It is an exploration and development game similar to Twilight Imperium.  Here, the exploration effect allows you build up the board in ways that benefit you and hinder (or help) your opponents.  While the luck in this is thematic, it can cause problems.  I feel that the game provides ample opportunity for overcoming initially poor luck.  Many others seem to disagree.

The tech tree is interesting.  I don't particularly like how the techs come out.  It would be nice if your player order could be manipulated to take advantage of this.  Unfortunately, it is blind guess.  That is probably the weakest portion of the game -- the person who has access to some of the best technologies is often a crapshoot.  

Beyond that, I enjoyed the rest of the game.  I like the way combat works for the most part.  I like the resource management, particularly the use of the discs to add significantly increasing costs to your expansion.  Ilike that you can still do things after passing if you really need to.  I've not played with the alien races yet, so I have no opinion on that.

I'm not sure how I feel about the set number of rounds.  It seemed to work out just right in our game.  I do like the various means of scoring victory points.  I'm not sure if it is the best way of determining the winner, but it certainly works.  

All in all, a game I am very happy with.  If I can get some more plays in, I expect that its rating can improve.  [07/08/2012]

Sounds exciting except that the game forces you through a cycle where you try to arm up before the last 2 rounds of tactical skirmishes to wrestle terrain off people. It's alot of work and time spent for very little payoff.

RATING: 2.414
7-hour game!  If my leg had been chained to the table, I would have been tempted to saw it off!

If you've got several hours, you might as well play something like Star Fleet Battles.  To me the whole building up your ships process is a complete waste of time.  (That's like going to a play a role-playing game meeting and everyone sits around for hours rolling up their characters)  Building up your ships should be done beforehand, especially for a long multi-player game.  Who wants to use your ships for attack purposes when you've spent HOURS building the damn things?  That makes your last few hours a complete waste of time!  And then your opponents get to keep their ships and become stronger for not engaging in combat?  You can't seem to move very far within a limited number of turns, etc.  Winning a game like this with bonus points instead of combat seems a bit lame too.

Admittedly, it could play better with fewer players.  My game started with 6 players until the instructor had to leave at which point it became a 5-player game.  I think two of the players who were going to join our game refused to play a 6-player version of this game.  I'm an old fan of Titan which is a game that can be very long and unwieldy with lots of players, but the expansion of territory and units seems to happen faster and better in Titan.  Thus, it might play "okay" as a two-player game.

This game seems to be much more popular in Europe than the United States.  I'm not sure why that might be except that perhaps there aren't enough copies in the United States yet.

The last turn of a game like this could get a bit silly with everyone trying to get one additional point to claim final victory.  I just wasn't prepared for the time length for this one.

RATING: 10

The alien races are really fun.

My only complaint about the game is the inclusion of the 4 tiles in the bag for fighting. That mean that someone could easily get lucky and draw the three fours which is as much as almost maxing out on all the tech trees. and often more than anything you actually do on the board. So I just took mine out and left them in the box.

RATING: 6
Definitely a Euro-version of a 4X game, but with lots of randomness.  It's a worker placement game.  The Influence disks are workers that are assigned to various actions and also uncork the economic game elements in the form of "exploration".  A randomly picked buffet of commodities  (cabbages/paints/technology) are added each turn for players to scrabble over in a first-come-first-served smorgasbord to provide enhancements to their farms/cathedrals/spaceships.  It's called "research" in the game.  Combat is silly.  I attacked an Ancient with two interceptors, two Cruisers and a Dreadnought and rolled dice repeatedly for almost five minutes trying to get sixes.  The entire game can unfold and key technology would never be available.  For instance, I could have numerous Tachyon drives available but not a single Tachyon Source to power it.  This is supposed to provide me with "replayability" but it was thematically unpalatable because how would one ever research Tachyon Drives without the Sources to go with them?   In the end, I would much rather play my 35-year old game of Outreach by SPI.  This is definitely not a good direction for this genre to go.

RATING: 10

RATING: 8
Based on app (hard to get a group together). 

So many ways to win or cleverly time key moves to steal victory. Alien races feel very different. I wish someone would play the board game version with me :(

The app itself is good but has no expansions.

Some really tough decisions based around the context of each game. What tech to take? Which route to take? Who to attack? Now or later?

I feel some people who don't like the game don't understand its intricacies. Yes the VP scoring is a bit random but by giving everyone engaged in conflict some VPs it encourages a third or fourth player to get involved. Exploring is random and has an effect on the game but your job is to make the most of it. This would be silly in a two player game but because people work together to ensure the leader won't run away with victory it balances out.

Every turn gives you something to think about. Every turn is meaningful. That's why it's a great game.

RATING: N/A
New/Sealed
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Eclipse is the real deal! I was initially intruiged because of its meteoic rise, but I must say, deservedly so!
It has all the best elements of an Ameritrash: the drama, the narrative but combines it with the best elements of a Euro: a clean rule set, victory point based scoring.
Players research technologies, with which they can customize their space ships, with which they explore the galaxy and battle to be the most dominant alien civilization. Meanwhile you have to successfully manage three resouces: money, science and materials.
As a mostly Euro player, my biggest gripe with those overproduced Fantasy Flight Games is their unwieldy ruleset. Yes, there are a lot of exceptions which make thematic sense, but for me, those get in the way of the gameplay. Eclipse has none of that, but still delivers on drama and narrative. 
A big part of the credit has got to go to the graphic design. All the iconography is clear and consise, without need to constantly reference the rulebook. Also, the game does a great job in functionally conveying a complex board state, without compromising on thematic presentation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An excellent game with a really great graphic design! The player boards, and graphic design in general, are very well done: a lot of information is clearly displayed in a simple, convenient way! 

The game has the space exploration and conquest feel of Twilight Imperium, without all that annoying negotiation and downtime, and without the never-ending game play! The board shows a central hex, with each player's home hexes in surrounding spaces with space between all of these. Players play either humans or an alien race, all with some variations in starting setup. 

On your turn, you can explore, build ships, move ships (3 types + star base per player), research (buy technologies from a display, filled with random tiles each round), upgrade ships (apply some techs) or place/move influence. The more actions you take and the larger your empire, the greater your maintenance costs! Players continue taking turns until everyone passes (and after you pass, you can still take limited actions if necessary!). You earn VP for holding territory, battling, winning battles, researching, and building certain items. After 9 rounds, the player with the most VP wins!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is quite the beast.  I don't think I have ever played a true 4X game before this one and it was only okay.  It's not that much different than a civ game like Sid Meier's Civilization, which I've also played and enjoyed a bit more.

The game is played over 8 rounds, each round you have a number of turns to perform 1 of 6 actions: exploring, shifting influence, researching new technology, upgrading, building, and moving your fleet.  These actions are limited by the amount of your resources in 3 categories: money (used for actions and influencing areas), science (used for researching upgrades), and building materials (I'm sure you can figure this one out).  There are also several different alien species each with special bonuses and handicaps in different areas to even them out.

I wish there were a little more content here, which may be surprising to some.  Despite how much STUFF comes in this game the amount of different stuff isn't all that much.  There really isn't a lot of difference in the tiles you discover; they either have ancients on them or don't and could have ancient discoveries or one of 4 different types of planets (one for each resource and a wildcard).  The technology trees also aren't that varied.  There's pretty much the same stuff on all 3 which is mostly just different upgrades for your ships to use in combat.

There's a lot of decisions to make each round which I like but it also isn't as deep as it would seem.  There is a definite advantage to maximizing your money.  More money means more actions and more tiles you can influence, in every game where I've maxed out my money track I've won, and by a large margin usually.  After all, the more actions you can take and tiles you can influence typically means the more planets you can colonize so with money the other materials come and with most games the player who takes the most actions usually wins.  In this way I certainly think there are certain alien species that are more powerful but I haven't really played enough to make that definite assertion.

This game is also long which would prevent me from really playing it that often even if I really did enjoy it.  The 2 hours listed on BGG is being generous, it perhaps takes just that with 2 players but the amount of set-up and especially tear-down will add another hour to that easily.  You're probably looking at another hour per player you add past 2 and more players makes this game a lot more interesting in my opinion.  So at the recommended 4 I wouldn't be surprised if the game takes 3-4 hours plus an hour set-up/tear-down.  Ouch.

With that in mind, I will probably rarely play this game.  With such a time investment and considering I don't think this game is as deep as that time investment warrants I think I would rather play better games, even though this one is fine.

Summary - As of early Nov this is my Essen pick of the crop, moreover one of the best games I have played in the last three years. --------------------------------------------------------

Queued for 25 minutes to get this slice of space shenanigans so I hope it will be worth it. The rules are promising,Ti3 lite, with a few clever looking euro twists in the economic part of the game. The production is pretty fabulous as well

Another touch I like is that the Tech. upgrades come out randomly - it creates a tension as you cant predict exactly where you are going.

------------------------------------------

Call of the search - the grail, a fast paced Space empire 4x game has been found. I absolutely love the mesh of Euro mechanics into a Sci fi space opera game, each turn is quick - there is no hanging around , you need to get out there as fast as possible, VPs available for all battle participants makes combat attractive. The semi random technology availability makes for some confounding difficult and wonderful choices, and there seems to be no one way of winning. All this based on one two player game, i imagine it will be even better with more. 

--------------

2nd full game with 4 - just awesum, all followed slightly different strategies, all seemed viable, though the military route won with Science a close second, turtle/explore third and a mixed approach last.

You cant fix a strategy at the start (with Terrans at least) you need to see what exploration and the techs offers you - every tech choice was difficult with a need to boost economy, bulk up ships and VPs.

The wormhole movement rule prevented the bain of multiplayer war games happening i.e player 3 benefiting from players one and two fighting.

On further reflection I think this more in the tradition of a Civilisation type game than a 4x - its the the theme that leans it to the later comparison.


-----------

Third game - again great with a really different challenge from the outset. Now need to play with races.

----------------

Fourth game won by a player whi build the ulitmate 'battle' cruisers - lethal and fast but one hit and they were dead

------------------

Fifth game I won in a five player cold war - I had the race that produces cheaply and was able to knock out 3 momoliths on the last turn for victory, I should have been attacked

-------------------------------

Sixth game i won with race that has bonus vps for system control. Weird game as low cost techs just did not appear first two rounds - also owner of system centre did not win and from a peaceful universe to turn 5 it went v violent thereafter.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Truly excellent, um, "eurotrash" game -- to me it feels a lot like Nexus Ops married to a Caylus or a Hansa Teutonica. There are fleets of mighty plastic ships; there are wooden cubes and a very clever system of progressively more expensive actions.

First impressions are that the luck of various draws can be a killer and that, as has been debated ad nauseam, missiles seem too strong, or at least to distort the rest of the game. It's kind of funny, but the first thing I thought of was David Weber's Honor Harrington series of space operas, where the Star Kingdom of Manticore and the People's Republic of Haven spend several books discovering that whoever can belch out the most thousands of missile pods in any given combat is usually going to win. The same strategy often works here. I'm not at all objecting to the idea that a transformative technology or tactical doctrine can be, well, transformative -- but no other technology (except perhaps wormholes) has the same level of effect on the game, and that I don't like.

This fills the niche in my collection I had hoped would be filled by the likes of Nexus Ops and Small World: an almost perfect light conflict game. That it's not really light at all just goes to show that I should stop buying light games.

-- 

My previous rating reflected what I saw as the game's promise, but that promise has never been realized. Every game I've played I've made some excuse as to why it was less enjoyable than it could or should have been. I'm tired of making excuses. There are many wargames I'd rather play for my conflict fix and many euros I'd rather play for the economic development.

I'm the first to admit that I don't do well with games centered on open conflict, but Eclipse exacerbates the problem by being sufficiently abstracted and euro-fied that it does not feel like a thematic adventure; it feels like a spreadsheet game with capricious random elements added. It's absolutely not a game for me.

RATING: 9
Wow...great game!  I'm impressed by everything about it...the time requirement is manageable, the mechanisms are fun and innovative, the play moves quickly, the rules are remarkably digestible.  I have the same feeling about this game that I had about Through the Ages--i.e., "I can't believe what a great boardgame interpretation of computer game X this is!"

I love the courage of the tech trees being uncertain, so that people can't have planned strategies for their tech progress.  I love the ship blueprints.  I love the movement/combat systems and how they make war difficult even for those with overwhelming force without feeling contrived.

My worries?  Well, I think the game may be best with 4 or 6 just for the symmetry.  I also think that my play group needs to work on less turtling, more fighting.  But generally this is as good a multiplayer wargame/civ game as I've come across.

RATING: 8.5
Amazingly great game. It is like Twilight Imperium 3, but in half the time. Unfortunately, the game is still prone to a little too much luck and variance than I'd prefer. Also, I wish there was a little bit MORE to the game, as it is very combat oriented and can become a dice fest.

Hopefully, the expansion(s) will fix these problems, and I see this game making it easily into the top 10, if not the top 5.

EDIT: After repeated plays, the game still holds up, but lacks some of the interesting surprise mechanisms that I enjoy (like secret action cards or some type of hidden information). This doesn't hurt the game much, but decreases my rating from a 9 to a 8.75, and maybe an 8.5 depending on how I feel after a few more plays. Bumped it back up to a 9 because of how different the alien factions feel. Definitely changes the game and adds a lot more replayability.

Need to try playing with "draw 2; keep 1" for tiles when exploring. Right now there's a ton of variance that is only exaggerated with the expansions.

EDIT 2: Dropped down to an 8.5 due to how much variance there can be in the game that just screws someone over early and compounds throughout the whole game. Still a great game, but can feel like an impossible battle with luck sometimes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Hybrid space conquest game with many innovative features. The premise is a tried and tested one, where players have to explore and conquer different systems thereby increasing the resources available to them, which are needed to increase fleet size and develop technologies. So far, so 'Twilight Imperium'. Where this game differs so much from its predecessors is that at its heart its a Euro resource-management game with a fixed number of turns. The three resource tracks, which allow players to increase their number of actions, develop more technologies, and increase the size of their fleet, is an incredibly well-designed mechanism, very Euro in its style, and certainly makes 'Eclipse' stand out from similar games. The fact that you know when the game will end due to the set turn number means that players are forced to be pro-active in their strategies. You are forced into going onto the front foot and there's no point players sitting there spending and age developing a huge fleet in the hope of a slow and attritional game. The game doesn't quite have the epic scope of some other similarly themed games, but its mechanisms are certainly something to be commended and its manageable play length means that it stands out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Have played 20+ times. Own RotA and SotR expansion (and can fit everything in the base box). This is my favorite heavy game. Even better with larger player counts.

For people trying to cut down play time:
- Use the dual action tokens that came in the RotA expansion. This allows 2 players to take actions at once. Plus it makes the game feel like a real time strategy vs turn based strategy as the board is always changing.
- Organize the ship parts in a Plano box ($3.99 at amazon). When someone takes the upgrade action, pass them the box and the next person can start their action. 
- Resolve two combat hexes at the same time. Have two people who know the combat mechanisms and have combat performed in parallel, unless they could effect each other.
- Bag the discovery tiles and draw them randomly from the bag. No need to have a stack on the table to draw from.

RATING: 7.2
It does a lot of good things; all of the good things from TI3, but with 2-9 hours less time time invested. I like the exploration (and I'm inclined to agree that it balances out fairly well overall), the the tech-trees are simple enough, the various options seem well balanced and well thought out.

My main gripes are that the honour tokens for taking part in (or winning) a battle are random and hidden, the techs all do too many of the same things (if 1 gives you increased chance to hit and one reduces the chance to hit, they are largely pointless, if one gives you a second die to roll and one doubles the damage one die does, they are *basically* the same). It seems a lot like there are choices for the sake of choice, when in practice, the differences between any two or three is tiny.

Finally, combat can be tedious when it requires an average of 36 die rolls to resolve (using a couple of poorly equipped guns).

Yes, all of these are avoidable, but they detract from an otherwise very promising game.

RATING: 9
Eclipse takes [i]Twilight Imperium 3[/i] and replaces its heavy influence of [i]Puerto Rico[/i] with [i]Through the Ages[/i].  It also cuts out all of TI3's fat, making for a quicker, stream-lined 4X. I like Eclipse's leanness, but I also like TI3's fat.  (Like with meat, the fat is often where you find the flavour.)

RATING: 7
Here's the very prototype of a preliminary rating as the rating rather reflects what I think this game will settle down at or what I want it to be, because in all honesty the 2-player-session I played was rather a 6.5 or a 7.0, but then again this game isn't meant for 2players. I am intrigued by the tech "trees" and the customizable ship types, I am intrigued by the rules for the diplomacy in a game with more players, I am intrigued that someone who doesn't stand to his word gets to be penalized with the traitor card and might have to stick with it until the end of the game, I am intrigued with the possibility of still reacting to a game situation even after having passed and I love how they considered that these actions would of course be weaker than the regular action and I definitely like the combat system. There's so much in here, but in this 2p-session my coplayer fell behind and - he was right in that -there was no way for him to catch up or no mechanics that would compensate - in a game with 3 or more players other coplayers would have targeted the leader, i.e. me, but with 2 players that gets kind of hard. So, here's my advice: However much you yearn to try this game, don't play it with 2. 
Kudos to the design team. They created something that is paradox at first glance when really it isn't: It's an epic game on a "small scale". That said it doesn't quite achieve the space opera feeling that TI 3rd edition evokes,but it comes close and it exceeds contenders like Phantom League by far. 
--------------------------------------------------
Update: Woah, that was a disappointment. With 5 players this game comes close to the same game length as TI 3rd edition. And setting up really takes loooooooooong! Unfortunately our session suffered from the same cons as TI3 and adds heavy new ones. Sharing the negatives:
- cold war conduct (building up fleets, trying to intimidate opponents and only at the very end battles occur)
- very dependent on luck of the roll (Seeing everything you build up in hours fall to pieces within a few seconds of outrageously bad die rolls sucks)

Cons it adds on top:
- very dependent on luck of the draw (when it comes to reputation tiles from battle)
- Missilegeddon makes a huge impact on the game (Hopefully this is fixed with the expansion)
- even more downtime than in TI3. At least there you can make use of the secondary ability when it's other player's turn. There's nothing you can do except wait for your turn again in Eclipse. 

Really, this game is not the No.1 4x game the BGG ranking would make believe. I stil love the ship type configuration and the resource management, but still I expected this game to shine. Which it didn't! People claim, it achieves things TI3 doesn't, when in fact it's not an improvement in regards to its reference. Will probably have to wait for quite some time before this one hits the table again! Maybe I'm so pissed off at this game, because I knew we could have fit a session of Clash of Cultures and Tzolk'in in it. And I saw that most of the group didn't have a good time playing.

RATING: 6
Man, this game is so damn fun. There's just so much randomness, strategic depth, and options involved with each turn you take, and your race changes it up so much... gathering resources, discovering ancient artifacts, developing new tech, upgrading you ship designs, printing more military... there are so many things you can do in this game, so many ways to win, it's just super cool.
But...
Oh dear sweet lord, this game is such a time investment. Seriously, don't bother without 4 hours. Worse, over an hour of that is likely setup and tear down. Organize the bits as much or as wisely as you want, it still takes forever. Likewise, it isn't just getting the free time together, if it isn't your turn, you are extremely univolved. This means other players turns don't involve you one iota typically (MAYBE some diplomacy or a combat happen... not more often than not). So you won't be participating in at least half this game, for two play... 1/3 for three, 1/4 for four, etc... and while you could argue that's normal, when turns can take 10+ minutes, its a real damn issue. I found myself pulling out my iphone... which is not something you should do during a board game, an activity meant to be social. 
Sadly, even making it an AP didn't help... while faster than a human, even the AI takes awhile with turns. I makes it hard to recommend it, crazy as it sounds for how fun it is when you're actually playing.
Sadly, you spend little time while playing Eclipse actually PLAYING.

RATING: 5
Lots of fun. Upgrading your ships is lots of fun on its own, but there's also different factions that all play differently, exploring, and war (or trying to avoid war).

Update: Increasing my rating after playing with the expansion. The expansion makes the two player game more interesting by adding some ancient homeworlds to go after, and some warp portals that can make it easier to move across the board if you want encounter the other player more often. Also, the game is just a good euro that has some combat and lots of theme.

Update again: I've heard this complaint, but I've finally seen for myself one big flaw of the game: drawing the blind combat tiles is a huge random element. If a combat-heavy player draws poorly, he can easily lose the game based on pure luck of the draw. The randomness of the technology tiles can also be an issue. I've seen games where no power sources came out, except for one, for almost the whole game and the player who got that one upgraded power source won easily. That upgraded power source allowed him to get the other great technology tiles that came out, while the other players didn't have enough power to get upgraded tiles. Some sort of variant to correct the combat tile draw and the technology draws would be needed if I play again.

I still like the game overall, but between these flaws and some people I play with not liking the game, I got rid of it.

Sold.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
I'm very excited to get this one to the table.

::UPDATE::

I got it to the table and I was disappointed. I recently traded it away. Here are my issues:

1. Luck-riddled exploration ruins the game from the start. The first half of the game isn't about planning any kind of long-term strategy. It's about exploring and hoping ([i]oh please let me get a good tile, please![/i]) you uncover a useful tile. If not, bummer. Oh well, I have a couple more turns to try. The decisions are boring in the beginning.

2. Lucky draws for victory. So a player goes to battle a couple times early and draws the high-point tiles. Game over. It's boring for everybody involved because you can tell by the smug look on that player's face what he's got. Secondly, it's boring for him too. He's going to win and he knows it. All he has to do is play out a mediocre game for the next few hours. Which brings me to the last point.

3. Too long for what it delivers. I can play a game of Puerto Rico with five players in 90 minutes. In that 90 minutes, I will make uncountably more interesting decisions than I will a 6-hour session of Eclipse. There just aren't very many interesting decisions in this game. It all seems like aimless decisions: [i]"Well, I did some exploring and got some tiles that were okay--I wish I would have been as lucky as Bill over there, his tiles turned out to be awesome!--I guess I'll start seeing about upgrading my ships a little...I guess."[/i]

This game has received unbelievable praise. I just don't get it. I want to make interesting, difficult decisions. When I play Eclipse, I feel like I'm on autopilot.

::UPDATE::

10/4/2013 - After creating [geeklist=163260][b]this GeekList[/b][/geeklist] and putting Eclipse as my most-overrated game, a friendly Geek pointed out to me that according to my own definition of overrated, it was in fact not my overrated unless I lowered it a whole point. So, I now rate it 4.5. Most overrated game I know. :b

RATING: 6
I'm torn on this game. I think the design is really, really clever. There's a ton of interesting choices. There's quite a bit of luck in dice rolls and exploration, but with careful planning and other players keeping any runaway leader in check, I think the game is sufficiently balanced. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Plays: 1.

I was dead-set against liking Eclipse before I actually played it, but because I was in the minority opinion of our group of four, I put my most optimistic foot forward and kept an open mind so I wouldn't seem like a jerk.

I was pleasantly surprised by how easy the turn-to-turn gameplay was. When you first see all the pieces and numbers, it seems fiercely complex, but really when you get into the swing of things it's fine.

I enjoyed the resource gathering a lot; very elegant in its design. Building and moving ships was also cool. However, the methods by which you purchase and apply tech is needlessly complicated. And unbalanced: if you get the right piece of random tech from a defeated alien, you can pull far ahead of your opponents early on.

Also, while the game seems very open and full of options, it actually becomes incredibly restrictive at the end. If you get locked in with tiles that won't allow you to expand further (and thereby kill aliens, the only way you'll really win), you'll be forced to start taking your opponents' territory. And if some of your opponents are far too powerful, you may be forced to take out your trading ally, and therefore take a penalty to your victory points.

The theme could also use some work, but I guess that's common for these types of games. I admit I don't understand Eclipse's popularity, and it's not terrible, but I don't think I'll voluntarily play it again.

RATING: 7.5
After playing this a few more times, years after its release it has grown on me a bit.

It's a nicely designed very euro'y 4X game.  The way you get to design your ships and add new techs is quite cool.  The economic balancing act of "can I afford to do another action?", "do I forfeit control of this sector to save cash?" is a really interesting mechanic that more games should use.  

My only issues with the game are the very large luck of the draw map setup.  Due mainly to luck you can be surrounded by open space or ancients while your opponent is drowning in resource rich planets.  While it's not impossible to overcome, it isn't easy to come back from that since the game does involve a technological snowball effect.  You go from having slow, ships that hit on a 6 and have the defense of a Ford Pinto to having a full blown Doomsday Device that is virtually indestructible, so if you get behind the 8-ball you will probably stay there....for 2 hours.

The scoring might be one of my favorite parts of this game because the temptation to have the biggest most frightening army is so great, but also isn't the easiest way to get points.  Long term planning and not losing focus on points generally pays off, but the game will constantly tempt you with a bigger laser at the expense of 2 points!  Just do it!  Look at how big it is!

All in all it's a fun game, and quicker than most other 4X games, it gives you the full experience in 2 hours -- albeit with the potential for a hard luck game or two.

RATING: 6
This underwhelmed me compared to the hype. It's not by any means bad. It's just that it's simply not 'as good' at any of the things it does as a handful of other games in any category, and the sum total of it's parts isn't impressive enough to me.

If I want to play ship customization, I'll play Galaxy Trucker.

If I want to play diplomacy/player interaction, I'll play Republic of Rome, Twilight Imperium 3rd.

If I want to play space combat, I'll play Space Empires 4x or Twilight Imperium 3rd (or any of a longer list for just better combat in general).

If I want to farm victory points, I'll play just about any euro on the shelf.

I have never found myself wanting to do *all* of those things at once, and when I get even close to it Twilight Imperium 3 does it better for me, in a similar play time with an experienced group of players (which I fortunately have available readily)
