=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Epic space opera experience. 

The game has tension, variety, replayability, tough decisions, tough diplomacy, an excellent pace and of course an excellent theme. The eloquent (simple yet very deep) mechanics are excellent, and the action/cost system along with the technology system are the highlights. The optional alien races are also excellent and appear to be both balanced and very different. Battles are tense and not mathy, with the blueprint system being unbelievably effective. The pace of the game also deserves a special note, as what starts as an exploration game gradually evolves into a race for the center and then an epic showout. The flow is also great, as half an hour per player for such an experience is an amazing trade.

Exploration appears a simple part of the game, but is actually by far the most complicated. Reacting to your exploration results (what systens to keep/discard, when to go for the ancients and at what odds, what economic tech to go for, what to explore and in what order so as not to be blocked, what systems to immediately colonise/colonise and then abandon/colonise later etc) is half the game. This is great for veterans as it creates a very fluid and balanced replayability but not so good for new players who can easily mis-react to their exploration and be out of the game from early on. The most major problem for the game is than an early battle loss can be crippling, and although players can and should mitigate this with technology, there will still be the odd early battle from time to time where a player will lose even with 95% chances to win -  and there is no way back from that. Everything I note here as a disadvantage, is a very minor issue for me, both because it doesn't affect experienced play at any important degree, and because I don't know or can think of game that can make exploration&combat better than Eclipse.

All in all, it is an excellent game, that also hits a sweetspot in my preferences, and thus I cannot think of myself ever denying to play this.

RATING: 9.5
An extremely layered and satisfying space 4X game.  Every part of this game, including exploration, building ships, researching technologies, upgrading ship parts, expanding empires, and combat, all mesh together perfectly.  The mechanic where influence disks indicate how many actions you have available as well as the size of your empire is brilliant and thematically correct.  The whole game feels clean and just makes sense, there aren't any annoying rules that aren't streamlined which is saying a lot for a game of this size.  The rules are easy to understand after only one play, and the luck in the game is easily mitigated with strategic play.  It is also beautiful and impressive when it is laid out on the table.  This is an economic game at its core, it is all about using the resources you have to the best of their ability.  It just so happens that some of those abilities include making meaningful alliances, developing advanced ship fleets, and clashing those ship fleets against your enemies, which is awesome.  Fantastic.

RATING: 7
Eclipse is almost everything I hoped (and expected) it to be. An interesting combination of euro-style resource management and ameritrash space battles with streamlined player turns and a strong theme. And it lets you  configure your own spaceships! Love the fact that, for such an epic game, the rules are intuitive and easy to comprehend, downtime is minimal and playing time very acceptable (although is still a pretty long game). Components are great, except for the standard spaceships. Depending on the tiles you draw when exploring, it might start a little slow though. And it doesn't really keep you on the edge of your seat most of the turns. Still, it is a very enjoyable game, and the only epic space opera game I need in my collection.
UPDATE: Lowered my rating to a 7. It seems that in every game so far we had a player who was denied victory due to some unlucky tile draws at the beginning of the game. A big drawback as far as I am concerned.

RATING: 8
On the short list of the best space-themed games out there.  It manages to distinguish itself from a crowded genre with amazingly tight actions and resources, along with extreme granularity in ship building.  The influence system is ingenious, and this game expertly toes the line of just enough detail without being confusing.

The inevitable comparison is to [gameid=12493].  They're both long space operas with races fighting over a hex-based map.  This clocks in at about 2/3 the length, but you don't quite have the same distinguishing races and player powers, or quite the same epic feel.  This game is focused on small skirmishes, while TI3 is about sweeping offensives.  You probably don't need to own both. My preference is for TI3, but there's a valid argument to owning this one instead.

RATING: 9
UPDATE: Selling my copy of Eclipse. I love this game, but it only shines with a large (6-9 player) gaming group. We typically have 2 - 4 players, and only 3 gamers maximum. It's not great at this player count. We're keeping Clash of Cultures, which has the same feel, but works at smaller player counts. Unfortunately, Eclipse needs to be taking to London on Board (our local gaming group) and played in an all-night session from 5:30 to 10:30pm. The occasions when we can do this due to husband's working hours mean it's unlikely to get played more than once or twice a year :(

UPDATED: Rating raised to 10 after playing two-player, despite an unbalanced Orion/Hydra game where Jon wiped out my forces plus the Galactic Centre on turn three. It's like the heavy version of Cyclades two-player... A brutal wargame with a cool sci-fi theme, and science and economic bits.

UPDATED: To 9 after playing a six-person game in four hours. It's an epic 4x space game playable in an evening - ameritrash feel, but running a euro strategy engine to introduce speed, smoothness and skill. Loads of shouting. Absolutely brilliant fun. I'd recommend it to anyone who fancies TI3, but isn't sure about the running time: there's skullduggery in spades with the right crowd - we had three traitors in one game.

****

My husband loves this and wants to play it constantly (two-player). He'd probably give it a 9.

I'd give it a 6 or 7. Winning seems too dependent on which tiles you discover when you 'explore'. We've played twice and the first time I found a bunch of habitable star systems while exploring (and won). The second time, he did (and won). I'm sure it's not as simple as that, but I felt this luck factor was unfair for a game that is broadly skill-based.

The fighting system is absurdly silly. Roll X dice and see what hits... Regardless of what technology you've bolted to your ships, you'll miss most of the time.

The pieces are good quality, but the artwork is ugly. Lots of bits in the box for the money. If you're considering getting Eclipse, I'd definitely recommend it.

RATING: 5
Played this once with 4 players and the following house rules suggested by the experienced player at the table: (a) players choose from +1 tile for their first 3 explorations, (b) turn order for next round is determined by passing order this round, (c) tech tiles available next turn are on display this turn.

All in all I think this is a very successful attempt at a 2-3 hour 4X game (at least with 4 players, which I sense is the game's sweet spot). Even though I'm not the target audience for this type of game, I can appreciate why it has risen so astronomically in the BGG rankings. However, the plasma missiles really do warp the combat dynamic in an unpleasant and uninteresting way, and without the aforementioned house rules I would find serious fault with the randomness of the game. Even with them, the randomness of tile draws ans dice rolls can be a decisive factor in who does well, but in fairness I suppose that's intrinsic to this type of game and thus to an extent unavoidable.

I'd be more interested in playing and possibly even owning Eclipse if it weren't for the plasma missiles. Not that they alone are the culprit, but they're bothersome enough to push me off the fence where I would otherwise be sitting with regards to further exploring this game.

RATING: 4
The problem, I think, is that I just don't like 4X games (too much aggression, when what I really prefer is confrontation), but that's not the only thing wrong with Eclipse.  Part of it is the time of the game (2-3 hours with two players, and I saw a game of six take over six hours, not including rules explanation), and then the other part is the randomness of the technology tiles.  It can really, really suck for the player going last if very few weapons technologies come out and he's stuck without him.  Being the nature of these sorts of games, the weakest player will just become a target for every other player, and it just stops being fun when you're being beaten on by everyone else.  I only played one two-player game, which probably exacerbated the issue, but that was enough for me to get a feel for it and realize this just isn't my sort of game.  For folks who like that sort of aggression, I get the feeling they'll like it, but for me, it's just more frustrating that anything else.

1 play: 2 players

RATING: 10
What an amazing experience. I love pretty much all about it. Graphic design and character design is really well made with a strong retro vibe. All the X's are here:

EXplore - Even when every tile possible is explored you still feel like a conqueror, finding discoveries, gaining special reputation tiles (SotR), hives (RotA), anomalies (SotR) behaving in an unpredictable ways...

EXpand - You can see the color of your empire spreading all over the galaxy! It looks and feels powerful.

EXploit - Every technology you get, every planet you harvest, every discovery you find and implement... The galaxy is yours to dominate.

EXterminate - Tons of dice on top of a Euro engine. It's such a beautiful contradiction. Battling is unpredictable as it should be. No silly cards, no power points just you, your opponents and shooting across the space!

My favourite multiplayer game of all time.

Player Count:
:d10-2: good (more of a euro game)
:d10-3: very good
:d10-4: amazing!
:d10-5: amazing!
:d10-6: amazing!
:d10-7: bigger galaxy feels epic, amazing from time to time

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I can certainly see why Eclipse has become such a phenomenon on BGG. I think that most of us that are "geek" enough to like boardgames, are predisposed to liking space and science fiction as well. Previous games offered in this genre have had a tendency to be both long and complicated. As a general rule, that put most of them squarely in the province of wargamers and ameri-trashers.

Eclipse though, is a different beast. It utilizes a ton of streamlining and abstraction to eliminate the usual tedium of tracking resource production, empire sprawl and trade, i.e., the things that usually make managing a cardboard empire a real chore. Also, there is little, if any, downtime between turns. The only thing that slows play down is combat...but again, compared to other games of the genre it plays out very quickly.

One thing I was surprised to discover is that Eclipse isn't the Space Civilization game many early adopters have made it out to be. The technology base of the game is almost entirely military, so victory via more passive approaches is nigh impossible. There isn't much in the way of objectives either. The vast majority of victory points come through aggressive behavior. It is a race to conquer from the start, so if you typically play your games with an eye for the merchant win, you might want to find a different game.

Once you've dispelled the illusion that you will be doing anything other than smashing face, you can begin to enjoy Eclipse for what it is. The technology system is pretty interesting, as new advances appear in a random order every game, making them more or less valuable depending on the timing. This has ripple effects throughout the game, altering the strategies of players and forcing them to adapt to the constantly fluctuating power levels of their opponent's war vessels. Which brings me to the the most interesting part of the game.

Warships in Eclipse do not have fixed abilities or combat ratings. They are almost completely modular and allow players to customize them with quite a bit of tactical flexibility. A player can focus on building first strike missile boats, "unsinkable" hulls, or lightning fast interceptors that can deliver neutron bombs behind enemy lines. It's a great feature and the one thing that will keep me coming back to this game, when the Cult of the New buzz wears off. I'm not sure I see it as a top 5 game...but it's a damn good one.

RATING: 4
I want my space games to be loud and sexy, not drawn-out operas that sing in Italian for 3+ hours and bore me to tears.  If you like to peer down at your games from the royal viewing balcony, though, [i]Eclipse[/i] could be up your alley.

I could prattle on about my general dislike of 4X games, but it boils down to the fact that I find them to be scripted (OK, time to scout resource planets...) and not remotely fun.  As I explore the Big Black, I want to cut through the hull of an abandoned shuttle and have an alien vault onto my face and rip the corneas from my eyes.  I don't want to massage my tech tree and resource scheme so that I can upgrade my light fighters to lightly armored light fighters.

It's also annoying that [i]Eclipse[/i] has the same flaw as every other 4X game: if you flip the wrong resource/planet tiles during your exploration phase, you're probably screwed.

Non-4X space games I'd rather play: [i]Star Trek Fleet Captains[/i], [i]Shadowlord![/i], [i]Battleship Galaxies[/i].

4X games I'd rather play: [i]Galactic Emperor[/i], [i]Empires of the Void[/i], [i]Ascending Empires[/i].

A 4X game I will never play: [i]Twilight Imperium[/i], because I don't want to jump into a 6-8 hour game that I know I'll hate.

Warning: I don't rate any 4X games higher than a 6, so my comments should be taken with a grain of salt, pepper, or resource of your choice.

RATING: 7
Imports a lot of pleasant Euro-y things into an Ameritrash game with mixed results.  While some of the Euro mechanics are welcome - the board/playboard/cube mechanic lifted from Through the Ages works very well - Euro banality does eventually inflict damage on the game's theme.  See: awarding randomized victory points for simply having combat.  Why do this?  Because we want to encourage combat!  Thus gross idiocy triumphs over nuanced development, and gaminess triumphs over theme.

Will I play it again?  Certainly.  But it doesn't scratch an itch on the ass of TI:3.

RATING: 8
Very cool game; nice design (gameboard as well as the starships) and lots of ways to win so you can try out different strategies. Two major downsides though; first of all the little cubes which are hell for klutzes like me. And secondly the fact that this game is very prone to "analysis paralysis". Because you can score in many ways, you'll probably end up with at least one adversary who'll analyse every single scenario before making a move. Since players cannot play at the same time, this makes for long pauses. So a piece of advice; choose your fellow players wisely and don't play with the guy that already has trouble choosing a drink...

RATING: 8.5
While I've only been able to play this game a handful of times, I know that it is something that I really enjoy. 

It is essentially an economic civilization building game with an element of war mixed in with a healthy dose of luck. There are so many possibilities each round yet everything is very streamlined and not overly complicated. You're constantly trying to balance everything that you'd like to do with what you can economically afford. You also need to pay attention to what your opponents are doing as what might seem like a healthy alliance could come back to bite you if you're not careful.

Playing with the asymmetrical powers of the aliens really brings out the best in the game. While one race may seem overpowered at the beginning, another race might have a more beneficial longer-term strategy. Playing to your races strengths is key and is something that I haven't been able to explore due to my limited plays. I also think that you need to play the game with at least 4 as there isn't enough tension in the early parts of the game with 3. While I have only been able to play the game once with 4 and with the difference races, I can see its potential and wish that I could play it more.

RATING: 6
Rating will likely descend sharply with more plays. Much like an attack ship on fire...


I think [i]Galactic Emperor[/i] is superior to this, but I am clearly in a very small slither of a minority of thinking here. BGG is a GEEK site that has a love affair with sci-fi themed games above all else. This game delivers its dose of confirmation bias to those that need it, overlooking significant flaws.

Quick summation - as I should be doing something else right now.

1. Draw a few shitty explore tiles early in your game - forget it. Make a coffee. Bake a pie. Plan what game you'll play when the choice of the evening comes 'round to you. Don't plan on doing a victory dance.

2. Doesn't feel like you're ruling a space empire. At all. Fun has escaped out of the airlock.

3. Mostly a solitaire game until the dreaded LAST TURN KING-MAKING BATTLE.

4. Turtling is encouraged. Space battles are infrequent and uninspired.

5. Tech tiles are hugely numerous, fiddly, and mostly boring.

6. Another commentator put it better than I ever could 'Plays way too long, but ends before things get interesting.'


All said and done - this game is made for others (not me) who desire such things.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
To be honest, I haven't played this game much.  I love the mechanics.  Though, when I first tried it, I had never played a 'worker placement' style game, so it took me a round or two to understand the mechanics of it.
I would like to play it more, but for a few small issues.
First, the game takes up A LOT of space (no pun intended).  The table i have just isn't enough room for a good game.  I can fit 2, maybe 3 player.  But as soon as I add more than that, the tech sheet has to go on a coffee table beside us - not terribly convenient for play.  
Second, (sort of an extension of the first) is the fact that each persons personal play sheet and resource management can be quite tedious.  When you're moving your own blocks around, your oft to accidentally knock one out of place and spend a couple of minutes just trying to figure out which resource type it was supposed to be on.  And when it's another player sheet, it is really hard to, at a glance, figure out what is going on.  The fact that each person has resource trackers that are tiny, vaguely coloured and (and this is a big one) too big to fit on the single number track together (ie, if all your resources are at the same number, you'll often stack them, and have them fall over and yet again spend a few minutes trying to figure out where they should be) makes the game more *fiddly* than it could be.  
Thirdly, combat.  Not quick to resolve.  It seems like it should be quick.  But it isn't.  You will be taking your ships on and off the board, just to have them lined up in initiative order, then trying to remember each ships upgradestats.  And the pips on the upgrades DON'T correspond to pips on the dice - very counter-intuitive.  
It works, but again, it's just not streamlined.  This game should steal some of the component/mechanical ideas from other games to fix the frustrating fiddlyness.  
Again, mechanically, it is a sound game that is enjoyable once a session actually starts flowing and you remember how each part works.  But, the first few rounds will be spent going "so...  how many dice do I need?" or "which block is supposed to be there?" etc...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A gem of a 4x game that reminds me a little of Galactic Civilizations on PC. The customization of your ships is a brilliant idea and implemented in an excellent fashion. This is where the game shines for me. 

Beware that there is randomness in the draw of tiles, research, dicerolls but that it can be mitigated by adaptive play and the right choices. People who mind a luck factor will probably not like the game very much, but if you like a strategy of adapting yourself to the situation on the board and see what you can make of it, then the game is for you. 

It doesnt have as many options as Twilight Imperium, but I find it clearer and more streamlined. It's also more a eurogame score VP game compared to the fantasy flight esque space game of TI. One thing TI does better is the diplomacy with a voting system and it has a more fleshed out story. Eclipse has a more euroesque mechanic with actions-resource interaction. While TI is strategic resource management with negotiation.
